reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak is a well made sequel to Homeworld - tactic and RTS fans get their money's worth.

Since I was fortunate enough to participate in the beta test I have played long enough to give you my review.

Story
The story is actually a prequel to Homeworld 1. In part 1 the intro reveals that alien artifacts have been found within the desert of Kharak which made the construction of a mighty spaceship possible.
And the latest part Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak tells you the story about the search and excavation of the artifacts on the planet Kharak.

Gameplay
You control some sort of rolling aircraft carrier called Kapisi (your mobile HQ) through the life-threatening world of the planet Kharak. Kapisi allows you to store resources, research technologies, and the production of units. Although Kapisi has the functionality of a base, its mobility helps to set it apart from traditional RTS games. Thus a proper base building does not exist. You're looking for a suitable location and gather resources to enlarge your fleet and to research new technologies.

Above everything else it's a strategy game. You can use the units from previous missions in upcoming ones, therefore you should keenly collect all resources and build units before moving on to the next mission.
A unit limit prohibits you from taking too many units to the next mission. Grr.

The roughly 15 hour long singleplayer campaign is tactically rather moderate and not very rapid. Most importantly you must take over good positions step by step to intercept your enemy, gather artifacts and finally destroy the enemy. In the online mode and skirmish battles everything's much more rapid, there are also 3 different win conditions in the skirmish gamemode.

Otherwise one notices the well executed control system, the fitting sound, the good lighting effects and the breathtaking graphics within the gameplay. In terms of gameplay it's a well made game, though the shortness of the singleplayer campaign and the Interface, which needs getting used to, disturb a bit in the beginning.


Pros: Breathtaking graphics and great effects thanks to the Unity engine
Sound &. Music fit the game very well and sound great
Easily learned and uncomplicated unit controls
Good animations and short video sequences with real actors in between missions
Well done and very innovative multiplayer mode. Expect tense fights with differing win conditions, like for example destroying the main base, total destruction or the hunt for artifacts (a kind of Capture the Flag)
Good physics and you can use the terrain to your advantage
Steam Achievements & Steamcloud
Neutral: The AI is not completely stupid, but currently only hardly reacts to areal attacks and it's easy to properly position oneself, trick the AI and intercept the constantly reocurring attack pattern.
There is no minimap but a tactical interface.
Only" 13 singleplayer story missions which are beaten within 12-15 hours on medium difficulty
Cons: Newcomers to the Homeworld Series are left with unanswered questions regarding the story
Interface and construction menu requires getting used to
There is a pretty generous unit limit

Conclusion:
Someone who likes RTS should take a closer look at this innovative
recommended: but only if one's not only keen on a singleplayer campaign
hoursPlayed:
but also enjoys a few skirmishes or playing online.

This review was written as a valuation inside of its own genre.


Total rating: 8/10


If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but for this one I just felt I have to.

First of all let me super straight - the game brought a lot of positive memories from my past when I spent dozens of hours playing Homeworld, then Homeworld 2 and then the Complex fan-based modification. The graphics, the music, the gameplay, the story, the general vibe of a Homeworld game - it's all there.

Unfortunately there're a lot of other issues with the game that I found rather disappointing. All of them seem to align with what other not-so-excited reviewers are writing.

First, campaign length. I've spent about 10 hours playing campaign only. I've tried to obtain every resource available on *all* 13 missions and it only took me less than 10 hours to get this done. I felt quite disappointed when I realised this is it.

Second, the AI is just, well, dump. There's no real challenge here. Just built dozens of AA units and fear that AI will send ground units only? Don't worry, they'll keep on sending those fighters.

Worry an enemy AA unit will rush to help his friends being bombarded 100 meters away? Don't worry, the AA battery will just nicely sit there, waiting to be eliminated by your ground troops once you clear the area around using air units.

I haven't lost a single mission in this game. Hell, it was more of a... cakewalk.

Third, just five maps in skirmish mode? Really?

So tl;dr;. Would I spend €46 for this game knowing how short my satisfaction would be? Probably not. Would I recommend it to a die-hard Homeworld fan? Probably yes, but only if you're really willing to spend this amount of cash for a game so short.

reviewText:
Positives:

- Wonderful audio

- Gameplay is very fun

- Art Design and Graphics are good, the game looks very good overall

- The story is fantastic, especially for a RTS. If you liked the old homeworld games lore, get this one asap. Interesting characters, well written story and dialogue. Did I just write that for a RTS game... Yup lol. Best writing in a RTS since World in Conflict.

- The Atmosphere is very well done, it feels like Homeworld, oozes the whole feel perfectly


Negatives Or Things that can be improved:

- The AI needs some work

- More maps would be nice (I have seen today the devs announced free maps are on the way down the road)

If you prefer a slower RTS, over say Starcraft 2 or if you want a RTS with a great campaign that is well written and  a blast to play, pick this up. Not perfect, but quite a good addition to the RTS genre, especially at a time when RTS games rarely come out and if they do they are usually multiplayer focused, nice to have one doing a good job with the campaign, story and atmosphere. Not as fast paced or twitchy as the popular starcraft2, but at the same time, the multiplayer in starcraft 2 has alot more options.

I will post more impressions and thoughts late on when I have more hours on the game. So far it is very good though! Very Immersive, audio rocks, it looks nice and it is fun to play, despiate the ai issues and lack of maps for multi on launch.

reviewText:
I love this game. It doesn't mean I would tell someone to buy it.
Just finished the game.  Classic Difficulty.  I had a blast playing it as an old homeworld fan. Won't lie was hoping for something that was more Homeworld: Cataclysm then the other two games.   It feels and plays like a Homeworld game. Each unit has a purpose and excells in that roll, but as far as the campaign is concenred there is a certain point in which anyhting smaller then a Cruiser becomes useless. This is very much Homeworld 2 over the previous games which might turn some off.
The hard part though.  Would I tell someone to spend 50$+ on this?  As the game is right now no.  Unless that person is a major homeworld and rts fan there is really no reason to buy this. Even then it is a hard sell.  The campaign is 13 missions long which is fine, but the skirmish and multiplayer as others have said before is where an RTS survives.  The fact the game shipped with 5 maps and a barebones AI which you will notice in the campaign really makes me worry about the longterm survival of this game. That and the lack of marketing on gearbox's front makes me worry that gearbox doesn't expect this to live long either.
Edit:
2/1/2016
There are now 6 multiplayer maps.  Multiplayer is reciving balance so meta is a bit better now. Ai is still braindead.

reviewText: This is a true spiritual successor to the Homeworld series.  Every little touch that made Homeworld so memorable is in this game.  Unfortunately, for a $55 dollar price tag this game is woefully lacking in content.  I completed the 13 mission campaign in under 10 hours of playtime.  Whats there to do after that? Not much.  Theres a skirmish mode against an absolutely horrid AI, even on the hardest difficulty.  There is also a multiplayer but the map pool is so tiny (5 maps total? only two of them are for the most played online mode 1v1)  Just bare bones content wise all around.  This is why i cant really recomment this game for this high of a price tag.  There is zero replayability in the campaign, its a once and done kind of thing and the multiplayer is just barren.  Get this if you absolutely need a homeworld fix, but personally id avoid this until it goes on sale for at least 50% off. Just nothing to do in this game.

reviewText:
The best RTS Ive played in a long time, hands down.

The campaign is an absolute masterpiece. Great atmosphere, immersion, visual style and music. SUPERB mission design. Every mission is very different without being gimmicky, and offers a wide variety of strategic play. The game favors strategy and tactical control over twitch micro, much like previous Homeworld games. 10/10

While somewhat slim on multiplayer features at release, DoK has already had 3 major patches, with a fourth coming this month. The developers continue to support this game with new maps, multiplayer features and balance changes, and DLC. The MP community is rather small, but very friendly and welcoming to new players.

If I had to find fault with the game, its the occasional bugs in the Public Lobby for custom games. Sometimes there are issues with p2p connectivity, but you can generally resolve them with a restart.

If you like RTS, Homeworld, or Sci-Fi, buy this game.

reviewText:
L I T E R A L L Y  H O M E W O R L D.

RTS vehicle physics look better than my life

Homeworld has always been a game that's very intense with the art direction, so the world looks absolutely flawless, though perhaps it might not be for some. All of the cutscenes thus far have been fantastic with their animated art concept. The actual gameplay is very similar to Homeworld, but now instead of a groundbreaking 3D space RTS... we're on a planet. Blackbird made sure to try new things here though, and they want to keep some aspects of the original game alive in that now the game feels quite authentic. The terrain isn't flat, you have topographical maps and need to pick and choose the best positions to place your forces if you want the advantage you desire. The storyline is top notch.

reviewText:
Hello everybody.About myself: RTS player, usually oriented on competetive multiplayer experience (CoH, SupCom, MoW:AS), have limited experience with Homeworld franchise overall but definitely a persone interested in lore.

In short: Game is great. It has some issues, but there is no core flaws which can make a game unplayable or effect its replayability. Game core mechanics are pretty deep, It has rich solo experience and well thought-out competetive oriented multiplayer. It is defenitely a Homeworld game from Homeworld developers. You can feel the soul of game universe while playing this game thats for sure. Amount of work those guys put in lore, game details and gameplay is huge and you can be sure that project not gonna be droped like some random moneygrab. Get this game and invest in quality game development.

Core mechanics
Game is defenitely self sufficient as Homeworld game and as real time strategy. There are multiple gameplay layers from terrain to unit active abilities and veterancy system. Solid groundbased strategy overall which can be compared to original Company of heroes.

Solo campaign
Story is rich, gameplay is really immersive. You have great wrighting, voice acting, awesome cutscenes\videos, unit persistance with veterancy system and pretty intence atmosphere overall. Expedition Guide adds alot for lore guys like me. All you need is a bit of imagination and good headset to dive into desert.

On the other side difficulty even on classic is not that hard, but game do not hold your hand all the time like TotalBiscuit tells you.

Multiplayer
Information about multiplayer was limited before release to say at least and this part of the game come out as a great surprise. You can clearly feel that original Shipbreackers project was oriented on multiplayer. You have 1v1, 2v2 3v3 ladder system with matchmaking and skill tiers. Artifact retreaval game mode in ranked saves this game from passive camping of original annihialtion gamemode of Homeworld multiplayer. Belance is pretty good for a fact that there were no closed\open beta for multyplayer. You can play 2 factions with really good diversity, dont listen to those who tells you that they are all the same. There is no identical units at all and there are huge core differencies in strategy\abilities\unit compositions etc. With great game core mechanics this game have a possibility to became a noticable RTS game like CoH or SupCom. There is no replay and observers system which are essential to form a competetive community around the game. And 5 maps are not enought thats for sure. Devs have a lot of work here if they want to bring this game to competetive standarts.

You can look at competetive part of the game here - First Ever Shoutcast! Pro 1v1" from well known Company of Heroes commentators https://youtu.be/XQcZM8-lMMA

That is all i think

If you like RTS and you've heard of homeworld, don't get this one. It's not finished. It feels like a demo. I completed it after a few days and thought was that it? I could have got more enjoyment out of £30 of booze.""

reviewText:
This will be my final write up on this review, as I have now completed the campaign and because of that alone my opinion is now a very, VERY cautious recommendation IF all you are after is the prequel story in a rushed format. If you're after replayability, hours of skirmishing etc, then go play Homeworld Remastered/Classics
I've played the Classics since I was a kid back on a 98 os system (all the way through xp and windows 7, I've probably put over a 1000 hours into each) and I've put well over a 100 hours into remastered just so you know that this is an opinion on the game from someone who has been tainted with the previous Homeworlds. A new fans opinion may obviously vary from mine.

I'll start off with the positive:
The art style of the cutscenes is fantastic, it's actually something I wish other media would uptake it's so pretty.
The music is classic Homeworld, desperate and dramatic tones of orchestra, it's great.
There's more dynamic battlechatter (for example when an enemy is detected but not seen units will report they have signals but no visual conformation) which is a very nice touch
Guard formations are back, (took us this long to get that back?)
Atmosphere and story is very homeworld, a desperate struggle against a formiddable enemy
Love the fact Rachel is a unit, any game which lets you some way have a badass chick is usually good in my books
Artifact recovery is a fun little thing to do, and it's a great asset, they offer great strengthening factors to your fleet
The prequel story is very compelling, not to spoil anything but after the end of this I immediately went and started playing Homeworld 1 again

Now the negative:
The game looks like ♥♥♥♥ when compared to remastered, even on ultra, ship textures are okay and the explosions are....okay, but the other FX look pretty poor and the sand textures look extremely lat and lifeless, to the point where I look at the screenshots above and scoff.
Combat has a serious lack of individual unit importance, the only way you can win is mostly by unit spam, you'll throw a lot of the starting units straight to the winds
There's no ballistics, at least from what I can tell, rail gun hits seem to be RNG and everything else is just falsely animated when compared to what's actually shooting and what's actually taking damage
No docking? No harvester drop off animations? What?
TERRIBLE unit clipping, like half the stuff on the surface doesn't actually exist, I've got scavengers just driving through the wreck of the Kalash like it's nobodies business
Very little unit variation both in each race and between the two races, one race hovers and the other doesn't but in terms of combat they are identical
Only 5 maps for Skirmish/Online
The controls are pretty butchered, unnecessary button changes to a system that was well understood and well loved, and you can't even get that system back because the controls are NOT-REBINDABLE
No ALT focusing, making trying to keep an eye on your units in combat even more difficult without them clipping through sand, mountains, bigger units and resources
Unit target priority is very odd, rail guns will try to shoot tiny fast LAV's while another railgun is killing them, it's like they just defend themselves from what they see first which will ALWAYS be the LAV's
I know this is precise but, the support carriers guns will all fire when in combat, even if not all of them are on target, so you get bullets just flying off the thing in random directions for no reason
Missiles and bombs have very random velocities, they'll launch/drop at reasonable speeds but as soon as they get close to a target they'll accelerate to ridiculous speeds and perform seriously unbelieveable changes in direction. I understand a bit of smudging to make stuff like that hit but, this is immersion breaking
I find very few of the scenarious in the campaign to be imaginative, you've got your standard first mission of testing resourcing, production and the like and from there's it's just been engage and destroy the enemy mostly (as well as the aforementioned artifacts to recover)
Skirmish AI is both useless and a dirty cheater at harvesting resources much faster than you ever could
Camera gets stuck at certain zooms sometimes
Sometimes turret animations will simply fail and rounds will come out the back of them instead of through the barrel

Of course some of this can be fixed in patches, we NEED Alt focusing again and we DEFINITELY need rebindable controls, as well as a fix for the buggy clipping, certain odd unit behaviour and some busted animations

My final word is that I really want to say I enjoyed this, hell I probably did, the campaign (as un-imaginative as it is) is enough to make you want to complete it, but that's pretty much all you're getting. If you're a die-hard Homeworld fan and you want to experience this epic journey of the great expedition then be prepared to experience the feeling of a very rushed game along with it. Buggy animations, unit clipping, fairly certain I've mentioned it all. And it will ruin the immersive moments, even the end of the game was almost ruined for me, as the final scene plays and the beautiful animation style shows us the sky of Kharak, Rachel was saying her piece and was interrupted twice by the blockhead Intel Officer saying Galsien fighters approaching" even after I'd killed every single last one of them.

I just chose to ignore him (the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)"

reviewText:
Unfortunately, I haven't ever played the original Homeworld, but I know what a gem it was.  I've been missing a good RTS ever since Westwood was gobbled up by EA and Command & Conquer started to decay.

Deserts of Kharak is a breath of fresh air and gives me the same joy that I missed from the good ol' days.  For those who don't have any context on the game, it feels like Battlestar Galactica mixed with Dune.  Its fun, it's demanding and I can't stop playing it!  I would write a longer review, but I need to get back to the campain story (which is amazing) to see what happens!

HIGHY recommended to any and all RTS fans!

AFTER HAVING COMPLETED THE CAMPAIGN:

Soooo, I think I got ahead of myself here.  I really loved the game, it was so much fun, but I don't think it has enough depth for me to keep coming back for skirmishes.

The campaign was a bit short in my opinion (about 8 hours on normal difficulty), but I really enjoyed it. I think I would buy an expansion for this game and I would recommend, but I think I would suggest waiting until it goes on sale in a few months.

reviewText:
As I eagerly launched this title. I had a nostalgia hit me from the series.It felt like a Homeworld game and sounded like one with the superb voice acting, Excellent music and accompanied by beautiful cutscenes. The only downside however was the uninteresting backstory lore of the game and lack of depth in strategy from the opponent. The game is fun and the multiplayer works however there is a shortage of good maps seen.
The game is as good as a Homeworld game can get as player control Rachel S'jett along with the coalition to battle the Galsien empire to reach the anomaly before they do on the dying world of Kharak
cont...

Video Review https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FlwQOwmKRTw

Pros + Great soundtrack as always from the Homeworld series along with top notch voice acting
+ Battlechatters between units and acknowledgments as the battle wages between two factions the Coalition and the Galsien on the dying planet of Kharak.
+ Graphics looks good and not too overly done, the game runs really well and feels optimized. Though the texture could use more work but overall the environment of the world of the dieing planet Kharak is full of sand, dunes, tornadoes, and sand storms adding the feeling of immersion.
+ Units animations such as leaving sand dust when they speed up or blowing up leaving debris and black sand is enjoyable to watch when zoomed in or when units jump over giant dunes.
+ Cutscenes are beautiful and top notch with cinematic watercoloring type of art along with in game cutscene that adds to the storytelling.
+ Easy to understand unit counters accompanied by a great tutorial that explains how to play the game and use the camera
+ Good ui and not overly cluttered along with easily understandable hotkeys.
+ Multiplayer matches are fun and easy to understand in two modes, carrier destruction or capture the artifact.

Cons  - Story was uninteresting and left new players left out on the lore without much proper explanation of the situation one has to be a fan to understand what exactly is going on.
- Ai in campaign does not respond to your units engagement types and literally cannot counter you, They are also set on predetermined pathing so if you die a mission, you can reload and test yourself and see that they will always go in the same directions or send the same units for situation even on the hardest difficulty. Not entirely dumb but needs rework.
- Hardest difficulty beaten in seven and a half hours. Without rushing and played by veterans.
- Cannot bind your keys though will not be a problem for those familiar with strategy games and can learn, the issue will be for left handers and others who cannot put up with the control ( THIS IS A SITUATION THAT CAN BE PATCHED!)
- No units formations like in the original Homeworld series. (ie no formations at all so your support units can end up in the front and or too far from range to heal your units which sucks. You'll have to manually set them up in position.
- Multiplayer is very lacking only 5 maps total to fight against your friends/enemy. Hopefully more will be added or a map editor of sort so that we'll have more maps.
- Lack of strategy depth for units

In conclusion for those of you who are Homeworld fans you'll like the game, it is good but its not great. I am awaiting a sequel and hopefully see more improvements to Homeworld itself. It is a fun casual game to play online as well as an enjoyable narrative game with a short campaign without overly complex units and strategies. At best it is up to the multiplayer if this game will continue on living but even then the lack of multiplayer modes and map is undesirable and only time will tell if the game will withstand the test of time. There aren't many strategy game these days but this definitely isn't the worst. Hopefully future patches will improve it. Wait for a price drop or get it if you are eager to just play something.

reviewText:
An (awesome) indie game with the price of an AAA game
First of all, I feel bad for not recommend this game, the game is great, RTS at its finest, complex, hard, offers variety of strategic... is the best RTS I've played since Supreme Commander. The campaign (isn’t mind-blowing anyway) has a great atmosphere, the feeling of being on an expedition in the middle of nowhere, with everything against you. That sense of rush while you're collecting resources for example, not knowing when an enemy patrol may appear through the dunes. Had a great narrative, a superb missions design, the video sequences have a magnificent design (like drawn with a brush, a speed painting between 2D and 3D), an incredible soundtrack... And an interesting plot.

So why i cannot recommend it? Like the title said, is an indie game (sometimes even one on early access) overpriced. There's a important lack of content for the price its cost. You can beat the awesome campaign in less than 8 hours... and there's no more to do. There's not many units (and not very different aesthetically), only one campaign, the scenarios are incredible (but are similar, ok, a vast desert, you know), the HUD is an schematic and insipid 2D (you don't need to see how the pilots move inside their vehicle like on Starcraft 2 of course, but it makes it quite clear what kind of game it is), the units doesn't speak too much sometimes... Of course you got the skirmish and multiplayer (in fact you just need to look the achievements of the game to see it is the main feature), but only two factions, well, to be fair they're the same with different skins... less than 9 maps and of course only 4 game modes (almost identical)... and by the way, the online mode is dead.
And well... now, they just released a DLC...6.99 to add 4 vehicles to the online mode... well 4 skins more or less. So... again a very overpriced stuff. This is not the correct way to make better the game, or even to bring back a game focused on the online mode. The game need new campaigns, offline campaign.

The game is great, if you like the original Homeworld you will love this (the game is a mix between Supreme Comander and Ground Control with the Homeworld greatness), if you are a fan of real RTS you will love it too, I do. But the game is not worth that price (25-30 is recommended price, IMO), if you only can buy a game... look for another or wait for a discount (a big one), if you don't care about overpriced games, go for it.

First and foremost i personally think this game is amazing! I am having a blast with the campaign and the story is actually really fun & exciting. Even the 'cutscenes' are great to watch.. it's like a mini movie getting you pumped before the mission, feeding you with emotions so that you try your best to save 'X' people and do 'X' mission.


I will not get to much into the graphics because im not fussy with them. - Graphically, the game is stunning..   i am playing  1920x1080 with all graphical settings set to Ultra, and i must say i am blown away with the amount of detail they have put into the maps, terrain, units and just everything! Even when you zoom down and you can see your units up close and personal, you notice the small details and just appreciate the work they have put into each and every object to make it look very realistic and sophisticated. Ahh.. The lighting and shadows are spot on! It gives you that extra 'real life' feeling to it, i can't explain it much more than that, but everythings looks great so far.

My PC specifications for those wondering:

Processor:-    Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-2600 CPU @ 3.40GHz
Video Card:-   NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 Ti
Memory:-       16 GB Ram
Resolution:-    1920 x 1080
Operating System:-   Microsoft Windows 10 (build 10240), 64-bit

Campaign/Story - The story so far is actually exciting, and for me that's hard to find in a game. Truth be told, i don't tend to finish many campaings on any game i play.. Usually i just jump straight into Multiplayer and later on try the campaing, don't like it and just go back to playing the Multiplayer section, but 'Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak' has already gotten me hooked.. I for the first time in a long time have just enjoyed playing the campaign and not even thinking of joining an online game. Why? the story line.. like i have said, it's amazing and really fun with some awesome mission, some are simple and some are hard. Also i do suggest giving the tutorial a go for new players, if no you'll have a hard time adjusting to the game when either playing the campaign or multiplayer.


Another thing for now that i shall mention, terrain. It's great to see an RTS game add realistic areas(I'm not saying other games have not done so in the past), for example.. If you are planning to attack a target, you can't just select your units and tell them to attack 'X' units.. Sometimes you have to put them on higher grounds because the terrain isn't always  flat.  Even the smallest hill will make your units just shoot into the sand and do nothing, thus why having to put them onto the perfect location so they can fire and hit their target and have an advantage, and at the same time getting a little cover. This really does give the maps/game the complexity that games like this need. Another thing i love, is with certain heavy tanks you can now 'smoke screen' an area to cut off long ranged attackers hitting your units, this means the enemy has to bring the heavy tanks closer and will make them vulnerable to attack, or make them wait out the smoke and that will mean they're useless for that short battle! Simple things like this make you think!  it's great.


Like i said, ill keep updating this review.. but for now this is all i have. Hope this does help for anyone thinking of buying the game - This is more so the positives of the game, because i have not encountered any big negatives thus far.. so i suggest reading other reviews if this has not satisfied you.

Some Gameplay of the first two missions, thought this would also help to choose if you like this sort of game style or not.

Multiplayer i will add here when i have played several hours of it.


Well, have a great day/night and see you on the battlefield!

reviewText: The story behind Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak’s development is a bit of a strange one. It started as a Homeworld-inspired project being developed by ex-devs of the original games, with the obvious difference of it being a ground-based RTS instead of a 4x space-strategy title. Yet events conspired to land the Homeworld license in Blackbird Interactive's hands, and instead of starting on a new project, they opted to retroactively fit their existing title into the universe as a prequel. What they have created feels surprisingly authentic, with gameplay mechanics and atmosphere that emulate the lonely, haunting, vaguely middle-eastern experience that characterizes the series.\n\nContinue Reading [www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
Homeworld is back!

Let's start with the good:

The Homeworld atmosphere is recaptured perfectly.
The music is as good as in the originals.
Surprisingly good story.
Awesome sound design. The audio chatter among the units is one of the best I've seen in an RTS.
Fine visuals.

Now the bad:

Lackluster AI. Finished the campaign in 12 hours (classic difficulty) and didn't break a sweat.
Perfomance issues. The game ranges from 100fps to a crawl, even without anything spectacular going on.
No key rebinds. Unnaceptable in this day and age.
No skippable cutscenes. Unnaceptable in this day and age.
Only five skirmish maps. Couple that with the crap AI and you only have the campaign going for it.

Do I recommend it? Yes. But only for fans of the originals. Others be warned and wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Great game, especially for fans of the original 3 games. I strongly recommend it if you like RTS campaigns or mature sci-fi stories.

+ Good story. Playing this after LotV reminded me that RTS campaigns don't actually have to have garbage plot and characters.
+ Excellent music and audio, especially the dynamic unit chatter. Why can't all sci-fi strategy games do this?
+ Excellent art design as one would expect from this series. Nice graphics overall, once I figured out I needed to manually tell NVIDIA to activate my video card (the game defaulted to integrated graphics)
+ Comes with HW and HW2 remastered for free!
+ Solid gameplay. Compared to HW2, elevation and line of sight partially make up for the loss of the z-axis. Heavy units aren't as overpowered as in HW2, while turrets and motherships are far more interesting.

- Poor long-term value. I would have liked a longer campaign with more factions and the skirmish mode is bare bones with few options or maps. Devs have promised more content for free, we shall see.
- No in-game pause, only pause to menu.
- No official modding support as of yet.

reviewText:
Firstly you will note that I've chosen not to recommend this game so I will briefly summarise why that is the case.

As a prequel for the Homeworld series this game does live up to its predecessor in relation to the campaign and overall presentation. The story flows well, the cut-scenes are well done, and the tasks in the missions offer some variety. The story itself, as you may no doubt have guessed, follows the progress of the 'Expedition' refrenced in the very first opening sequence of the original Homeworld game. This game wasn't developed by Relic but that certainly doesn't show, at least when it comes to the single player campaign polish.

Other than the single player campaign, the rest of the game leaves a hell of a lot to be desired. The fact that the campaign is only 13 missions long, the first practically being another training mission, in-and-of-itself, doesn't help. Regarding the multiplayer side there are only 6 maps at present to play skirmish games on. When it comes to skirmishes against the computer, the AI in this game is very underwealming and not challenging at all. As for playing against other human opponents there doesn't appear to have been much uptake of this game from other players from a multiplayer perspective as I have searched for nearly an hour trying to find a ranked game, and public lobby games are few and far between.

All in all, if you're a fan of the Homeworld series I wold recommend waiting until this game is on sale at at least half the price. As things stand its not worth the money for a single player campaign with barely any multiplayer support or community,

reviewText:
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak takes the classic space RTS gameplay of the original Homeworld games and brings it down to the ground. Namely, the endless desert of Kharak. The result is a refreshing take on the RTS formula with superb art direction.

I really love the way this game looks. The mix of the rugged industrial motifs of the ships traveling through the desert and the naval iconography of the aircraft carrier on wheels (which is an idea I just love!) works supremely well. I specifically really adore the fact that the UI is modeled to look exactly like what you would imagine the characters in the game would be looking at on their computer screens. Art and design on this game is top notch and make this game stand out from other RTSs, while still hearkening back to what made the art of the original Homeworld games special.

I also very much like the combat. The two factions in the game are similar enough that you can pick up the other pretty quickly if you've learned one, but also different in very cool ways. The Coalition is great at defending particular locations; they can build turrets and must build stationary logistics modules to increase their fleet. The Gaalsien, in contrast, are all about mobility and covering the map. They can produce units from multiple locations simultaneously and their units generally are quicker and more mobile. They also do not need static logistics beacons because they upgrade their fleet capacity as research on the carrier.

All of these factors and the Battlestar Galactica"-esque campaign make for a great complete package. I think this is going to be one of the strategy games we talk about for years.

See more about the game and my opinions in this pre-release video:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=604237964"

reviewText: Those that experienced the original Homeworld game back in 1999 were in for a real treat, with the epic story much like the modern Battlestar Galactica series. A slower paced RTS game with intriguing reverse difficulty and epic lengthy capital ship battles. Whatever you complete your mission with is what you start with in the next mission. And Homeworld was purely in space, and it had some control issues as it wasn't common to play an RTS game in pure 3D space.\n\nThis new Homeworld prequel is a fantastic experience, but plays just like the original -- except everything is on land, thus 2D and easier to control. I recommend playing on hard, for the full experience. I would have to frequently reload an old save if I made a major tactical. But as a fellow game developer with a lot of RTS experience, BBI have done a most impressive job using the Unity engine and putting together the complete package. It performed well with max settings at 2560x1600 resolution.

reviewText:
>this review may change in the future.
>1/25/16

This game is an absolute must for any RTS fans out there, especially ones that plays RTS for the single player.  The Gameplay is the typical homeworld style, only this time, its on the ground.  Unlike space where there is nothing to get in the way, the new enviroment this game is set on, offers a fun and great experience, especially since its homeworld.

The campaign may be short in RTS standard.  but its the missions offers something great.  Keeping the same units you built since the beginning was fun, it always ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off to see my high ranking units get destroyed (mostly because of poor decisions).  I reccomend playing it on classic mode (hardest difficulty) while the AI may not be great, the mission designs somehow finds a while to keep the challenge.  In short, the single player campaign is fun.

Now for skirmish.  like I said before, AI is not great and there are only five maps.  Hopefully BBI or Gearbox will release free DLC maps very soon and allow modding for this (lots of potential for great mods too.  Mad max Mod anyone?)  You may have heard this before in the discussions of this game.  Bad AI, five maps.  In an RTS game that is a big nono.

Multiplayer is, like usual, the best one.  Downside, region lock.  So far I have been only been able to find 1v1 matches 2v2 and 3v3 takes forever, that the only way to find larger matches is through the public server browser, but thanks to the region lock, you barely find anyone (usually juse one match/server is open)  I hope they fix this.

The game has some weird optimizations, if you have a good computer, a great PC? You will get stuttering, no matter what option you set in the game.  hopefully in a patch they fix this.  Not really surprised that the game will have optimization problems, people did say, Unity Engine (which is what this game is using) has problems running smoothly.

Would I recommend this game?  yes BUT, with the very few features it has (like usual, bad AI, short campaign, five maps) the price it has right now, is not worth it.

IF YOU REALLY WANNA BUY THIS GAME.  you're better off waiting for a sale or looking to other retailers/sites that offers a lower price, like ♥♥♥ or something similar

If they fix all these issues, mainly the multiplayer region locking, AI, and the fact it has only five maps.  It would be great.


+Great campaign
+beautiful artstyle
+Good gameplay
+Good Story
+Use of terrain/utilizes full 3d enviroments
+Challenging single player (on classic)

-Short campaign
-poor optimization
-five maps on release
-bad AI
-region locked multiplayer
-Price of the game despite how very little features it has

reviewText:
Homoworld: DoK is one of the best RTS' to come out in recent memory. It's incredibly atmospheric and has arguably the strongest sound design and art direction in the past 10 years.

The campaign - while not as challenging as previous iterations of Homoworld - captures the feeling of the franchise and looks amazing.

Multiplayer is a hoot & a half, with Paper-Scissor-Rock RTS gameplay mixed with the tactical maneuvering that comes with fleet combat. The MP player-base is small, but everyone is really friendly in providing tips and helping new players learn then came so they can hold their own in MP matches.

If you're a fan of RTS games, like getting stuck in with an atmospheric game, or looking to try something different from your usual gamer tastes, Homoworld: Deserts of Kharak has what you're looking for. Add your boy Causal Male, Extra Large on steam and let's play some Multplayer friend!

reviewText:
Well I played the original Homeworld back in 199something! I haven't played any others since, though I was most pleased that I decided to pre-order at the last minute before launch to pick up the Homeworld Remastered (plus originals). Kudos to
Blackbird Interactive for following their hearts and kudos to Gearbox for picking up the whole franchise in the first place (I'm glad someone there saw the potential).

I'll keep this review short and sweet. I'm not a huge RTS player, though I used to enjoy the C&C series (last one being C&C generals). This is Homeworld, without a doubt, The story is great, the camapign is well designed, the art style is spot on, the sound sfx and voice acting are solid. The music perfectly retains the music of Homeworld while placing you neatly into location - The Deserts of Kharak. Pro tip for campaign; play on classic and keep your fleet persistance!

The Good:
Campaign, story, cutscenes, everything about it screams Homeworld, I loved every minute of it!
Art
Sound
Music
Gameplay
Lore
Multiplayer: Artifact mode is a nice twist, plenty of maps (11 so far), good skirmish options such as 1 vs 3 AI etc, Co-op vs AI.
Subfaction DLC's are amazing worth buying.
Game replays.
Great development team behind the title very responsive to feedback!
The bad:
No mod tools or Steam Workshop as of yet (still early days)
If you're a fan of the franchise and/or RTS genre in general, I don't think you'll be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Take Homeworld's fleet management, combine it with Ground Control's tactical use of terrain and unit abilities, and you've got Deserts of Kharak. Set in the period of time leading up to the rediscovery of the Hyperspace Core, it acts as a prequel to the original Homeworld, and has all the atmosphere you'd expect from a Homeworld title.

While the campaign is short (I finished in approximately 14 hours, in no particular hurry), the plot is enjoyable and did manage to spring a surprise on me, and the missions throw you the occasional curveball, such as commanding a team operating independently of the main body, with no production facilities. Overall the gameplay is fun and engaging, although I cannot comment on multiplayer as I'm terrible at RTS and just stomp computers while watching pretty explosions.

Unit designs and animations are generally quite good: enemy units explode most satisfyingly, Light Attack Vehicles catch air off the tops of dunes when using speed boost, Baserunners open hatches to drop turrets and sensors, and the carrier launch and recovery sequences have an intricate detail that I just can't help but zoom in to watch. This does make the lack of resource harvesting animations a bit disappointing, however.
Sound design is superb, especially the chatter. During a slow period in an early mission I heard the engineering crew of one vehicle have a friendly argument with their commander.

My only real complaint is that the main camera doesn't let me zoom out as far as I'd like, so I spent much of the game in sensor view rather than enjoying the desert landscapes, but the developers appear to be taking an active interest in feedback and player suggestions, so there's a good chance this may be fixed.

If you liked Homeworld and/or Ground Control, you should buy this game.

reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak is probably one of the best RTS games I've ever played. You woudn't think the Homeworld formula would survive the transition from space to land, but somehow BBI pulled it off. What's left is an ingenious mix of Homewords 1 and 2, Ground Control, and some SupCom. This is defintely a great Multiplayer RTS.

Combat has some rock paper scisors elements, but empthasises micro. Almost every unit has a special ability, which if used correctly can greatly augment its ability to do damage, take it, or support other units. Managing your fleet over the course of an engagement is a rapid fire exercise in getting your positioning right to ensure your damage potential is maxed, managing said abilities, deciding which tech to pursue, and reacting to the enemy. Central to all this is your Carrier. IMHO the DOK Carriers are the best 'player' unit I've ever seen in a game. Not only do they manage research and production like the HW Mothership, they're also an extremely viable combat unit if upgraded throughout a match and paired with a good support fleet. They also act as a resource dropoff and the hangar for your air force, so positioning them is critical as well, in fact you'll probably roam your carrier quite a bit. It's always a sign of a fun and even DOK match when you can end with a carrier showdown. Or with careful placement of artillery and railguns you can snipe them from range, but this requires time and resources.

Singleplayer is good. The story is well told and the cutscene art is beautiful, but it's short. If you're familiar with HW lore or at least the first game, you'll enjoy it. If not, then some of the impact of events can be confusing. The Expedition guide (sold as DLC) can expand on the lore greatly, but I'd only reccomend that for diehard fans who love the fluff. Other than that, there's skirmish with the AI. AI got patched recently so that it's not just a poor cheating system, so that can be a good introduction to gameplay. Skirmishing has questionable longevity though.

Let's talk other content: The number of maps has gone up since launch, but there is still only 1 3v3 map. If you're playing MP, most of your matches will be on it. BBI is working on new maps and other content, but until that changes don't buy if you like map variety. I can live with it because I love the gameplay, but YMMV. There are 2 factions: Coalition and Gaalsien. Coalition are hard hitting, Gaalsien are fast and can build units quicker since they use crusiers for production. Both are fun to play, but most people play Coalition. Both have different versions of similar units, all with different abilities. There's also the Soban fleet pack now, which is based on the Coalition, and a potential future pack which could be  Gaalsien based. Finally, you can't rebind keys, which may be a deal breaker for some (theres talk about fixing that, however).

Overall, I'd reccomend DOK to anyone looking for an RTS that differs from the usual formula. If you like Homeworld, you've probably already bought DOK. The community isn't large, but there are more than enough people who play regularly to get a full match going. I've had immense amounts of fun with the game as it is, more than enough to justify the purchase, and future patches and expansions will only make the game better! But if you're still worried about the amount of maps or any missing features (Spectating, Keybinding, Etc.), I'd reccomend keeping an eye on the game and holding off for a future sale.

If you love RTS, you owe it to yourself to go carrier hunting sometime in your life!

reviewText: Deserts of Kharak is not as gorgeous and rich as Company of Heroes or even Starcraft, but still it's a charmingly looking one. Being a prequel to original Homeworld, the game tells a story of battle between two clans (Coalition and Gaalsien) that hunt some very old and powerful knowledge, hidden in a deadly desert. Not only a story connects these Homeworlds, Deserts of Kharak also descends a wonderful tribal music and stylish movies from origins. But as a game, the new Homeworld part is not about big skirmishes - it’s tidily made RTS that carefully combines different approaches and features from well-known strategy games of past. Imagine if you would play Ground Control 1 in a very lovely Dune-like desert, where Commander APC does unit production/research work and harvesters collect minerals. It's a tactical RTS with some unit heritage from original Homeworlds, where gameplay is about small armies and squads - and this will be a full description of DoK.\n\nP.S. Another Ground Control feature - Coalition looks like Crayven Corporation and uses wheel and crawler terradins, on the contrary while vicious red hoverdines of Gaalsien came directly from Order of the New Dawn.

reviewText:
I think it's the best RTS of 2016. I played Ashes of the Singularity and this seriously trumps it. There are almost no downsides to this game, or rather there are almost no things that will hinder this game once everything is added. A DLC has been announced recently that will add 1 more playable race, allot more features and a wide barrage of new multiplayer maps. With that in mind, and possible future DLC’s the game will take allot more body and shape.

Graphics wise it's absolutely stunning, the maps look immersive and the units feel real and well developed. Gameplay wise I missed the formations of Homeworld 1 and 2, I also miss the maps, multiplayer is urgently lacking maps. The AI could also use with different stances, like aggressive, passive or balanced, and I can’t help but feel like a third race (maybe in an expansion) would benefit this title allot.

As it stands I personally like the game, it shows amazing potential.

reviewText:
I've played alot of RTS games and this brings back good Homeworld meories. Is this as fast paced as Starcraft? No, but that is okay. I like the overall slower pace.

As for the maps and AI concerns. Devs are already on it and coming out with a patch soon. The community is active in finding and squashing any bugs that slipped through. The Devs are VERY active and open on the discord channel which a link can be found on the homeworld reddit.

Devs are involved and they want the game to go far.

The single player is awesome. Vs AI is lacking but that will get patched. Multiplayer is new and exciting. Don't get frustrated if/when you lose. Learn and move on. Just like in any other RTS. You won't be a GOD at the game until you learn game by game how to be a proper Commander.

Although this game falls short when it comes to multiplayer because of the lack of maps and factions to play, it still holds up against other RTS games. The storyline is great and the multiplayer can get pretty intense and is just as fun as Homeworld: Remastered. The battles can last a decent amount of time and the AI loves to keep rushing you with small attack groups.

You have to pick this up if you're an RTS fan and also Homeworld: Remastered if you don't have it already.

It started with two playable factions and they have just added another with a very affordable DLC. I would expect more to come really soon.

reviewText:
A beautiful looker for an RTS with solid mechanics and balanced Rock-Paper-Scissor-mechanics. Some flaws remain though , which are a matter of personal preferences and taste.

On the good side:
Balanced factions, meaningful units, beautiful terrain (even though its mainly dessert), great explosions. Good for beginners and intermediates alike.

On the bad side:
Lackluster amount of maps, too much handholding in the campaign, minor bugs and unpleasentries.

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is actually a good game. However, it seems to lack in content where it really matters: The campaign and the multiplayer maps. There are only FIVE maps, which is unacceptable for any multiplayer focused game. The campaign can be busted through rather easily, at least on normal. Not very punishing, little room to tackle problems your way and, truth be told, missions are not long enough to do experimenting or exploration. Hard to get your moneys worth on singleplayer alone, at least in this state.

reviewText:
Although I have to agree with some negative comments I've read in the reviews, I still have to give this game a huge thumbs up as the best RTS I've played in many, many years. Maybe it's because I grew up on StarCraft and developed an obsession for sci-fi RTS games, maybe it's because I was always curious about the backstory to Homeworld 1 and 2, but despite its flaws, this game was tons of fun. The only thing I'd say is wait until it's on sale, because if you're like me and really keen on the campaign, you may feel ripped off by the end of it.

PROS:
Great story, graphics, audio, UI, smooth and fun gameplay. Tons of fun!

CONS:
Normal difficulty is a cakewalk, campaign took me just under 9 hours, leaves you feeling like there should be more at the end.

9/10 will play again
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Totally brilliant, not perfect by any means, but very enjoyable. A good old fashioned homeworld story, great visuals and audio and a compelling narrative make it a lovely way to spend a day or two.

If I was going to criticise I would say it's nuts and bolts are somewhat lacking, I wouldn't have complained if this was a couple of years after homeworld 2 came out, but it's not and all the bugs and not quite there yet features just aren't as acceptable. One notably annoying missing feature is the lack of formations and positioning that was in homeworld and would have made a big difference in a land based strategy game. And the UI while joyfully reminiscent of the original could have done with a bit more updating and making it really pop and could do with better group management tools to let palyers access abilities easier, that being said it doesn't really get in the way too much so that is a plus.

The balance is ok, very homeworld 2 rather than 1, it would have been nicer to have a bit more nuance rather than the simplistic rock paper scissors that leave you mashing cruisers at the end. The best of the old homeworld mods that kept the game alive all added depth and complexity making even smaller units useful all the way through the game. It would have been nice for the devs to take some of that onboard with the new game.

Overall its well worth a buy on it's own merit, better than any of the RTS games last year other than the homeworld remasters. I'm pretty happy with it as I would have bought it anyway just to increase the chances we get a third homeworld game, that it's actualy fun is a real plus.

reviewText:
If you are going to buy this game already knowing you will not play MP, expect to be dissapointed, because even though overall story is great, gameplay itself is, as in almost any strategy, quite boring, and instead go play some other AAA sci-fi tactical strategy game... oh wait, there is none (excluding Star Craft, but there is a good chance you already played and finished this game).
If you are going to buy this game and play it in MP, it will knock your socks off. You can also ignore about 90 percent of negative reviews, most of them criticize SP.
It is on opposite end from most of current strategy games, and requires very little micro and feels overally epic, which is great change.
I think there are quite a few things that needs fixing, for instance bombers not dropping their payload, sometimes units refuse firing (mostly when dealing with artillery, so it might be minimum range, in that case, please indicate), but all theese things can (and i hope will) be fixed, so in a few month this will not be viable complaint.

reviewText:
I do not recommend this at all for the price of the game there is NO WHERE NEAR ENOUGH content for the price. Cities skylines was like $30 and had $60 worth of content for this i would pay $30 no more. Now to give out the pros and the cons.

Pros:
1. They kept to the old ways of Homeworld story telling if not better in the animated art so kudos to that
2. I like the concept of ground RTS different for homeworld Space 3d play
3. Graphics about the same if not better than homeworld 2 remastered
4. Great sound quality and music score for the desert enviroment not to mention a lot of voice chatter which makes it more lively.

Cons:
1. Styory is nice and all but still feels as though they are lacking depth to it even though if you have played the past homeworld you know the future outcome but there is not much telling of the history or about what goes on much.
2. Content Biggest peice right here. Lack of unit types and use of said units. The coalition seems to have fewer units than the oposition and lack futher potential of other units. You notice if you get this the main units you will mainly use are armored assault units and rails mainly combined with air units and thats it. Railguns are really the most affective against everything except lack armor and affectivness against light combat units
3. Campaign is short if played correctly seen people beat it less than the time it took me which was roughly 8 hrs. Won't spoil what happens but mainly just grinding through enemy forces.
4. Higher ground includes Defense bonus too? higher ground grants damage bonus but should not in any way grant a armor bonus if anything should be less since you are a bigger target.
5. Lack of multiplayer maps to 5? Really you launch the game that is a RTS with only 5 maps?
6. Hud interface of Old homeworld to ground RTS bad match up why? the game controls and hud set-up is great for the space one and using arrows is good for that but would recommend WASD for scrolling on a ground rts. This makes the game a bit more difficult to play with this kind of interface for a ground rts not to mention having the right mouse button to pan the camera everywhere can get annoying when sometimes it gets stuck.
7. Cannot skip a cutscene in game at all everytime i am in the mist of doing something cutscene happens and i lose units or have no control which is very frustrating in a campaign mission.
8. Controling air-units is abysmal. Why? because you cannot have them all fly to one location to select them all because once they get there and there is no target they auto-return to land then you have to wait until they land and re-launch. This makes them rather difficult to control and grabing them while on the move can be hard sometimes exspecially if you don't want to grab other units while your at it.
9. Gaalsien have a better tactical and more diverse units than the coalition hands down campaign and multiplayer which makes it unbalanced.

Now don't get me wrong but the Concept of it is great and all but how this was excuteted is abysmal Wish i could get my refund but steams policy says over 2hrs play and no refund but if it was gamestop they would let you beat the game and bring it back and get full refund so thats a shock right there.

I have played the past 3 homeworld games and yes there is 3 and this by far is the worst of them. If you really want this game i would suggest waiting until they drop the price because it is not worth $50.

reviewText:
Hello.

After playing the game for a good bit I have come to the point where I have to admit that the game does not live up to to the huge expectations most people have from a homeworld game.

It is a good game. A well made game.
It has a very nice homeworld feeling, the devs really made an effort here.

Why now a thumbs down?
Like many people I find myself wishing for a neutral button right now but in the absence of one I have to choose thumbs down.

The lack of real unit varity and the rather shallow tactics are my major negative points.
The missing pause function is ( if you ask me) a really stupid design decision.

The main problem is that the pure awesome feeling of drifting spcae hulks and massive explosions, flickering laser light and the depressing emptiness of space is missing.

It is a nice rts, it makes many things right. But it misses epic by a good mile.

reviewText:
Fills every expectation of a homeworld game. Great story, surprisingly pretty legos, and the best sound engineering available. Deserts of Kharak has the best audio by far, and the previous games were magnificent. A few hitches here and there (brand new title just needs optimizations) but no crashes, no problems, and runs great on my barely middle of the road PC specs.

BBI hit a home run as far as I'm concerned and I'm already waiting for a sequel. And a space one. and a space sequel.

Basically steam needs more homeworld.

Make it happen gentlemen.

reviewText:
My opinion of Deserts of Kharak as of 3/14/16 (subject to change).

Pros:

Engrossing story (particularly when placed into the context of the Homeworld mythos).
Straight-forward 'rock-paper-scissors' gameplay with options for more advanced combined arms tactics.

Cons:

Price ($50 was a bit much for this title, might have given it a pass if I had acted early on and gotten it for the Homeworld: Remastered purchasers price).
Length of the single-player campaign felt very short, hopefully multiplayer will make up for it.

Addendum:  A solid addition to the Homeworld series and hopefully a sign of more to follow.

reviewText:
Surprisingly good.

Didn't expect much after the last couple games published by gearbox, but I'm too much of a consumer ♥♥♥♥♥ to not buy something with the homeworld brand and art style. I didn't think the story would work well, given what we knew from the homeworld 1 manual, etc, and the plot retcons between 1 and 2, but they definately pulled it off.

Gameplay-wise, it's a nice translation of the mechanics of the older homeworld games to a 2d plane. outside of some little turrets and sensor posts, there are no structures, everything is built, upgraded, lauched, etc. from a vehicle. Units now have toggleable abilities, which I'm not actively opposed to. It's more micromanagement, but clever use of them can  make a huge difference I'm sure.

The art direction is rock solid. The Galsians, especially, look fantastic. The environments are as grand as you'd expect from a homeworld game, even if they're on the ground. The sound and music fit well too.

It's kind of weird that they have cool mythical sounding place names for every dang mountain and valley and sand dune when they've never been there and probably only have known about them since they launched a satellite to map the planet.

Anyway, it's bretty good, would buy again.

reviewText:
Nothing like the feel of sand between your toes!
If you loved 'Ground Control' and 'World in Conflict' and enjoy sci-fi units as featured in Planetary Anniliation this is a must have!
So, the zoom out could be a bit less restrictive, the large map overview could use a splash of color, and the single player campaign leave a lot more of your enemy to ponder but.... I LOVE IT! The story is a prequel to Homeworld and reveals a heap of history from the universe and this game is based all about massive spaceship discovery operations. The Campaign covers all aspects of multiplayer and is great for introducing new players to the franchise.

Pros
-Cool and unique cutscenes and in-game cutscenes (awesome artstyle)
-Constant radio chatter and perfect voice acting
-Simplistic and streamlined unit control
-13 Single Player Missions that do not get boring or drawn out
-Steam Achievements & Steam Cloud accessable
-Easily learned gameplay & hot keys
-AMAZING explosion sounds and fitting music
-Multiple game modes (Classic RTS modes)

Cons
-AI has a bit of learning to do to put up a more balanced fight
-Large Radar Menu could use some color and zoom out could be less restrictive
-No Minimap (Just takes some getting used to)

CAMPAIGN & FEATURES:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LqDTSgRYQa4


TOTAL RATING: 9 out of 10

Recommended for anyone! If you like RTS games or are interested in giving them a try this would be a great start for you and a fresh game for lovers of the franchise. A well made game that gives you a fair game at a fair price and leaves you wanting more!

reviewText:
A solid game!

I was a pretty good high-master league starcraft player.

What i like about the game so far?

1. It punishes hard macro early in the game, you can straight up lose if your opponent does a push
2. Knowing the army composition of your opponent is vital, just massing low tier units will get absolutly rekted against a few armored vehicles. This adds a great dynamic.
3. The multiplayer is brutal and unforgiving, if you ♥♥♥♥ up, you lose.

Its just really solid, i don't care if its not innovative, its a great competitive game with alot of depth. Artifact retrieval, which to me just sounded annoying at first is actually a great deal of fun. The game encourages players to be active all the time, just turtling to the lategame is not an option!

I've seen some reviewers note that the game is not worth the money because of its lack of innovation, hell, i don't need flashy new weird gameplay mechanics, i just want a solid competitive game that is brutal and punishes mistakes, this one does it, i hope the competitive scene will keep expanding in the coming months.

The only major negative point is, if one player has a bad connection, it will pause the game every few seconds without dropping him from the game. I really hope they solve this, some matches are unplayable because of it.

reviewText:
First of all I will preface this by saying I love all the Homeworld games and bought/played them when they first released all those many years ago.  I also own the remastered editions and enjoy those as well.  I also wish this review system allowed more than just a Up or Down ... but since it does I have to give it a Down because I WOULDN'T recommend this game for its full price.

So let's start off with the good.  The graphics are great.  They aren't taxing or mind-blowingly realistic, but for Homeworld they really fit.  The cinematics in the game fit well, and are a step up from the previous games.  They feature actual animation and fit in very well to the atmosphere of the game and the setting.  The music is very solid and has the normal Homeworld vibe to it.  The Rock/Paper/Scissor system used for the units is a bit standard but at the same time the units offer some more advanced options for abilities that allows greater strategic uses of unit.  Nothing crazy in-depth or complicated, but enough that you can do things like hit and run with some units.  The amount of units comes off as a bit limited at first but eventually you unlock a few more through gameplay, very similar to the other Homeworld games.  The carriers themselves are great additions to the game.  They're more than just your base of operations, they are slowly moving super units in and of themselves.  There's a system for changing up what you want your carrier to do by diverting limited power to weapons or repair systems, ect.  Still, it's a nice change from Homeworld where the mothership was little more than an anchor around your fleet's legs.

So why the No" recommendation?  Sadly it comes down to the amount of playability I got out of it.  For $50 I kind of expected more than a 9 hour campaign.  Now I know you can play multiplayer but that's not really my thing.  I bought this game today and finished it by tonight.  I didn't rush through anything
date: either.  I'm fairly meticulous when it comes to the Homeworld games
recommended: to the point that I NEED to get every resource before I leave to the next level.  So my 9 hours could quite easily be closer to 7 for the non-OCD types.\n\nThe game was great except for that.  I enjoyed the story
hoursPlayed: although I already knew the end (duh) and it was a bit predictable.  There just wasn't enough meat in this sandwich to garner the $50 tag.\n\nTL;DR:  I recommend putting this on your wishlist for a sale.  I'd say a $25 to $30 price point is fair for this game.  I'll amend my review if it comes out with more content
voteText: but I really doubt that's going to happen."

reviewText: It was always going to be a tough act to follow the massively successful Homeworld franchise yet Deserts of Kharak copes admirably. Set on Kharak - the HW series planet of origin, the latest installment is an excellent prequel to the events of the homeworld series. Set on the harsh desert world of Kharak, the sands of said planet are in a very odd and unexpected way interchangable with the cold vacum of space from the original games; both are hostile environments inhospitable to man. This is why Deserts works so well, it retains the feel and massive scale of the homeworld universe, the art style, the lore and backstory but fleshes it out for ground combat. Would recommend for anyone who enjoyed the original HW games or to anyone who enjoyed Dune in its many multmedia guises, similarily if anyone was thinking about buying HW remastered start instead with Deserts of Kharak, then migrate into space - the RTS equivelant of doing ME 1, ME 2 and then ME 3 and keeping the same character throughout!

etc...) can be vital during a battle

Cons:

- Global chat seems to fail to update sometimes and your left with what was typed 30 minutes ago
- Multiplayer synchronisation errors (happens often)
- No display of player's ping (so people know who is causing the connection issue if it's not the actual game that is the problem)
- Unknown errors (e.g. During a match one team randomly gets a message that they won the match and can only leave the game while the other team is still able to play)
- Skirmish synchronisation errors (only happened twice)
- Poorly optimised matchmaking
- Hosting a match can sometimes be impossible because for some reason the start button is locked (happens a lot)
- Skirmish AI doens't provide enough challenge with the exception of the highest difficulty where its feels like slightly borderline cheating (campaign AI is a bit more competent but best played on highest difficulty)
- Lacks unit formations like previous Homeworld games
-Multiplayer and Skirmish are limited to 5 maps

Neutral:
= Short Campaign
= Only 2 Factions available
= Low unit capacity which can limit micromanagement (although it makes unit choices a bit more important)
= No refresh button on public game lobby (its more of a personal con since to me its a stress button)
= Ground units sometimes fall from the sky (e.g. first campaign mission and my carrier drops from the sky into the docks)

Just as i said above i recommend this game for those interested in a compelling yet slightly short story but at the moment i can not and will not recommend this game for those looking for a good multiplayer RTS experience.

Deserts of Kharak tries to bring forth some life into a barren planet but the question is how long will that life last in such arid conditions and will it be able to adapt or evolve or will it end up being forsaken just like many others."

reviewText:
As a Homeworld fan I can tell you that this game is in line with the lore and gamplay it is a wonderfull adaptation from 3d of the space strategy to 2d.

The storyline is something that a lot of RTS games would be jealous of with intrigue, deception and all out rivalry.

For RTS fans this should a must have as the strategy in this game can go very far.

There are some controle issue, as example your weaker units tend to go up front which means they get damaged very quick. This needs some micromanagment. As a folowup of that your support/repair vessel is all the way in the back so you have to command them closer.

The origenal homeworld games had the possibility to assign groups of ships a certain setup ( Cap ships in front, Fighter screen, frigate line or cruiser line ) which can help a lot in soaking damage, next to that the setups would imrpove effeciency of the selected ship setup.

This comes back to the controle issues as it would help a lot!

Everything accounted for, I would still 100% recomend this as a buy, especially for an RTS fan.

reviewText:
Definitely a fun game and worth the price of admission, manages to bring a remarkable amount of Homeworldlyness to a land-based game which is definitely nice although it does seem a bit forced at times.

Gameplay is solid, though a touch shallow in terms of depth, the tendency towards the 'big ships steamroller' is still present and could stand to be toned down a bit in terms of the ease of aquisition. Given the 'all deserts all the time' asthetic I would have liked to see some more environmental hazards, sand storms that take big chunks of the map and reduce visibility and do some damage, steeper dunes actually having a chance of collapsing on units, wind managing to shift dunes around a bit.

Graphics and sound are both excellent, they did a good job of making the desert seem visually distinct. The sound design was a lovely return to form.

The campain was fun, not so short that I have any complaints and I'm certainly left wanting more time in the deserts after that.

reviewText:
If you played and liked homeworld you will love this.
If you Have not played homeworld this is the place to start.

Most negative reviews seem to center around the price.
Everyone has a different value for money so its hard to speak for everyone.
Personally i think the game is well worth it. The production value of the campaign and the game as a whole is better then most AAA titles. IF they can charge 30 pounds for the remastered edition then surely 30 pound for a new game made from scratch is not too much to ask.
The music, the speech, the graphics, and general theme of the game is outstanding.

I really appreciate a game that is well polished and this is it, the little touches are what made me love homeworld and the same effort has been put into this.

Just for an example the unit speech when you issue commands. Sounds like a small thing but when you are selecting and moving units constantly an annoying sounding unit can become grading. With homeworld: Deserts of Kharak you never get tired of hearing the units give out scan readings and comfirmations. Even while idle the units talk to each other, one will talk of a local reading and ask another to confirm it which they do. You will be told when enemy units are spotted when a unit dies, everything, but it doesnt feel like too much. It feels like a real warzone with alot of information being relayed.

Things like that remind of command and conquer, dawn of war and some of the other best strategy games ive played.

I was never one for multiplayer strategy games so i cannot speak for that. I prefer campaigns and this one is great. The cutscenes are not quite starcraft 2 but have their own charm. They create a sense of atmosphere that i have only encountered in homeworld itself. The idea of scale, discovering a large thing out in the desert and seeing one of your tiny light attack vehicle next to it.

As for the actual gameplay, its smart. Homeworld had a unique style to it and this follows that path and i love it. You dont control a base as such, you dont build buildings. Instead you have a convoy. One main cruiser which produces your troops and handles research. Then other support vehicles can be built. All of your resources collected, units built, research carries over to the next mission. So you get this feeling that you are literally a convoy moving towards the main objective of the campaign, getting bigger along the way. The missions are fun, each one has a twist, starcraft 2 had a similar method which made me enjoy it so much. The mission is never just kill the enemy. You have to scan things, protect things and such. They add things like tornadoes to the mix to keep you on your toes.

If you want multiplayer this might not be for you, ive heard theres not much going on with it. If you like campaigns then i would highly recommend. Its worth a try you will learn quickly if you like the style of gameplay. PLus if you enjoy it you have homeworld 1 and 2 to play.

reviewText: One of the biggest surprises of the new year is Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, a prequel to the original Homeworld that has long remained an icon of PC-based strategy warfare titles.  DOK abandons the vast emptiness of outer space for the sand-choked deserts of the ill-fated planet Kharak, and tells the story of how the people came to locate the ancient anomaly that would give rise to their exodus towards their titular homeworld.  The switch to ground-based strategy gameplay is a definite change from the 3-dimensional tactics one could employ in space, but it's not without merit.  Here, Gearbox selects elements from Homeworld's pedigree and marries them to elevation tactics from other notable strategy games.  Thus, elevation becomes a driving force behind victory over enemy units.  It's a fanciful, albeit simplistic way of approaching combat, but it does come at a cost.  DOK's stripped down for everyone" approach means that some important elements such as battle formations have been jettisoned
date: reducing the level of depth that Homeworld veterans may be accustomed too.  It's a bit jarring
recommended: and makes DOK feel more like a mini-episode in a much larger storyline.\n\nThe game focuses heavily on short and long-ranged units almost specifically
hoursPlayed: forcing players to mix up units in order to guard and attack.  Naturally
voteText: enemies can attack from all directions
helpfulPercent: and the relative shortage of resources (or should I say
votesHelpful: compartmentalized resources) means that there isn't a lot of elbow room to establish bank-breaking fleets as seen in the original Homeworld games.  Researching new technologies is on a need-to-do basis
votesTotal: and therefore feels a tad linear.  The speed of the game has also changed as well.  Units build much faster
votesFunny: research takes far less than it used to
commentsCount: and enemies race in out of nowhere.  Is this an attempt to court players with less-than-stellar attention spans?  Perhaps!\n\nIronically
column16: it's a magnificent game despite the narrowed and more centralized gameplay mechanics.  I'm hoping that future chapters in the Homeworld saga won't go this route
column17: but for a game set on the surface of a planet
column18: instead of outer space
column19: it's an admirable and enjoyable entry in the franchise.  Let's face it.  There's a criminal lack of Homeworld games for us to play
column20: and this is the first true sequel in over a decade.  Who are we to complain?  DOK retains the signature Homeworld atmosphere
column21: music and visual styles of previous games
column22: and it's nice to see unit designs giving nods to what will eventually become spacefaring Kushan fighters
column23: capital ships and destroyers.  It's like going back to the beginning to a world where little is left.  The dry sands of Kharak are a perfect backdrop for a pretty good (but not stellar) story
column24: and a nice little glimpse into the richness of Homeworld's still mysterious storyline.\n\nRECOMMENDED!"
