reviewText:
To make it short and simple.

Either you will love this game and join its fanbase or you are gonna hate it because it goes against the current standards of RTS.

It's a mix of the old homeworld and COH and Ground Control. IT IS NOT A SUPCOM COPY.

The Pros:
- The Single Player is breathtaking. The perfect prequel to Homeworld & Homeworld 2
- The Units while not numerous are well done and play well in the rock-paper-scissor scheme of any RTS.
- The theme and structure is awesome. Let me repeat... is awesome. Rarely will a game suck you in and especially an RTS game.
- You feel that you are a commander in the field. Not like a base builder and then send your units and thats that. Resources are scarce and tactical descions are paramount to be succesful.
- My experiance is mostly on the single player with a few multiplayer games thrown in against a couple of friends and I feel the multiplayer needs a couple of mods and/or ways to play.

The Cons
- The keybinding issue (You can't change them) and according to the Devs they are working on it.
- Unit formations needs to be looked at.
- Multi has only 5 maps which is sufficient to get through the time being while more are being worked on.
- Needs a couple of multi player modes... Capture the hill and tower like defence against AI?


Overall: 9/10

P.S. For the new comers to Homeworld... The story continues on Homeworld and Homeworld 2 which are pretty darn good in their own way. DON'T MISS THEM.

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a true continuation of Homeworld gameplay, even if the story takes place far before the events of Homeworld 1.

Many Homeworld veterans might be concerned that battles take place on land instead of in space, however all the pieces are still there:

The Mothership/Flagship is now replaced by a massive central crawler that serves the same functions. You produce capital" crawlers in the same vein as capital ships in previous titles
date: and use a mix of light and medium units in the same vein as Fighters/Corvettes/Frigates.\n\nPositioning is still "3D" in the sense that using proper elevation can yield significant bonuses in combat

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aIugL1wiiyc&feature=youtu.be

Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak was developed by Blackbird Interactive and published by Gearbox Software. It was released for Steam on January 20th, 2016 for $49.99. A press review copy was provided for The Hidden Levels.

Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak is a Real time strategy game and the follow up to Homeworld: Remastered which debuted at PAX South in 2015. The game is set as the title suggests in the desert. You are in control of what can only be described as a “giant aircraft carrier which can move on desert sand”. The campaign is relatively rich in story albeit militaristic and choppy in tone it does manage to capture your attention. The mechanics are somewhat simple and shallow for a full RTS but that adds a meta game element to the potential multiplayer battles.

What I enjoyed:

Keeping it simple – Deserts of Kharak doesn’t have a ridiculously deep unit type count nor a wide variety of ranges on those unit types. It has three, and each counters one of the others similar to rock, paper, scissors in that none of the three are overall superior. This was initially a bit of a let down but in the aspect of game design it’s a relatively solid strategy. This type of limitation encourages players to think critically without knowing a rich meta-game or end game strategy like other RTS games require.

Dune tunes – The audio and music in the game are well done to a point I felt immersed in the desert once I really sunk into the game. The militaristic style of the game isn’t exactly my personal style, but it’s well done in that I was annoyed by the commanders barking orders at me genuinely. The weapon sounds are also well done and not overzealous like RTS games tend to be so ultimately the audio in the game was clearly part of the cohesive design strategy.

Real time real issues – The premise of the game towards the beginning is that the desert and it’s storms are taking over a planet. This is a relatively topical theme weather is was intended or not since global climate is such a hot button issue. The other issues that come up in dialogue suggest that the environment is incredibly important and not to be taken for granted. It’s an interesting notion to think what would happen should a planet begin to slowly evolve into a desert.

What I disliked:

Sandy voices – The voice overs while convincing were speaking in choppy military speak which started to sound less than human. The dialogue really was a bit of an annoyance to me in terms of how it was written and delivered. The voice acting was likely directed in this course but I can’t help but feeling like it was a less than human performance. The multiple five word sentences and unnaturally bureaucratic tone repeating over and over was irritating.

Sunburnt AI – The AI enemies in the game don’t tend to make very logical decisions nor seem to play well against humans. This is a complaint I’ve heard from other reviewers in discussions about the game and it leads to a bigger overall issue. The game with poor AI then relies on the player base to enrich it via multiplayer games. I have some issues with any game that can’t stand alone without an internet connection unless it’s design is purely meant to be human vs. human.

Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak does have some great moments and fun aspects which are worth taking a look at eventually. I can’t encourage anyone to purchase a game at such a high price point without a better AI or certain multiplayer following. I’d like to think people will see the use of the three unit types as a good limitation of design but ultimately my thoughts are that they will stick with the bigger deeper RTS titles on the market. Relying on us to populate the multiplayer for replay value is a bold choice and forces the mode upon anyone looking to get their full value. I am simply not sure that the game will have enough of a following to garner that sort of multiplayer presence which is a major contributor to my score to wait until the next Steam sale for this one.

Score: Wait for a Sale

reviewText:
Well, here it is, the prequel to Homeworld. This game didn't start out as a Kharak story; it started out as just a new RTS game by Blackbird Interactive which consisted largely of the original Homeworld team. When the Homeworld franchise was auctioned off (again) by Gearbox, Gearbox tracked down Blackbird Interactive and partnered up with them to get their RTS game reconstructed to be a Homeworld prequel. It took all of a year or two to rewrite the storyline and plot and apply narration (etc) assets for it.

The good:
Beautiful game matching the aesthetics overall of Homeworld.
Brillliant artwork, graphics, music, sound, narriation/acting.
Gameplay mechanics very similar to Homeworld.
Fun mechanics, very playable and fun game.
[Barely] satisfying campaign length. (Could be longer, feels rushed, but generally satisfying-ish.)

The bad:
No true 3D gameplay (but definitely 3D terrain if that matters, along the lines of Starcraft)
Infuriating glitches such as aircraft needing to be double-clicked (while they're moving in flight, good luck) and reminded" to land and rearm.
Auto-save checkpoints immediately precede long cutscenes that can't be skipped; you must remember to save after every cutscene if you don't want to repeat them.
Plot and game ending triggers block resource collection for building up for next mission.
Massive narrative plothole at ending requires a complete understanding of the first level of Homeworld 1 before can it be understood to say nothing of being appreciated.

Conclusion:
I have mixed feelings about this game. Overall
recommended: generally satisfying for the Homeworld fan
hoursPlayed: as the essential gameplay elements that made Homeworld great (other than total 3D strategy) are here. If you're a Homeworld fan

reviewText:
Simply put, I think this is the most brilliant RTS to be released since Starcraft: Brood War - coming from someone with thousands of career games in SCBW and SC2, someone who is as competitive and serious about multiplayer RTS gaming as they come.

The statements I'm making in this review are based on approximately 50 hours of play in multiplayer with approximately 90 games under my belt and a 60% win ratio.

The tactical combat in this game is deep and exhilirating.  Ignore the small unit roster - each unit occupies a very specific role and has nuance and depth in their usage.  Ignore the boring desert maps" complaints of others - the desert is a hidden unit in your army.  Its dunes will shield your vulnerable units
date: and their peaks will give your killers their perfect shots.  If you cooperate with the desert and allow it to shape your play
recommended: you will be victorious.  If you disregard it
hoursPlayed: you will be punished by the opponent who doesn't.  Ignore the "two factions are very similar" complaint
voteText: because that couldn't be further from the truth - while each faction has analogous units that ostensibly occupy similar roles
helpfulPercent: they end up functioning and feeling very different in practice.  I would be highly surprised if anyone making that statement has as much time with the game playing both factions as I do.\n\nThe BW similarities come in the form of the incredible lethality and power of the tools at your disposal.  Everything is overpowered
votesHelpful: therefore nothing is overpowered.  One well-placed unit executing a properly positioned ability can decimate an entire army.\n\nUnlike Broodwar and unlike many other RTSes that come before
votesTotal: this game is far more about how you use your units than anything else.  You don't need 500 APM

reviewText:
A worthy addition to the Homeworld universe, the game is both recognizeable enough to be familiar, and different enough to keep me interested.

Pros:
- The story of the search for the 'Primary Anomaly' is interesting and a nice look back into the past of the Homeworld universe.
- Gameplay, while not groundbreaking, is solid and fun. The unit strengths and weaknesses are easy to understand, without getting over complicated.
- Sound is, as always in a Homeworld game, excellent. The background unit chatter makes the forces at your command more than a collection of dots on a map.
- Music deserves it's own entry, it fits the tone wonderfully, giving a sense of the open waste of desert, or the thrill of combat. I WILL be getting the OST.
- Unit designs are cool, from the zippy Strike vehicles, to the lumbering Carrier. Not many games get me to want to own replicas, but dammit, I want a model of that Carrier on my desk!

Cons:
- Occasional oddities of units moving inside of each other, mostly noticable on the Salvagers while collecting resources. Not a big issue, but it would be nice to see it patched out.
- VERY rarely I would notice enemy units jerking around, instead of smoothly moving. This has only happened once however, on one mission, one playthrough. I have yet to replicate it on any other mission, or on the same mission when I restarted it.
-In engine cinematics. I love them, they're well done, add to the story, and look nice... BUT YOU CAN'T SKIP THEM. Seriously, non skippable cinematics in 2016? I am dissapoint. (Yes it's a minior gripe, I know)

Overall, I definitely recommend this game, even to those who have not played any of the Homeworld games before.

reviewText:
OK first up, if you are a diehard Homeworld fan like myself then yes, buy this game. Because it's a bit like meeting an old friend you haven't seen for many many years, and quite frankly feared had died. A friend that was a blast to hang out with in his old spaced out days, but now it seems he has become a well grounded individual (if you catch my drift). Does this make your old friend a bit dull now? Hell no. DoK looks, feels, sounds, and plays just as you would expect a Homeworld game to, irrespective of not being in space. But most importantly it's fun.

If you like RTS games, or are new to them then I would suggest you check out reviews and game play videos on YouTube. As HW relies on a mobile fabrication and persistent fleet mechanic with limited resources that make spamming units a pretty much redundant and counter productive strategy. Which is not to everyone's liking. Make your own mind up, don't let me or anyone else tell you what's good or bad.

Also bear in mind this is not a AAA game, and as such I think some people had unrealistically high expectations, and/or no past experience of HW1, 2, and Cataclysm. The game looks great, runs fine on my medium rig with settings on ultra, and no crashes to report.

However, there are some tweaking issues within the game at launch, which seems pretty much the norm (an additional month or two in production wouldn't have gone amiss), but can be fixed with patching. BBI have already stated they are going to support/patch and add DLC, so the game can only get better. Plus DoK opens up sooo many possible future game avenues for the Homeworld series to pursue, which has to be a good thing for the franchise, and fans alike.

Thanks BBI and Gearbox for resuscitating the Homeworld universe. Any chance of HW 3? Please.

reviewText: Let me start by saying I loved the original homeworld series, and wish they could find a way to bring back the other Homeworld game(Homeworld Cataclysm I believe).    That said, this is a fun game, but I feel its lacking in a lot of the things that made the Homeworld series amazing.  Part of what I loved about the series was the details they put in, for instance how every ship could be seen actually undocking or docking, even the capital ships, and the resource collectors actually had to dock to drop off supplies.  In this game, most of the ships come out of the right spots on the carrier, but when you retire ships they just drive under the carrier, not into the ramp on the back, and the resource collectors just have to touch the carrier or supply ships, not actually dock with them.  They are all small things, but I feel they are a major part of what made the original games so good.  Also, some of the controls or commands for ships are either missing, or badly done.  For instance there is no patrol option, if you queue up too many build orders on base runners they often get messed up, especially if you don't keep that many resources on hand(when you give it the order to build something, it doesn't subtract the resources from your total until the base runner actually gets there).\nOverall, yes I would recommend this game if you are a fan of RTS and/or Homeworld, but I feel they could have done better on it by focusing on a few more details.

reviewText:
Finally, a new, good looking, good playing, deep sci-fi RTS!

Some of the controls I wish I could change - my only gripe, but I can overlook that.

Very much Homeworld meets Ground Control. Your units are expensive and robust and thus you want to protect them - requires to you play using your brain over mindless brawn. You cannot just spam endless units to win the day, instead tactics, strategy and efficient use of a maps resources are the name of the game. Each unit has interesting little abilities and/or deployables that really add the to strategic play.

And let me say this - vehicle porn - lol, the units are gorgeous to watch.  Im not ashamed to admit I lost a few battles because I was too busy watching things move, wheels turn and turrets deploy =)

There is the occassional silliness of an obviously very heavy vehicle flipping end over end when going over an obstacle, but aside from my making me chuckle it doesnt seem to effect gameplay, least it hasnt for me.

Also - the unit chatter, the ambient chatter - Ive never experienced something such as this in an RTS game - it feels completely alive - you can really believe all those units you're moving around have living, breathing people working inside them.

My short two hours in game took me to the 4th capaign mission if I recall - and its been a very cool experience all the way.

If you liked Ground Control and Homeworld, if you like RTS games, if you like the idea of a sort of psuedo Supreme Commander 'lite' (ie: no base building, but large strategic maps and terrain control, similiar play style, rock/paper/scissors style to a large degree) - you cant go wrong here.

It looks great, it sounds great, the units are interesting and fun and just plain old fun to watch - I cant wait to get further in =)

reviewText:
A true, modern Homeworld experience, BBI did a great job.

The campaign, though only moderately lengthy, is fantastic. Great cutscenes, story and progression. The whole way through the singleplayer is a blast.

The combat in Kharak is simplistic but well refined, and follows basic unit-counter mechanics alongside the strategic use of the terrain itself (line of sight and height advantages). It's also awesome to watch a clash of assorted dune-machines blast away at each other, presentation is top notch. The atmosphere this game has with its audio is also second-to-none.

Unfortunately the multiplayer community took a large and rather devastating explosive warhead on launch when the game was tied to Steam region-based matchmaking servers. This region-locked the community, and alongside a few multiplayer connection bugs that prevented games starting in the first place the online playerbase plummeted, you couldn't reliably find and play a game. A shame this is, as Kharak's multiplayer is actually really good. It's a fast paced, skillful and sleek tactical RTS arena.

Due to the (now fixed) initial multiplayer launch issues and resultant lack of players, if you want to have a multiplayer game you'll need to go hunting for people in the forums or on steam etc. I have accumulated a small bunch of Steam friends who I can play a game with on a regular basis, but you need to go hunting, trying to search solo will net negative results.

Ultimately I would recommend Deserts of Kharak to any fan of the Homeworld series or RTS genre, although perhaps not at full price. A game you should pick up during a sale without hesitation.

reviewText:
My review comes from a multiplayer perspective. The campaign has already been covered well  by other reviews.

Its a bit rushed and rough around the edges, (no key binding, few maps, occasional animation glitches etc.) but the developer hasn't given up on it yet and are planning future updates to fix bugs, balance gameplay, and add new maps.

The core game mechanics for online multiplayer are solid. Taking advantage of terrain and scouting are critical to success. Good tactics can and will beat high Actions Per Minute and larger armies in this game. Though there are fewer units available than in other homeworld titles almost every unit has multiple purposes. For example the Gaalsien missile ship is a standard AA unit but also has an EMP motar that can disable ground units.

If you are looking for an RTS that is truly tactical you should give this one a try. If not now, at least when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Loving the transition to ground vehicular combat, very enjoyable. The campaign is surprisingly good with great little cutscenes connecting each mission, some great writing on the dialogue and the art style is fantastic, it's incredibly immersive and the radio chatter is amazing to listen to as it's so varied. Small niggles about the annoying camera controls, your viewpoint feels too close to the battlefield especially when hills and mountains come into view, it's missing vital features which every RTS cannot do without and several other things they need to tweak and fix, but judging by their official forum they're already hard at work on more maps and fixes and improvements.

It's a good solid return to the brilliant setting of Homeworld and I hope BBI continue to add and improve upon it. It's a safe addition to the Homeworld series but I just wish BBI did more with the time they spent on this game, it's good but not as great as it could have been.

So, basically. What's great is the story, voice acting, dialogue, music, gameplay, immersive both visually and through its audio and easily replayable either through mastering the harder difficulty of the campaign because the gameplay is so enjoyable or multiplayer to see how cunning other Homeworld fans can be!

reviewText:
Imagine dating the girl of your dreams 16 years ago. Breaking up with her, going out with Jennifer Aniston a year later and then two years after that, Jennifer Lopez. Then for 14 or so years you justifiably cannot fall in love with any other girl because of that.

This was my entire feels trip through Homeworld, Homeworld: Cataclysm, Homeworld 2. And now, Deserts of Kharak.

reviewText:
Overall, I give Homeworld: DoK a score of 8.5 out of 10.

While it may not be a revolutionary RTS, there are some excellent tactical elements to this game that look like it will have some longevity.

Before the launch of this game, a lot of people were complaining about the number of maps and units in the game. While it is true that there are not a lot of each, this game has done a good job with adding some depth to standard RTS elements to give what the Homeworld series was originally known for - tactical strategy.

The individual units in the game can level up, increasing their power, armor, etc. Research also allows for various special abilities, so the base units in the game can really be customized and used in a variety of ways.

The mobile carrier that is your main base is an interesting change to traditional RTS where you have to build stagnant bases. This is where you build your fleet and research, but you can also customize the abilities of the carrier to make it tougher, a repair hub and/or a strong defensive base.

I'm only about 1.5 hours into playing the game so far but wanted to give my initial review. Personally, I'll be keeping this game. While it may not be worth a full $50, I got it with the remastered package, so all together they are well worth it.

I do hope the game will expand with some additional content in the coming months - more map variety and maybe a few more units couldn't hurt. However, I'll still be happy with this game without it.

Honestly, my biggest complaint about the game is the graphics. They're not horrible but they're not great either. They don't feel like an A+ title in 2016 (close-up shots during the cutscenes show gradients realy bad, for example). However, during normal gameplay, the graphics are decent and have a nice feel.

Overall, if you enjoy RTS games (especially if you like on-the-go combat) and/or are a fan of the Homeworld series, I would recommend DoK.

reviewText:
Sublime. No other game makes me feel like I am experiencing the sublime as well as a Homeworld game. I was nervous about Deserts of Kharak--the developers haven't made a Homeworld in twelve years, and the last one they made was in space. Could Deserts of Kharak be any good?

Yes.

Yes it could be.

I don't know about Multiplayer or Skirmish--I don't play Homeworld for that--but this is totally a Homeworld game. All the mechanics that really mattered are here, and, to be honest, they make creative, worthwhile use of the terrain in one of the most innovative ways a developer has ever done. Great story, great gameplay, great campaign.

It's Homeworld.

reviewText:
Homeworld: deserts of kharak will take you to the scorching desert in this tactical sci-fi rts.

good:

bad:

reviewText:
DoK is a very Homeworld game, right down to its gameplay and experience. The only major element that comprises every homeworld game is the compelling storyline. As the storyline is good, I wouldn't say it is great compared  to HW1, HW:C and HW2 (I liked HW2 very much as compared to many people). Also, the feeling of lack of mysticism. Where the feeling of mystery existed in every Homeworld game before this, DoK has a profound lack of mystery surrounding the ancient ships buried in the sand and the artifacts that are collected. The artifacts are just passed off as Carrier Upgrades, and no further explanation or depth is given to them. Also, in HW1, there were many other different factions whom the Kushan encounter, and even mysterious ancient objects that pose a formidable obstacle to your journey. The ending itself feels really rushed and it seems like the devs quickly wrapped it up so it could ship fast instead of expanding the end a little more.

I did not quite like the physics of the game as many a time I have seen the entire Kapisi standing with its head up when the immediate area was filled with units. Also, disappointing unit animations. As compared to the original HW, the ballistics can sometimes make no sense at all. I have seen a railgun not firing in the direction of an enemy yet the enemy gets damage. Gameplay itself was fun.

A better game than HW1, HW2 or HW:C? Nope but still recommended as the first game for those who are interested in entering the HW universe.

reviewText:
Singleplayer delivers the homeworld feel pretty well. The feeling of isolation and limited resources is really nice. The persistent units and veterancy helps with giving you a sense of what is at stake.

However it is short, and the AI isn't anything special but is challenging enough in the campaign as it can spawn tons of units and is heavily scripted.

Skirmish isn't great, as there's too few maps and the AI cannot counter air units and in general isn't very good.

Multiplayer isn't great either. The tech tree isn't entirely visible, so you'll have to memorize it while the gameplay is mostly focused on getting a bigger blob" of units than your opponent.

The game is not very focused on decisionmaking or strategy. There's little sense of "outsmarting" your opponent as it is you're "outplaying" him by keeping up your production constantly
date:
getting the upgrades at the right times and expanding at the right time. You're not setting traps or making elaborate plans. You're just building units and trying to keep your economy intact while doing it.

Some units have special abilities but they are not the focal point of the gameplay.

TL;DR: The singleplayer campaign is interesting. Skirmish and multiplayer is not very interesting."

reviewText:
Pros:
* Deserts of Kharak feels like a Homeworld game even with the y-axis removed from play. The gameplay is solid and the missions are varied.

* The story elements lend themselves naturally to building up on origin story for Homeworld. Some people are incredibly over protective of the Homeworld story but this seems to build upon it nicely.

Cons:
* It's far too short. I think this is an excellently made game but I cannot recommend you pick it up at full price because the campaign is over and done with far too quickly. The missions themselves are diverse but the actual tactical options are a bit limited (although not especially different to homeworlds tactics).

* Homeworld succeeded because although you were often facing the same enemy you occasionally had missions with other races and bad guys getting involved (for whom the usual strategies wouldn't work) - unfortunately this game doesn't really break out into new and unexpected opponents.

In conclusion:
If you are a die hard fan of Homeworld then pick this up but expect to smash through the campaign in about four decent length play sessions. The lack of diversity in your opponents means that you don't really end up changing your tactics which is disappointing compared to previous Homeworld games. If you can wait then I suggest picking this game up at about half its launch price.

reviewText:
A game that came out of nowhere but that I somehow wanted very badly. H:DK is a little joy of a game, with outstanding visuals, excellent optimisation... And FINALLY a gameplay that doesn't demand an LSD-Red bull mix worth of APM skills.
It's not exactly slow paced, but units don't die in two seconds, so you get time to adjust, control formations and positions, use what abilities there are (all straightforward and streamlined like speed boost for fast attack vehicles or smoke screens for tanks) as needed.

Despite the apparent lack of variety in units (something I would personally object, as there are roughly 14 units per faction, there being two factions with subtle differences in their lineup), the gameplay has many layers, and the balance of resource gathering / unit construction-research / carrier usage (they're like the Motherships of old, only much more powerful) / artifact retrieval makes for a game where there is always something more to do, optimise or respond to.

Finally, I grew up playing Homeworld 1. It was fantastic. This is its prequel, and from the audio design (guns, engines, UI, and especially the radio chatter), the music, the visuals, and the general narrative and atmosphere... I felt at home. It's more of a talented application of the meaning of this franchise onto a new game rather than fan service, and that means a great deal to me.

10/10 would grow up playing.

reviewText:
My recommendation?

This has been one of the smoothest launching games that i have seen.

I have a had a few issues while playing but i think the main cause of those may be in my hardware instead of the game.

The graphics on the game are amazing with the detail they went through. Mind you its still thr classic solid cockpit or at least on my graphics settings, but the attention to detail is 10/10.

Campaign is good, its 13 missions but it has so many areas you could lead into another campaign which i won't spoil for the potential player.

The audio is off the charts, the battle chatter is great to listen to and hearing some of the units spool up as well as launching your LAVS off of a dune with the overdrive hearing that engine rev is great.

While i havent gotten on multiplayer yet, the devs have confirmed that there will be more maps and they are also working on more.

11/10 would kill genocidal maniacs kiths ♥♥♥ again

reviewText:
Great little game!

I've got two negatives, one is probably something I'm quite alone in thinking, the other is a purely objective observation.

Firstly, as a fan of the Homeworld franchise I very much dislike how this is so character focused, and how they made it a prequel. I'd much rather have had a stand alone salvage-huge-spaceship-wrecks-game in the Homeworld universe, keeping some of the original mysterious atmosphere etc. More along the lines of what this seemed to be slated as when it was still Hardware: Shipbreakers.

Secondly, it's waaaay too easy, even on the hardest difficulty. I had to stop myself from soaking up all the RU/CUs on the maps because it would simply have made it all even worse. Not to mention if you dare to farm some enemies in one of the missions with endless waves (most of them) to gain XP. Or capture a few enemy cruisers. Just don't do it, else you can pretty much just attack move every mission thereafter to completion.


Still, regardless of those points you can't help but enjoy the time it takes to complete the campaign. It feels very reminiscent of Homeworld with some Ground Control thrown in. The S'jet focus takes away from it sometimes, but it still feels pretty grand and special while it lasts. The cut scenes are great for the most part, the action is non-stop, the tech upgrades and units keep on rolling out and the maps are mostly well-designed.

As for multiplayer in this one. Mjeeeh, not for me. If you're one to enjoy that aspect, I guess you'll get more hours out of it than me, and so might just get it at full price. Same if the mod scene takes off as that will no doubt add a lot of replay value.

reviewText: Deserts of Kharak is a good game with strong story telling, beautiful graphics, and responsive and intuitive game controls. It took me about 15 hours to beat the single player game on normal difficulty. I found the skirmish AI easily beaten at all difficulty levels, but I am hoping that will change with patches. All in all i recommend for anyone who is a fan of RTS games.

reviewText:
Good game, but not enought for 49.99.

Very nice story, tipical of Homeworld series and nice graphics. Gameplay is interesting, a bit different from what we Homeworld fans are used to but that is only because it is a 2D RTs not a 3D but regardless it has a nice feel.

Very few units and very limited strategy options due to the lack of options like stances or attack options.
AI is rubish and not competitive at all. very liear strategy, predefined and very predictable. You ovewhelm the enemy with bombers while keeping you carrier protected with heavy unit and you win any battle. The AI is not able to change strategy or adapt to different situations.

I will give it a positive vote because of the efforts, but the game does not deserve the 49.90 price.

reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak is an RTS set on the desert world of Kharak before HW1, unlike HW1 and HW2 this is a ground based RTS  the Home World feel is there.

Now more content will be added along the road, This was originally announced as Home world ShipBreakers a long while back, Instead of your massive mother ship you get a command carrier, and theres 2 factions rather than 4

- The Coalition
- The Gaalsien

The Gaalsien is your High Tech religous faction.
and the Coalition are the Hiigarans respectively

I've said before more content is coming so it should recover from what appears to have been a bad start.

reviewText:
I liked it. And I'm biased because I am also loyal to the brand. I've played Homeworld 1&2 when they first came out (they are in my nostalgia wishlist of things to get). The controls felt natural. The command playstyle was very Homeworld 1&2. It's a place where I was comfortable.

If you collect RTS this is one to add to your collection. It's a good, straightforward and solid RTS.
However, If you're looking for something unique, this game isn't the place to get it.

Things I noticed and gave nod to was the height map terrains giving defilade and enfilade (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enfilade_and_defilade) actual meaning. The homeworld version of the mothership was upgradeable and not defensless.

My biggest complaint is there isn't a lot of depth of gameplay. I completed the single player (distracted) in less than 8 hours. There aren't many ways to skin the cat (strategies that win the game) the story left me wanting more. I didn't feel challenged in the multiplayer and skirmish options. I've noticed that a lot from games recently, where they release a stable first product then pile on DLC's to increase the revenue. I get the sense this game will have more depth once the DLC's start rolling out.

reviewText:
This is a RTS with a new perspective of the Homeworld universe more of a prequel as it tells the story of an expidition force scowering the deserts of their planet for the salvation of their people. Your base is basically an aircraft carrier on treads called the Kapisi, you can reasearch, build and upgrade units from it and as you progress through the game it will also be one of your most powerful weapons (cue tomahawk missle). The bulk of your forces will consist of various attack vehicles of many roles and sizes but the best part is when you get aircraft. Nothing beats playing the song Dangerzone while launching fighters into enemy territory! The AI in the campaign is ok, but skirmish is where things are much to be desired. You'll be rushed quite a bit in the beginning with quite a few units, but as soon as you pick you balls up and build up a sizable the AI starts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ itself it just.... you win... basically, you walk your army to it's carrier and blow it to hell.

The Good
- the story is good for homeworld players
- the unit designs are good
- the art in general is amazing
- the voice acting is good quality
- combat is fluid
- units have a reasonable rock-paper-scissor mechanic

The Bad
- AI needs more work
- Story feels a bit short

The Verdict
This is a is good game but it's still kind of a diamond in the rough, it has the ability to be a top notch RTS game it just needs a couple more updates to skirmish to make solo play all the more enjoyable. I give it a 7/10, I can't lie it was hard putting down $50 but overall I don't regret it.

reviewText: Since I haven't played enough multiplayer to really comment on multiplayer balancing, this would mainly be a review for single player campaign.\n\nThe campaign itself is wonderfully done with the right combination of story and visual story telling. Story is being told actively as you play the game, and the pace at which the game unfolds new features in the campaign allows the player to pick up what to do with different units very naturally. Story integrates itself well to the original Homeworld universe, and suble hints suggest that this conflict behind the Desert of Kharak campaign does not invole any clear villain" or the "good-guy"
date: but a society torn between progressivist and conservative at a time of hardship on a planet going through major climate change. If you require the story to be told in your face with everything blatantly obvious
recommended: you would probably not enjoy the story of Desert of Kharak. However
hoursPlayed: if you enjoy picking up subtle hints and plot pieces spread throughout the game's campaign
voteText: you'll enjoy playing through this game.\n\nAs for the aesthetics and presentation of the game
helpfulPercent: it inherits a lot of the visual and atomospher of the original Homeworld series. The designs are very minimal yet cleanly done
votesHelpful: and if you were a fan of the original series (or a fan of the more realistic Scifi design)
votesTotal: it'll most likely please you. Voice acting is also done in a natural manner instead of the over-the-top method you would find in lot of the other games. However
votesFunny: this is not without it's cons. Although the game put heavy emphasis on terrain utilization
commentsCount: it's sometimes difficult to visually decipher which grounds offer to terrain advantage until your units are physically interacting with the terrain. Since the difficulty level of the campaign is not too high this is not a major set back
column16: but I wonder if this issue would be addressed in the future patch.\n\nOverall
column17: the game offer a lot of promise
column18: and I'm sure a lot of the kinks would be worked out in the near future. I highly recommend this game to the fans of the original Homeworld series as well as fans of RTS. Those who enjoyed games like Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander would definitely enjoy this game."

reviewText:
Short version:  It's a new Homeworld; if you liked the old ones or have been wanting to try a homeworld this is a good place to start.  If you're not a homeworld fan(or looking to get into homeworld), and you're just looking for a good RTS then your mileage may vary based on what you have previously liked in the RTS genre.

Long version:  Deserts of Kharak does well what every homeworld game has done before it - tell a story.  It's an exceedingly rare experience for an RTS to tell a story well, for you to care about what happens to the characters, for you to get emotionally invovled, and to be able to tell that story actively through the tiny units and voice-overs on the screen.

Gameplay is solid; each unit has a defined role that it excels in.  Exploiting unit's weaknesses and strengths is extremely satisfying when you're the one delivering, and appropraitely punshing if you're on the receiving end.  It's not so overpowered that you can simply overwhelm your oppoenent if they make a wrong move, but not so underpowered that it leaves you wondering if you actually have the upper hand.  Tactics (high ground, terrain blocking) and LOS make noticeable impact on gameplay as well, and this is a welcome addition.  It shakes up the standard rocks-paper-scissors gameplay enough to make every engagement interesting, and so that even a mismatched fight can be turned towards your favor.
A side-note on gameplay; I've seen a lot of criticism of this game because it doesn't live up to standards set by games like starcraft.  I found this criticism generally unfair because the comparisions drawn I find unapplicable.  I think this game most resembles a cross between company of heroes and total annihiliation/ supreme commander.  Homeworld to Starcraft is like a BMW to a Ford.  They are both a car, they basically do the same thing, but that's about where the similarities end.  But I digress, moving on. . .

AI and MP:  There's no nice way to put this but the AI is lacking in it's current state.  I played the campaign on the equivalent of medium, and at no point did I feel threatened or like I was going to lose.  MP is region locked which is stupid since there's a lobby system in place; it should have been simple to just add a ping and let players make their own decisions.  Also, there's only 5 maps to chose from when playing MP or skirmish.
These things are not a big deal to me (except the region lock), but that's probably because I played company of heroes competatively back in the day and there were only 5 maps I played on back then (1v1 automatch), and I only plan on playing Deserts competatively.  That being said, I still see these things as significant problems.  RTS's thrive on healthy skirmishs and a solid AI (or a solid competative community), and good maps help make both those things happen.

BBI has said, as of the writing of this review, that they are working on the AI and they plan on releasing more maps.  They have also said that maps will always be free and never DLC.  They have not commented on the region lock to my knowlege.

So is it worth $50?  As I said at the beginning, your mileage will vary based on what you like in your RTS genre.  If you're looking for a RTS you can play by yourself and be entertained with for a long time (e.g. AoE, RoN), I would say not in its current state.  Give it a patch or two; see if the skirmish state improves.  If you're looking for a good story with potentially competative MP, then I would say yes.

reviewText:
Overall: a positive review. Some points that I would change if i were Blackbird Interactive but any game that wants to keep the Homeworld legend going gets a thumbs up from me.

Positives:

- The story is really good. You really feel like you are working towards the survival of your people and you do get emotionally invested when you lose your units.
- Graphics look great and run well on my ultra HD monitor in max settings
- It is Homeworld! Even the unit icons look the same
- Controls are relatively easy
- Cutscenes are superb. The artistic effects are top notch.
- Story follows the Homeworld storyline perfectly and I love the references to things you learnt in Homeworld 1 and 2.

Negatives

- Dont buy the expedition guide. There is so little information in there that it is definitely not worth buying. In fact I cannot understand how it comes to 600MB. Perhaps I am missing a huge part or I am going blind but £5~ is a lot of money for something that would cost a couple of pennies as a piece of paper.
- Units could have a lot more variety. Hopefully they will patch in more at a later date.
- This is based in the Homeworld universe but isn't Homeworld. I miss having multiple carriers creating a fleet of ships. In this you have one command ship that makes things and that is it.
- Fleet sizes are a fraction of the size of in Homeworld the original. I remember making fleets of hundreds or thousands of ships (yes the lag was awful) and then fighting the enemy, In this game the fleets are only tens or at max a hundred.

Overall

It's Homeworld so buy it. The more people that buy it, the more chance of Homeworld 3.

reviewText: At first I thought I would end up bored by what seemed like a paucity of units and a desert enviornment. I mean how exciting can it be to fight in a desert? After playing 4 missions in the campaign I'm happy to say I'm pleased and hours went by without me realising it. The campaign keeps you on your toes and at least for me didn't allow me to camp too long and build my forces up to an overwhelming level. How you use light and heavy units becomes important as they all have strengths and weak points. Example: a pack of ranged railguns annhilated my swarm of light attack craft from high ground before they reached effective range. I'd like to see more maps for skirmish and multiplayer and hopefully some new units if possible. I loved homeworld and it's sequels and this ties in nicely as a prequel. In my opinion it's worth the money.

reviewText:
It's very difficult for a modern game to be as innovative as the original homeworld.

This game, I would say, isn't innovative at all. For fans of homeworld though, I would recommend this game. There are a few caveats, though.

1. Controls are not rebindable.
2. For a game that depends on terrain placement, one has to individually place each unit. With older homeworld games there was formation control, with this one, the controls are point and click. It's streamlined in a lot of ways, and this detracts from the overall experience.

But the major successes are that this game lives and breathes the homeworld universe. They essentially took every bit of lore from the 1999 manual to the cataclysm game, and fleshed it out completely.

The multiplayer maps are a bit thin at the moment, but they've promised that more maps are coming with future updates.

Launch Day bugs are very minor. Occasionally an enemy won't attack your position as expected. It's trivial to just go get them, or hit them with airstrikes.

Overall, as someone who loves the homeworld universe, I loved this game.

If you like the homeworld universe, you'll love it too.

You'll be slightly disappointed that it lacks some of the features of previous games, but you'll still have fun.

So with a few caveats, I absolutely recommend this game, and hope for more and better from Gearbox in the future.

reviewText:
I've never imagined Unity engine could achieve this massive battleground with Michael Bay explosions while the vehicle dynamic got so well simulated. Bringing the immersive gameplay just like I was there in the deserts of Kharak.

And the Expedition Guide was definitely the best eBook I've ever read. The character intros, the storytellings, the 3D viewers, the galleries, the films, the dev logs, totally fantastic!

I'm really glad the Homeworld title was brought back to the hands of its original creators. Every effort focusing on the details made the game so distinctive and so touching.

I think it's a good start for Blackbird Interactive and I'm eagerly hoping they could bring more and more fascinating contents in the future.

- the voice acting is good quality
- combat is fluid
- units have a reasonable rock-paper-scissor mechanic

The Bad
- AI needs more work
- Story feels a bit short

The Verdict
This is a is good game but it's still kind of a diamond in the rough, it has the ability to be a top notch RTS game it just needs a couple more updates to skirmish to make solo play all the more enjoyable. I give it a 7/10, I can't lie it was hard putting down $50 but overall I don't regret it.

reviewText:
I've never imagined Unity engine could achieve this massive battleground with Michael Bay explosions while the vehicle dynamic got so well simulated. Bringing the immersive gameplay just like I was there in the deserts of Kharak.

And the Expedition Guide was definitely the best eBook I've ever read. The character intros, the storytellings, the 3D viewers, the galleries, the films, the dev logs, totally fantastic!

I'm really glad the Homeworld title was brought back to the hands of its original creators. Every effort focusing on the details made the game so distinctive and so touching.

I think it's a good start for Blackbird Interactive and I'm eagerly hoping they could bring more and more fascinating contents in the future.

reviewText: This game was very well done and I enjoyed every minute of it. Now with that being said, I am a Die Hard HW1/2 fan who has play this series from day one and wouldn't miss a thing, but I have the capability to determine a steaming pile of crap. This game was never meant to be an exact replica of 1 or 2 and I knew that they were trying a new form of play. The formula was not completely there unfortunately. I feel it lack some of the luster it should have had and feel that there should have been more in the way of ships and their design. It is a start to a new company and I feel there will be growing pains, but in due time everything will be set right. 8/10 Will Play Again.\n
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Would totally recommend it,if they would still offer Homeworld: Remastered edition (classic included) as a gift,if you buy this game. Game is not worth the current price tag,since there's nothing much to do in this game right now. When you've done with campaign,you'll proceed to multiplayer and you'll get bored by time,since there's only 5 maps. Game feels like early access,although developers are talking with us and they're saying,they're already working on updates.\nThe real elephant in the room is the lack of content. As of writing this there are only two factions, five official multiplayer maps, barely any AI to speak of, and a campaign that can be polished off easily in under ten hours. Nothing scandalous but it's definitely sparse for the price tag. Doubtless more content is on the way, and once it drops I'll happily flip my recommendation to a yes. Until then you'll have to decide whether fifty dollars is too much for a shiny, flimsy toy like DoK.\nIf you've played SC2 or Company of Heroes,than this game will feel really fresh. There's interesting concept,it just misses a lot of Original functions of Homeworld. At current game state = Not recommended. Get it for discount or with Homeworld remastered included,since this game alone is not worth the 45.99 EUR.

reviewText:
I am one of the 700 people who backed this game as a Prospector in 2013 when it was first announced, because I'm a Homeworld nerd and  loved the idea of the spiritual sucessor of Homeworld. I even tracked the progress of this game all the way to release because I believed so much in this project.

Almost all the other reviewers here have ticked the typical checklist: the game is beautiful, the interactive manual is meaty and full of the lore goodness which has been missing from games, the campaign is great but...

The multiplayer aspect doesn't work.

The devs kept on talking up the MP aspect of the game and how amazingly competitive it's going to be, but it doesn't work. To make things worse, on the rare off-chance the MP works and you are able to wait out the 15-minute matchmaking timer, the players are horrid. I've had people banzai-charge their carriers into enemy lines, I've had roleplayers spamming chat with RP while doing nothing in the game but sending 4 LAVs to die. I won't mind the trouble of waiting for the multiplayer function to be fixed if the community is great, but it's worse than the ♥♥♥♥ blyat" and "putang ina mo" spammers in CS:GO and Dota2. But no
date: this game has no longevity as long as the MP function doesn't work
recommended: and the devs have not said a single peep on intending to fix it.\n\nAnd oh
hoursPlayed: it's not worth it to even play Skirmish with AI because the AI is pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.\n\nAs much as I want to like this game
voteText: I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to fellow gamers.\n\ntl;dr the game is cool but has no longevity because multiplayer does not work. Do not buy unless it's $15 on a future Steam sale."

reviewText:
Homeworld is back.
The singleplayer is beautiful. The sounds as in background chatter and music are just right and much like the orignals. Throw in sand tornado's gigantic rolling sandstorms the GFX are beautiful. The missions are progressive and take the player through the learning steps of how to play the game. The end is well it makes this a standalone by its self much like cata. Overall very fun game.

That said there is such a huge strategic side to this game. You want to keep you units alive because they level up. Each unit has a name and Xp. The more you keep them alive the stronger they get. So Blob tactics will get you killed quickly. Especially in multiplayer you need to work with your team to plan attacks and get out with the least losses.

Each race has its good and bad points for multi. In the end I would say try it. The single player alone is worth it and Multiplayer is very hard if your looking for a good stratigic game. This is it.

Knowing the modding community on this is huge. Expect a lot of fun mods for this. Already a few mods out for fun.

reviewText:
A Video production of this review can be found here https://youtu.be/fl21IelYZP8

HOMEWORLD: DESERTS OF KHARAK REVIEW
Author: SHADOWFORKS
19-Jan-2016

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel to Relic’s Homeworld series, developed by Blackbird Interactive.  After dejected in development hell for a good 6 years, the game is finally finished.  This new Homeworld game takes place nearly 100 years before the original.  In which a discovery of deviations in  Kharak, ensue an expedition through the southern deserts.

The Homeworld games are scientific, yet grungy.  And it is all used as a behind-the-scenes approach to help tell the story.  Religious warfare is a habituated trait among the dusts of Kharak.  And while an acreage of this plot was interlaced with the original Homeworld’s instruction manual.  Preconceived plot devices have been replaced in favor of concentrated design.  Squabbling races, somber sacrifices, and titanic discoveries all move the plot into a coherent stream, eventually creating a dynamic and unforgettable plot.

The animation and art-style are cel-shaded into an arenaceous aesthetic.  Vehicles look weathered and blemished.  And the physics are interlaced to the elevations of the deserts ridges.  Another description would be regarding the scale of your expedition through the secluse wild.  Units look impressive in scope when an abundance of them are present.  And the contrast from appliances, such as Salvagers when compared to the Kalisi, is well designed.The art-style perfectly conceives the atmosphere of the desert planet it’s trying to represent, with a great presence towards the desolation and emptiness of the Kharak landscape.  Seeing dune-buggy’s circle and bounce around their opposition is a satisfying use of physics, and the dust their wheels kick up is a wonderful example of the game’s attention to detail.  Overall this is a truly beautiful game, even on lower end computers.

The music in Deserts of Kharak is persistent in reminding you of the bleak pastels that you’re traversing.  Orchestrating and retaining the astrological concept of the original games, the soundtrack twists it into a symphony, chronicling an excursive crusade fully motivated by the desire to discover.  No longer are the airy drawls of the original homeworld, in it’s place are the searing sounds of low methodical beats.

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is an RTS, a genre that has been seemingly dormant during recent years.  You can organize attack-squads, call in airstrikes, and control the hulking PC called the Kalisi, as you traverse the seemingly endless sand-dunes and opposing forces you encounter.  The micro-managing of resources and defense of incrusion, is an exercise in choices.  Should I allot development of better units, or should I create more of the same in order to fend off this attack?  Which resource should I harvest, and how many attack units should I leave with them in order to preserve them?  All of these questions contribute to how you will execute your gameplay experience when playing Deserts of Kharak.  It’s all very complicated, but intensely rewarding when you execute a perfect mission leaving no possibility unsecured in a timely manner.

With a 15 hour campaign, Deserts of Kharat includes a decently meaty story.  And including a multiplayer mode that has a bevy of replayability value, the value for Deserts of Kharat is impressive.  The game is a worthy successor that takes a step back in all the right places, while including an impressive amount of innovation and character that was not yet seen in the originals.  Gearbox, amidst their incredible resume, helped make a descendant to the cult-classic series, a choice that I hope they will continue to go through with.

I was left wanting more by the end of Deserts of Kharak, not because of brevity, but because it was so satisfying to play.  Every second of the game was the perfect amount of difficulty that made me feeling hopeless one second, only to turn the mission around with one bold choice.  With a great world inhabited by great writing, Deserts of Kharak bares the Homeworld badge proudly.  The new perspective of ground combat is fresh and new, while the aesthetic and ambience increase an already quality RTS series worthiness.  Even if you are new to the series of Homeworld, and similarly unfamiliar with the RTS genre. Deserts of Kharak is a great game for veterans of the Homeworld series, and newcomers alike.

HOMEWORLD: DESERTS OF KHARAK DESERVES A 9/10

reviewText: Deserts of Kharak succeeds in both carrying the Homeworld series torch and being compelling without having played the other games in the series. Its gameplay is intuitive and rapid paced. Its story conveys the same sense of apocalyptic urgency and desperation as the earlier games without rehashing or repeating the same plot points. It's a visually remarkable game with a soundtrack that makes you feel as if what you're doing matters and need to hurry- the fate of Kharak is in your hands after all, right? Even the cutscenes are beautiful and (rarest of all) actually forward the story in a way that impacts the player emotionally. Buy it and play it.

reviewText:
I've not yet played all the way through the game, but have completed a little of the single player campaign. I'll write my thoughts now and update the review as I go through the game. This is my initial impressions.

Graphics, gameplay and performance

Again, graphically, the textures are of high detail for a RTS game and its a joy to zoom in and see the detail. Talking about the zoom, I like the tactical view, but, would love the ability to zoom out a little further, this game needs a supreme commander like tactical zoom. It can be tricky to navigate the battlefield when there is a lot going on.

You can customise the look of you fleet, for each battle, away from the default JCB yellow and in skirmish/multiplayer, play as either of the two factions, the Coalition or the Gaalsien. The Gaalsien have production carriers, allowing them to create units anywhere on the map, where as the carrier does this job for the Coalition, so they have managed ti create two gameplay styles here.

I played this on my Core i5 4670 with GTX 970 and it looked amazing, frame rate a costant 60fps, lovely to look and and play with such a smooth frame rate. All settings were set to maximum. The minimum requirments suggest a GT 440, which is less than half the power of the GTX 860m in my 3ghz core i5 4210h laptop. Initially I got an appauling framerate in 1080p, and wondered what it would be like on one of the older cards! Dropping to 1600x900 or 1280x720 resolution, settings can be upped to medium and a respectable 20 - 25 fps can be acheived.

**Update** I investigated further to see the cause of the low framerate and it was a combination of things.Firstly a recent Windows 10 upgrade" had reset many of my settings to default
date:
so the nvidia GPU was on auto select and the game had chosen the onboard intel gpu to run it! Forcing the 860m to again be default gave me 60fps at ultra. :)

The game seems stable and i've not experiences any crashing.

reviewText:
Story elements like any Homeworld game have been knocked out of the park, even with playing HW1 and 2 you still are invested, despite knowing the ending. They actually tried to flesh out the characters in this, which seems weird, you feel some connection to them, but they are relatively flat.

Combat is interesting, though aligning your troops on a ridge is damn near impossible. Aircraft offers a good long range strike capability which is OP, unless they have some AA defenses, but still they can also be knocked out using aircraft. Despite the aircraft dominating land vehicles still are effective for holding ground so you can better position your aircraft.

The little things are sadly underdone: docking, formations, tactics all seem to be gone which is saddening.

Overall I recommend because it is relentlessly capturing, I could not put in down.

reviewText:
Who would have though 12 years after homeworld 2 we'd still be waiting on a sequel.  Well here we are, and how pleasantly suprising it is to find a prequel that fits in so well with the established universe.

For the unitinitated, homeworld is a series that lives and dies based on atmosphere and imersion.  And holy smokes, does this game deliver.  The campaign cutscenes are epic, the desert landscapes are vivid, and the tension feels real.  And holy smokes do I sound like a shill.

This game is worth it for the campaign alone.  Some of us have waited years for a game to continue the homeworld legacy, and while its certainly not homeworld 3, and you can see the edges where the budget didn't quite come together, this is proably the most imersive RTS I've ever played.

Buy the game.  Drive a landcarrier.  Play homeworld 3 someday. (maybe)

reviewText:
Homeworld is still one of the best games I have ever played and I am a huge fan. Than being said I really enjoyed the new installment in the Homeworld franchise and you don’t even have needed to play the originals to enjoy this one. Any lover of RTS would love this game, and the fact that you have to manage your resources throughout the entire campaign makes it even more challenging at times.

So some Pros:
-Beautiful Graphics
-Great Plot Line and story telling
-Interesting gameplay
-MP is intense and very fun

Some Cons:
-The AI could use some tweaks at times
-Kinda disappointed in the selection of units (Homeworld 1, 2 and Cataclysm had almost double if not more)
-Sometimes I felt like I was just doing the same things over (In SP, MP is a completely different story)

Overall not a game without some flaws but would I say buy it.... Definitely! You will get your money's worth in time spent playing

reviewText:
Premium RTS experience from veterans who built some of the best offerings in the genre.

Approachable game play and controls immerse you in this highly polished environment wrapped in an engrossing story with excellent art and audio. Being able to maneuver the camera to see all angles of a map puts you in the middle of the action when you want to see the bird's eye view, or follow a single unit as it attacks an enemy.

Interface with its keybound counterparts lets you activate commands quickly and not get jammed up with deep layers of menus.

Combat is loud, flashy and fun with different units having their own characteristics and purpose in a fight.

Blend of fast paced action and well told story encouraged me to want to jump to the next map after each battle. Hoping the complete campaign is as fun as the missions I've already played, and the game remains playable when the mayhem from later missions unfolds.

reviewText:
Homeworld: Desert of Kharak is a great game a fantastic spin-off for the Homeworld franchise.

Singleplayer campaign took me about 12 hours on the hardest difficulty setting, I got wrecked by the AI a few times and had to restart or reload from a save multiple times. The story is well written and executed, it is mostly fed to you through cutscenes and animatics. Even for fans of the original titles (who kinda know how the game is going to end, after all it`s a prequel) there are plenty of surprises!

Multiplayer/Skirmish is fun but it suffers a bit from the low map choice (5 maps at release). At least in Artifact Retrieval" mode (basically capture the flag) the AI can be very

reviewText:
An alright campaign that lasts just over 10 hours doesn't justify its $50 USD price tag. The replayability comes from skirmish and multiplayer.

Skirmish has awful AI that is the worst I've seen in an RTS in recent years.

The Multiplayer, while balanced and fun for the most part, has awful servers. The last 5 games I have played have resulted in myself or someone else disconnecting and ruining the game. The lag is also unbearable and a result of BBI's laziness and greediness when it comes to investing into decent servers. The lead game designer himself said multiplayer is extremely important in RTS games and then goes on to release a game with servers so bad that competitive play is impossible.

Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 7/10
Multiplayer: 4/10
Campaign: 7/10
Replayability: 5/10
Skirmish: 4/10

Overall score: 6/10
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Homeworld: DOK is an amazing game. The idea with everything (almost) being mobile, is a nice take on the RTS genre, as is the giant carrier on wheels. Firefights kick up dirt, weapons feels punchy. The background radio chatter is astonishing. Graphics are great too. The game also sports a very nice interface/menu in-game.

The best RTS since C&C Generals!

I could use a little more zoom-out since many weapons shoot more than a screen length and I would like to do away with deploying logistic modules (which are used to be able to build more units), they are grounded which defeats some of the feel of a mobile army. The same goes for the ability to place fixed turrets. They should be replaced by vehicles.

Also, more multiplayer/skirmish options are needed. I would like to be able to have matches without air force for example.

Those are minor points, the game has blown me away.

reviewText:
As you can guess by the name Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel to the first groundbreaking Homeworld game.

Of course you’re not in space this time but on the world of Kharak fighting a ground and air war against your enemies. In typical Homeworld fashion your ship a massive is LANDCARRIER is forced to start it’s journey and fight battles before it was ready to. Unlike with the Motherships in the previous games, the Kapisi is not only a mobile production center but a warship able to destroy the enemy all by itself. Another change from the earlier games is you find out about the people who crew this ship. The most important of these characters is Rachel S’Jet. A science officer who plays a critical part in the story and has her personal reasons for being on this expedition. But you also find out about the captain, different officers and even your more experienced vehicle commandeers will have names given to them.

The AI isn’t the best and Blackbird has promised to work at fixing this and more multiplayer maps are said to be on the way. The number of missions is huge, but they are fairly varied and things can go sideways at times and your original goals might go out the window.

Despite it’s flaws it is a good game and I look forward to spending no small amount of time playing in the sand. sm

reviewText: Having played +20 hours multiplayer I can say this is a lot of fun. One of my favorite multiplayer games I have played. reminds me a lot of world in conflict which I loved growing up but this game takes all the good about that game and leaves all the negetives behind. the los battle combined with high ground and such is so interesting and fun. battles feel more like a dance as players jockey for the best postions. if this where it it wouldnt be so fun since the game would turn into who has high ground wins game, but with the relics and having to take them to extraction zones your forced to not only defend your    own relics but attack the enemies as well. the way the units are done is also really good, they have a nice balance bettween the different types. the railgun for instance is a long range heavy damage unit but it is a glass cannon and to get use of it's full attack range you need lav's which are fast and have a short range but fast firing gun, which can easily swarm over a bunch of unsupported railguns. to blance this all out there is armored units whihc the lav's do basicly no damage to but the railguns tear up if at range, due to there slower speed. if you can get close to railguns using cover or smoke your amrored units will tear the railguns up. add in height advatanges and experince as well as limted resources and time and you have an interesting dynamic which forces you to be out on the map in an ever changing battle.\n

reviewText:
Best RTS game I've played in a long time....

Just finished the single player campaign and I was impressed with this game. A pleasant surprise in the RTS genre! I've never played the Homeworld series, but I'm looking forward to playing those next (especially since the remastered editions came free with this).

Pros:
- Good unit selection with useful upgrade options carefully spread across the campaign
- Gameplay is challenging, but not overwhelming on 'normal difficulty'
- Interesting story with a climactic campaign
- Excellent graphics!
- Persistent resources/units makes you consider options more carefully before spending resources (which pays off in later scenarios)
- Good use of terrain/elevation
- Strategic map works well, which is good since you use it alot!

Cons:
- UI graphics were almost cartoonish in nature
- Aircraft AI needs some work (airplanes refuse to land and bombers can hover too long in target areas)
- Short Campaign (13 missions)

Also, desert missions looked great but would be nice to get away from the sand in any future DLC/expansions.

Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
Beautiful, story and narrative driven RTS.

This will be an ongoing, updated review, as I progress through the campaign.

CAMPAIGN

I've completed the first two missions and the tutorial so far. If you enjoy any of the following, I'd recommend the game based on my limited play:

Hard-sci fi narrative in RTS
A decent mix of tactics and strategy
Big Damn Trucks
The gameplay is much like the Homeworld series, streamlined, with an even greater emphasis on narrative. The game is gorgeous, and as mentioned, it's all about Big Damn Trucks.

This is a game that emphasizes strategy, not actions per minute. There's a nice combination of use of high ground, and unit special abilities to keep engagements fresh and allow specializations.

Cons
No docking animations for resource harvesters.
Few multiplayer maps, though BBI has stated they will be releasing more for free.

Keep in mind, this is a limited review until I finish more of the game, but so far, so good. I'll answer any questions I can.

reviewText:
Few hours into the game I can say that this is a must have for any Homeworld/RTS fan.

Graphics: 9/10 - I am not 100% happy with AA as it stands out with everything else being gorgeous.  Also occasional rapid turn animation of aircraft breaks the immersion.

Storyline 10/10 - so far I am loving it and it is a mix of original Homeworld with some elements of Battlestar Galactica in the desert setting (not to give out anything else)

Strategy 6/10 - at least early missions remind me of FF13 where you have pretty much one way with smallish side pockets.  Later on it opens up so gameplay is fun for an RTS.  Fairly limited resources and locations slightly limit your angles and the game doesn't feel as open as some of the other strategies out there but it is far away from being linear.

Over all: SOLID and fun gameplay and most of all bug free on release!

reviewText:
*Review has been updated below with regards to the Expedition Guide DLC*

At the time of writing this review, I have finished the Campaign on Normal difficulty and played a couple of skirmishes against Hard AI. Not tried Multiplayer yet or the Classic Campaign, may update review later if I try them. I played the Remastered Collection to completion and know the storyline of Cataclysm.

Pros:Fantastic visual design and art. Cutscenes are beautiful, artwork is beautiful, maps are usually beautiful, but occassionally not to the same standards of Sup Com 2 and similar titles.

Music is as good as the originals I'd say, definitely the same feel.

A few nice gameplay mechanics - such as acquiring new resources and artifacts from destroying wreck bulkheads, Carrier power systems, etc.Meh:Unit design is nice far out, kinda flat when zoomed in. This is an RTS though, you get most of the pretty factor focused away from the very expendable, very numerous units. Unit combat has a few visual bugs such as firing angles being messed up, and units hit by heavy weaponry sometimes do somersaults. Aircraft that are shot down will bounce as though they are made of rubber sometimes, but look very cool at least.

Couple of frame freezes in big battles but game ran smoothly for the most part.
Cons:Story is a bit barebones. I know Homeworld is very much about saying a lot with very little, but it seems like they only managed the very little part here; it comes close to capturing the feel of the story but misses the mark a bit. There's quite a few points where something is mentioned and never expanded on too. I think I might need to access that Expedition Guide DLC and see if it has the missing pieces there, but it feels like a lot of the additional lore and background for this game is simply not present. I'm also not really satifised with many of the wrecks present in the game; a couple of them especially feel like retconns, well, nearly all of them are iirc besides the Khar-Toba. A couple in particular are very questionable additions in my view though, and the ending itself was a little underwhelming. There's little characterisation in the game and little exposition.

Combat is very Rock, Paper, Scissors. A lot of the time it boils down to Does the Enemy have AA?". If not
recommended: use a Cruise Missile and ask the question again. If still yes
hoursPlayed: then send in the ground troops; otherwise
voteText: you'll be spending more money rebuilding troops than you spend on Cruise Missiles blowing everything to kingdom come. On Normal difficulty

column27: a lot of the time it requires finicky micromanagement to make proper use of it due to the lack of a Company of Heroes style click and drag movement control. column28: the default unit layout is abysmal and will lead only to defeat and despair.\n\nNo targetable subsystems on larger vehicles or the Carrier itself
column29: nor much unit variety beyond some simplistic balance where basically smaller direct combat unit is the counter to bigger indirect combat unit (if it survives long enough to reach it) which is counter to similar sized direct combat unit which is the counter to smaller sized direct combat unit. A decent rts game.
I recommend playing the solo on hardest difficulty otherwise it's just boring.
The game is very easy, what, you find it hard? Then stop playing the objectives and always think of getting the ressources first !!!
Sadly the solo isn't as epic as before, no huge fights with tons of huge ships. Just small engagements where your air units and tanks with support cruiser does the job. That's all you need to win the game.

Idc if it's in a 5$ dlc but this just feel empty for a war. I want destruction, pain, drama, real despair when you see the tide turning after a gruesome ambush.... Cause I just feel like I'm fighting with rocks and sticks at this point.

Having played this new game up to the review date, i have to say that is almost perfect out the box. The graphics are really great and give a whole atmosphere to the game, and finally get to learn that city that was seen in the original homeworld cutscene. The audio is really good, the sountrack is top notch and the battles are really something, compared to a few reviews i have read up about the durability of units and the lack of, there are some units that have lasted to the last mission from the first mission and there are other units that can take on a fair sized force by themselves with a support cruiser running back up for healing and defense.

The cons unfortunately are unit movements, in that when you click attack with a group of units, some of them do not respond on the first second or third attempt, they fire at the target if it's in range but they fail to move. You have to manually move them and then attack the target to get them to move.

Minor sound breaking specifically when you got a number of units parked against a rock, it can actually impact the performance by reducing frame rate as well, even with v-sync on there are some signs of tearing (everything on full and max and i have the rated computer for max settings without issue).

reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak has good RTS mechanics, solid controls, good graphics, and an interesting Campaign mode… which is rare for an RTS. Overall it’s a very enjoyable game that I wish I could feel safe recommending.

I’m giving this game a thumbs-up because I rate it to be above average, but not truly excellent. Unfortunately the game does have some caveats:
-	Campaign is truncated and felt underdeveloped (13 missions)
-	Voice acting, while passable, sounds phoned in at times
-	Multiplayer has only 5 maps at time of launch

It’s a good game, but the lack of content makes it a concern whether the longevity will be there. Bear that in mind before you go making your purchase. You can see my full review here: https://youtu.be/Q0uj9X5FqQM
