reviewText:
Fun RTS game at a time when there are virtually no new RTS games.

What I played: the single-player campaign all the way to the last mission, a few scirmish games against the AI and human opponents.

The good: the game feels like Homeworld. The music, art, unit design, UI all give the game that distinctive Homeworld look. Controlling units is a breeze and the UI is very clean and not very cluttered. Camera controls are also very smooth. There is a decent variety of units and you need to use most units effectively to achieve victory. There is no single massively over-powered unit that you can just build and win the game. Elevation and line of sight are done very well and are very important to winning each battle with minimal casualties. I found the story (a prequel to original Homeworld) to be a pretty good one, although anyone who has played the original Homeworld will know the story already. Although the entire game is set in a desert I loved it anyway because of how beautiful the game looks and there are still different desert types. It really made me think of Dune and how awesome it would be if Dune was remade using a modern engine.

The bad: the campaign is short, it took me about 8 hours to get to the last mission and there is no replayability value in the single-player campaign. It's not like Starcraft 2 campaigns with some branchine choices and big diversity of units. The voice acting in the campaign is not stellar and I didn't care much about the characters (heck, I don't think I can remember more than two or three names of in-game characters). The AI is terrible, it's not much of a challenge even on hard and it cheats aggressively to offer even this meager challenge. The scirmish mode is fun but it needs more than just 5 maps and two different game types (destroy the carrier and artifact hunt). Furthermore, there are only two factions and although their tech trees and units are slightly different, they don't really have that big a difference in play styles and tactics. There is a bit of color customization but otherwise you can't customize the look of your units.

Bottom line: this is a good RTS with a lot of potential, but at the moment there just isn't enough content in the game to warrant the price. I liked it a lot but I would recommend waiting until it's on sale.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm in love with this game. While you can find it strange, I will try to explain why.

I like this military drama story. Aside from that, I like how BBI used the Homeworld lore and added stuff to it. After a series of my recent disappointments like HotS (what they did to Kerrigan is abysmal if we take Brood Wars into account) and SW7 it is such a pleasure to watch the coherence with HW1&2 story.

Scenery is not as diverse as I wanted but it is okay for a desert planet. Unit design is sometimes cubic but I have no problem since it looks organic and intended: we have a really advanced and exotic race focused on hid and run tactics and slow but sure utilitarian design race. Which leads you to gameplay which is insanely addictive, watching the battlefield from a close distance can consume me for hours, excellent soundtrack adds to it and multiplayer... It is insane how many tactics you can use and how many builds you can choose since both races similar but plays different. Balance needs some tweaks but the core looks very promising now. The only thing I want to complain about is spawned enemy forces in campaign on higher difficulty, looks a bit cheap but who cares? It just intensifies the campaign :)

It has small bugs but nothing game breaking and almost all titles have them these days so I am used to it.

If you want a clone of Starcraft or Supreme Commander then this game is definitely not for you. And I am completely unsure about the e-sport part (since I personally don't care about it) so no input here. But if you can live with some rough edges and ready to invest into learning of this game's mechanics then you can find it just as fun as I am.

Crossing my fingers and hoping for a long after launch support.

reviewText:
Gameplay video + First Impressions below:

https://youtu.be/pO3okhiJ9CU

A key was provided to me early so I could check out the game before launch.
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak has the feeling of a great RTS.
I'm someone who doesn't play as many as I used too but even I found the controls and information on the screen very simple and easy to use. It provides you with great and accurate information and gives you nice quick control over it. Mixed with the voice overs in the campaign the whole experience really did give me a commander feel. Over looking the battle.
Terrain plays a big part of combat so I find myself pausing at the start of mission just to have a quick look round the battlefield for areas of higher terrain. Theres 3 terrain types low, medium and high. Any unit on a higher terrain will recieve a bonus over those on a lower terrain. Mix this with unit strengths such as the LAV being better against railgun units and you can really turn a few units into a dangerous force.
Combat looks great in the game LAV's being probably the most fun to witness as they circle and swurve there way around each other and the enemy gunning down anything near them.
The desert environment looks stunning and when you see a group of units moving with a cloud of dust behind them it gives a great atmosphere to the game.
So far though I haven't been able to play it anywhere near as much as it deserves I would highly recommend checking this game out. It performs well even on my not so great system and it plays beautiful. A great RTS game in my opinion and one I'm looking forward to playing even more of.

voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you thought Homeworld could not remain true to the original if it wasn't set in space, you were thankfully mistaken.

Having played the original Homeworlds years ago, like many I looked at them with rose tinted glasses. But In prearatin for Deserts of Kharak I started up homeworld one, and I have to say, it still holds up. It delivers an atmosphere and an experience of play oonly great games manage. And homeworld shipbreakers Manages both.

The aeasthetics are not only sunningly beautiful, but they remain true to the original. Be warned though performance is lower than expected from such a game.

The sound design, a known high point of the series also does not disappoint. Not only are the tunes perfectly in sinc with the action and visuals, but the constant unitchatter prowides an undeniable sense of presence. And I haven't heard a piece of repeated dialog for three hours into the game.

Mechanically, this is a competent RTS. It brings no great innovation, but what it does it does well. The small number of units may initially seem a drawback, but I've never found myself looking for any functionality that wasn't present in some way. Pathing appears good, and units respond well to orders. The game is set on a series of hard-counters, andthey are mercylessly enforced. So if that's not your thing stay away from it.

The multiplayer I didn't explore much, so I can't provide criticism.

TL.DR.:

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a game true to it's predecessors. Stunning visuals and superb sound-design support a competent but non-innovative story driven RTS with prominent hard-counter mechanics.

reviewText:
TLDR;

-Worth the price tag
-Could have been a bit more polished
-Not much content (Only a few multiplayer maps)
-Solid game overall

Not going to lie, the AI is dumb, the campaign is very easy. I chose normal difficulty on my first playthrough, and never even came close to losing a mission. On my second playthrough, I chose the harder 'classic' difficulty, and only lost once, (Due to my own stupidity, not the difficulty of the mission).

The storyline is nice, although the campaign feels quite short, and ends on a rather dull note, in my opinion at least. And from the outset, you are told the objective in the desert will lead to the salvation of the Kushun people, but why? How do they know this? Just seems like strange dialogue to have so early in the game when they aren't even sure what they are going to find out there in the desert.

I found the campaign to be nicely immersive however, and it seems a lot of thought and development has gone into the technology and engineering of the units, for how a civilization living on a desert planet would design their vehicles and such.

The camera is somewhat annoying as well, much of the time I found it very claustrophobic outside of the sensors manager (The blue map you get when you hit spacebar), and there isn't a lot of range to zoom in and out, it is capped at a very low altitude. Unit selection is kind of a pain too, there is no military-priority selection, so dragging a big box around everything is only going to select everything.

Pathfinding AI is quite bad too, on my second playthrough I tried building a lot of cruisers to form a carrier battlegroup, but most of them wouldn't follow my carrier properly, and would sit still trying to engage an enemy unit that wasn't within their line of sight.

There are no formation controls as far as I can see, and no proper positioning for units in formations, when told to guard/escort your carrier, all the utility units place themselves on the outside of the formation (where they will get killed by the first unit that attacks you), instead of hugging close to the carrier like you would expect.

There isn't a lot of content either, I seem to remember there being a much bigger variety of units in the other HW games, in this game you have;
A resource collector
Light attack vehicle (Scissors)
Armoured Assault Vehicle (Rock)
Railgun (Paper)
Baserunner (minelayer)
4 x kinds of cruisers
A fighter
A bomber

That is it, so overall it is a very simple game, there aren't different kinds of frigates or corvettes like we had in the other games. But this is partially compensated for by your carrier (mothership) which can shunt power and be used offensively, defensively, or as a support ship.

There are only 5 multiplayer maps too, which is a shame because it could really use the variety. I am presuming they will bring out more DLC to rectify this (Which we will have to pay for).

But overall, I am happy with my purchase, if you like homeworld, you will probably like this. If you aren't familiar with homeworld, I would probably just stick with the remastered collection, at least acquiant yourself with it before buying this one, because the story of this game really depends on your knowledge of the other games.

reviewText:
Homeworld, with all that flavor of space epicness. Add some beautiful Ground Control to make it just more terrain-related and season with Dune. Shake it well and the gorgeous result is Deserts of Kharak.
The 10-hour campaign is fantastic. The musics, sound effects, voices, animations are top-notch.
It's not a perfect game, but it's one of the best RTS out there. The game is faster than Homeworld 1 and 2 and units are definitely more fragile. During the campaign I missed that pause between skirmishes and battles that allows you to relax and appreciate each single unit deployed on the battlefield (the enemy keeps threading a lot and you have to focus on both strategy and micro management to keep your fleet alive).

Anyway, RTS players and Sci-Fi fan: you must try this game. That's an order!
WE DEFINITELY NEED HOMEWORLD 3.

reviewText: It's the videogame equivalent of The Force Awakens. Apparently, the way to revive an old, beloved franchise is to stick close to the originals' plot, sometimes lifting stuff beat-for-beat, and to focus mainly on recapturing the atmosphere. DoK is engineered to make players draw parallels to Homeworld: it has a somber mood, slow pacing, a lone mothership and its crew, a long, harrowing journey over enemy territory, a desperate quest that will make or break an entire civilization, ominous mystical overtones, a fantastic middle-eastern soundtrack, units and resources carrying over from previous missions, rock-paper-scissors balancing that makes units useless most of the time and completely overpowered when used against the right targets at the right distance with the right support, etc. etc.\n\nIt also has enough new stuff (elevation, air units, carrier upgrades and power-shunting) to not qualify as a retread, which is more than can be said of Homeworld 2 and Cataclysm. Honestly, as much as the desert setting is getting flack, I don't think a fourth Homeworld game set in space with the same old units would really have energized the franchise. And I'm happy we're getting a window into Kharakid society again, since Homeworld 1 had that wonderful Historical and Technical Briefing booklet that greatly expanded the lore of Kharak and its various kiithid... and then did away with the planet and its people in the first few minutes of the campaign.

reviewText:
Because i detest long text reviews myself, here i will keep as short as i possibly can. Also, i didnt touch multiplayer so keep that in mind. The credits rolled for me 10 mins prior to writing this.

Veterans of the series who have played all the previous games quite a bit, will find even the hardest difficulties too easy. That isnt a fault of the game, but rather the fact that you know more than most, making the game not balanced for you.

Veterans such as myself will adore this game and be sad when the relatively short (its long enough, but you kinda want more after the credits roll), the sounds, visuals, art style, cinematics and emotion are all amazing. The gameplay is 100% Homeworld. Only, set on a planet. At one point in the campaign, you will be annoyed at a plot twist, considering previous story elements. No spoilers.

As for newbies, you only have to learn the basics of finite resources, two types of resources, the value of different vehicles and general functionality. Once you have gained that, it will become easy to master.

If you manage to figure out the true objective of each mission (that is never made obvious) and end up making the latter half of the game effortless, you know you have discovered exactly how the original Homeworld games worked. :P

reviewText:
I just finished the game on the highest setting, Classic Difficulty (the name of which amuses me, due to the fact that the 'classic' game only had one difficulty...really freaking hard). The journey took me 12 hours of gameplay at this point. I loved the ambient music of the game, and am seriously considering buying the soundtrack. Now, to put it simply here are my views.

Pros:
Extremely thematic music.
It's a desert, but they keep the terrain interesting.
Each unit has its uses, and they keep the number small enough that you don't wonder why they put units in.
I've always loved persistent fleets, and the veterancy makes it even better.
Excellent story, and quite good voice-acting as well.
The power shunt system for your carrier is amazing.

Cons:
It was too easy to beat on the main difficulty. Your best bet is to get as many resources as you can to build a fleet, and then alpha-strike the main objective in a single massive attack to finish things. Otherwise you just get killed by the death of a thousand cuts due to your opponent not needing resources to produce vehicles.
The AI is less than stellar, but makes up for it due to campaign scripting.
Leaves lots of questions unanswered. Admittedly, primarily because they were answered in the other Homeworld games, but still.
Skirmish maps are lacking in number.

Overall:
I recommend the game to Homeworld enthusiasts. I recommend others wait for it to go on sale. Unless modding tools come out for it, at which point this is ripe for modders to turn it into something absolutely amazing.

reviewText:
If you are a Homeworld fan then you will definetly not be left wanting.

When I heard they were bringing out a prequel to the amazing homeworld series I was already expecting it to be subpar because Relic wasn't producing it. Thankfully this was the time that I was 1000000% wrong (yes I know 100% is max but bugger off)

Now for those of you who are looking at this game and you love your strategy games believe me when I say this.

BUY THIS GAME.

The eye for detail in this game is amazing especially when it comes to line of sight, you can actually use sand dunes to block line of site and set up ambushes.

One tip, always try to hold the highground it will make your like that much easier.

Ok the cons, yes all games have them and so does Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak.

It has crashed on me a number of times while playing it, though an update to fix alot of the crashing problems was released the following day.

The biggest con of all though is that there is an end to the game, I could play this game continuously but I just finished the campaign and I need more. When is the next one coming out.

So overall for a game that was released yesterday, with one or two little problems which are being dealt with,
BUY THIS GAME already.

I think the game is a little overpriced right now; I got it because on preorder it came with the old homeworld games. If you bought the remaster on the steam sale you automatically get 20% off this game so that's an equivalent deal.

Game runs decently well, even on ultra settings (i5/970) but in MP you probably want to play at lower settings for FPS. I like how you can press ALT to toggle sensor range / fog of war area, just try it because I'm not great at explaining it.

I'll update when I play some more campaign and MP matches.

reviewText:
The Homeworld saga has a great following, and this title shows great promise in delivering a prequel worthy of a place in that story. However, it is not quite there yet. With a nearly broken MP functionality and balancing issues it's proven to be challenging to like this game as much as I want to. It has all the attributes of a Homeworld title yet it seems obvious the game needed more gameplay tweaks and balancing done before release, it feels rushed.

- In MP the Coalition player is currently unable to research a bigger fleet meaning playing that faction is not an option until the (glaringly obvious) issue is addressed in a patch.
- The main campaign feels too scripted, the player is left with little tactical options as there is no time nor room for it and as far as strategy goes it comes down to two things only, aquiring resources and meeting mission goals and that's it. So one is left with the impression that there is only one way to successfully play through the campaign.
- The pace of the game is hectic and on par with your typical RTS style game of today, maybe a little faster even, which is not what the Homeworld franchise became known for. Forget spending time building up a fleet and plan your attack, there is no time, and either you have Cruisers or you don't. Once you have lost the heavies they tend to be gone for the rest of the game since the resources simply aren't available to replace them. Which leaves you with one remaining option, to use your Carrier as a battlewagon. You can get away with that, until later in the game and then you'll need to start over.

I do recommend the game, simply because of the undeniable potential which is there. Yet if you don't intend to get frustrated playing through a unfinished campaign and waiting for the patching needed then there's not much to it, wait for the update. Forget MP until the fleet issue is fixed and more maps are made available.

reviewText:
I recommend it. There's definitely some bad to it, but it's very solid. 8/10

I am a long time RTS player and as far as game mechanics go, this game is in my top 5.
Visually/atmospherically: This game is number 1. The music, the art, the effects, the feel, all of it are amazing.

Currently, the game loses a point for the multiplayer having too few maps. There are 13 story missions and I don't see how they couldn't reuse or rework story mission maps into skirmish maps. Perhaps that will happen later. Or even better, we will get player made ones.

The game also loses a point for some of the vehicle balance. LAV's are worthless. There is no point in having them except maybe as cannon fodder. You can run around with 4-5 AAV's, 4-5Rail guns, and 3-4 Missile AAV's and never get touched with a support cruiser in tow.

All in all, if this is what I can expect from BBI, I hope they continue the homeworld franchise. Very impressed. If you're a fan, you will love this.

reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak is a love letter to both Homeworld games that came before it.  A beautiful re-imagining of the original games, modernized similar to the HD re-releases Gearbox put out earlier this year.  From its unique art style, rousing music, to its masterful balance of your typical rock paper scissor mechanics found in most RTS games, its about as polished and well made as any RTS game released in the last decade.

The story, while a bit light, which is usual for games in this genre, still manages to hit the right notes and provide some great Sci Fi story telling.  It provides a thrilling backstory to the Homeworld universe, with unique a varied mission objectives.  I didn't mind the desert environments, each map feeling hand crafted.

If I had any complaints, it was the length of the campaign.  Similar to the previous homeworlds, it only had 13 missions in total.  There were several late game units that I didn't feel I had time to learn how to use, or bring to bare in an exciting way against my enemies.  Aircraft can also feel like an I win" button for several early mission
date: but are balanced later in the game when anti air vehicles become more prevalent.\n\nThe land carrier
recommended: which takes the place of the mother-ship from previous games
hoursPlayed: feels a bit too strong.  I did enjoy the overhead mechanics which had me switching between systems
voteText: but with a few repair vehicles near by I never felt it was at threat.\n\nOver all
helpfulPercent: one of the best RTS games I've played in years.  More grand strategy
votesHelpful: then your typical Star Craft twitch / micromanagement play style.\n\nI'm really hoping they continue the Homeworld series."

reviewText:
I'm recommending this game, but it's not a resounding recommendation.

The game is reasonably good.  The story is really interesting.  For all you Homeworld fans, it gives you all sorts of background info on the Unification of Kharak and the discovery of the Core.  The story is mostly told through personal diary logs,  in-game video cuts and simple artistic cut scenes.  It's all good stuff and it all adds to the sense of loneliness and desperation Homeworld fans would be familiar with.  For non-Homeworld fans, you're not really missing anything from not having played those games.  You'll get right into it and know what's going on.

The game also looks great.  There's not a ton of color or detail in the maps, but that was likely intentional to a degree so that the devs could convey the vastness and emptiness of the Desert.  The units, however, look great, as do their weapon particles and physics.  Watching your units traverse the sands (bobbing up and down as you hit bumps, cresting dunes and sliding down) makes it obvious how much effort Gearbox put into this type of immersion.

Getting into the gameplay itself, first impressions are really good.  Units are responsive, there's a lot of rock-paper-scissors going on and the units move fast enough and the weapons are powerful enough that you really have a lot to keep track of and do.  The battles themselves are exciting to watch too.  Units swarm around each other, artillery barrages throw up huge clouds of dust, and weapons all make satisfying BOOMS and impacts.  I had a great time playing the campaign and even on Normal difficulty there were quite a few tense moments.  I BARELY won the final mission, with my carrier within 10% health on a last ditch all-in attack to finish the objective.

Where I think this game lacked for me is in content.  Ultimately, I don't think there's enough there to justify the price tag.  The campaign was way too short.  I finished it in about 8-10 hours and while it was good, I expected it to be a lot longer.  This was disappointing.

Additionally, I don't see a large multiplayer community thriving around the game either.  I'd love if that weren't the case, but there doesn't seem to be enough content, unit variety or balance to encourage anything long term.  There's a TINY number of multiplayer maps and they're fairly small.  Like Homeworld, skirmishing and resource harrassment are a huge part of how the game plays out.  Unlike Homeworld, however, full scale engagements don't last very long.  Airstikes and artillery can make short work of large numbers of units and it really throws off the pacing of the game.  This might be addressed in balancing but personally it felt to me like the game, while polished and fun, was trimmed down more than it should be in terms of features and variety.

Honestly, I enjoyed it.  I don't regret buying it but at the same time I'm not thrilled with the purchase.  It's likely to be another game that entertained me briefly but that I'll ultimately forget about.

reviewText:
A prequel to the award-winning Homeworld series, Deserts of Kharak puts the player in charge of the Kapisi; a half kilometer-long landcarrier on a mission to retrieve a curious artifact deep in enemy territory.

At your disposal is a small, albeit adaptable, range of vehicles capable of traversing the dunes with ease.

While I'm not that deep into the Homeworld lore I still recommend this game as it is simply awesome; every single detail, from the realistic physics to the radio chatter, provides the dead desert environment with a surprising amount of life.

Meanwhile the score builds up an incredible atmosphere as you travel deeper into uncharted areas.

For a game set on a desert planet it is absolutely gorgeous visually as vehicles kick up dust, projectiles scorch the sand and as missiles cause realistic explosions.

All in all this is definietly worth the buy, especially if you are fan of Homeworld.

Good work BBI, I never doubted you for a second.

reviewText: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a great tactical RTS with all the gorgeous aesthetics and atmosphere of the original series. It tells a beautiful prequel story with great art, excellent mission design and wonderful music. Its a classic resurrected, capable to live up to twelve years of expectations, even though it's set on a planet. The single player campaign is a bit short, but the game worth every minute.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the original homeworld series, 1, 2 and Cataclysm. So when Homeworld remastered got released last year, I spent a huge amount of time working my way through the missions and the skirmish mode.
When I found out that Shipbreakers wasn't far off I took the decision to stop playing and move onto something else , and a day after it was released as Deserts of Kharak I have already completed the games campaign in the easy mode.

So what does this game have to offer?
If you are a fan of the RTS games like C&C or Supreme Commander then this is a must for you, even if you didnt like the original homeworld games.
The ground orientated combat is merged seemlessly with homeworlds ambiance and storytelling as you guide an expidition though the war torn banded desert on the hunt for an artifact that will save your race.

Yup - you guessed it if you didnt already know, this is a prequel and you ultimatley find the Khar-Toba, which would lead onto the Guidestone, and onto Homeworld 1...

What doesnt this game have?
Well, I'd like to say a long story, its only 13 missions long which was a bit of a disapointment, i would have liked to have played a bit longer.
Also the game seems to end each mission very quickly not allowing you to harvest the local resources and find artifacts that remain. Surely a mission like this, that would be a key focus. Similar to homeworld 1.
Also there are only a handful of skirmish maps, so I am hoping the developers release some FREE DLC soon with added maps, maybe some of the missions converted into skirmish maps as each mission map was excellently crafted.

All-in-all this for homeworld fans and other RTS fans alike, this game is a must.
But remember if like me you have an older system to turn the graphics down before you launch into the campaign as its difficult to change the settings unless if you use the main menu options pannel. There is one mission in particular that is a graphics hog.

So why did i metion that I stopped playing the remastered games?
I had a feeling that the last scene in the last mission would get me wanting to play the other games again.
And I wasnt dissapointed when I heard something familiar in the last cutscene. Im looking forward to playing homeworld 1 again after this. And I hope we see more new homeworld coming soon!

reviewText:
Its a mixed bag that to me smells of publisher interference, I'll explain.

- The core gameplay is there but it lacks the finesse of previous Homeworld games such that battles become more one of attrition than playing smart.

- The look and feel is Homeworld even though its not in space, BBI have done a good job there and the story telling works well... Until the end where it stops far far too short? If you aren't into Homeworld you are going to struggle with the plot imho because the ending isn't explained well at all almost as if they didn't want to fully cross over into HW1 territory just yet.

- Had a go at MP with a friend and soon discovered an OP early game strategy which basically blows MP out the water for now.

In summary then the basic game is there and is solid but to me it feels like I'm playing 1/2 a game (and suspect the 2nd half is on its way in 1yr time). Its almost like Gearbox is testing the market to see if Homeworld 2016" can work and opted for a shortened/summarised version.

Would I recommend it? Yes I would
date: I wouldn't call it 9/10 material though it clearly had the potential if it was allowed to mature. Overall BBI did a good job and really their fault is in not releasing what I would call a complete and well-rounded game but what they have done they have done well. To draw an analogy a little like Elite Dangerous where what was done was good but there needs to be more for it to work properly for the player/User Experience."

reviewText:
This is an excellent and well designed RTS game, which is stays true to the original series in terms of gameplay and overall feeling, despite all action comes down from space to the ground.

Pros:

- 10-12 hours long singleplayer campaign with various missions and interesting story.
- Outsanding art design. Just the sight of your fleet moving through desert at night can give you an aesthetic enjoyment.
- Sound effects, music and units voice overs are 10/10.
- On highest setting game looks very good and runs smooth on my 2014's hardware.
- Quite balanced and fun gameplay in the best traditions of Homeworld series. There are two faction which looks similar to each other at first, but they have different strategies and tactics to dominate the desert battlefield. This reminds me Hiigarans and Vaygr from Homeworld 2, though the Coalition and Gaalsiens have even more differences.

Cons:

- Just a five maps for skirmish and multiplayer. Developers already promissed more as free updates.
- Very few option settings for skirmish and MP
- Limping Gaalsien AI in skirmish. The Coalition one is much more aggressive even on easy, but still suffers from lack of cunning" and variety of tactics.
- There is no way to change hotkeys for now.

Despite its minor and temporal flaws I can recommend this game to anyone who is looking for good singleplayer experience in RTS. Multiplayer is somewhat lacking for now
date: but I'm sure things will be fixed quite soon and more content will be added."

reviewText:
Loved playing this game, very beautiful scenery, nice units, good story. Definitely worth buying and playing. Great mechnic of prebuilt armies for each campaign map in case you got wiped out on the map before.

Nagatives:

1. Skirmish Beats Artillery
2. Armour beats Skimish
3. Artillery beats Armour (and Cruisers)

Than you have Cruisers:
1. Support Cruiser (Repairs)
2. Armoured Cruiser
3. Artillery

Add to that some planes which basically all do the same thing.

It would be great if, branching out from the series, base mechanics were introduced, further it would also be good to have some different biomes.

reviewText:
I'm recommending this game, but it's not a resounding recommendation.

The game is reasonably good.  The story is really interesting.  For all you Homeworld fans, it gives you all sorts of background info on the Unification of Kharak and the discovery of the Core.  The story is mostly told through personal diary logs,  in-game video cuts and simple artistic cut scenes.  It's all good stuff and it all adds to the sense of loneliness and desperation Homeworld fans would be familiar with.  For non-Homeworld fans, you're not really missing anything from not having played those games.  You'll get right into it and know what's going on.

The game also looks great.  There's not a ton of color or detail in the maps, but that was likely intentional to a degree so that the devs could convey the vastness and emptiness of the Desert.  The units, however, look great, as do their weapon particles and physics.  Watching your units traverse the sands (bobbing up and down as you hit bumps, cresting dunes and sliding down) makes it obvious how much effort Gearbox put into this type of immersion.

Getting into the gameplay itself, first impressions are really good.  Units are responsive, there's a lot of rock-paper-scissors going on and the units move fast enough and the weapons are powerful enough that you really have a lot to keep track of and do.  The battles themselves are exciting to watch too.  Units swarm around each other, artillery barrages throw up huge clouds of dust, and weapons all make satisfying BOOMS and impacts.  I had a great time playing the campaign and even on Normal difficulty there were quite a few tense moments.  I BARELY won the final mission, with my carrier within 10% health on a last ditch all-in attack to finish the objective.

Where I think this game lacked for me is in content.  Ultimately, I don't think there's enough there to justify the price tag.  The campaign was way too short.  I finished it in about 8-10 hours and while it was good, I expected it to be a lot longer.  This was disappointing.

Additionally, I don't see a large multiplayer community thriving around the game either.  I'd love if that weren't the case, but there doesn't seem to be enough content, unit variety or balance to encourage anything long term.  There's a TINY number of multiplayer maps and they're fairly small.  Like Homeworld, skirmishing and resource harrassment are a huge part of how the game plays out.  Unlike Homeworld, however, full scale engagements don't last very long.  Airstikes and artillery can make short work of large numbers of units and it really throws off the pacing of the game.  This might be addressed in balancing but personally it felt to me like the game, while polished and fun, was trimmed down more than it should be in terms of features and variety.

Honestly, I enjoyed it.  I don't regret buying it but at the same time I'm not thrilled with the purchase.  It's likely to be another game that entertained me briefly but that I'll ultimately forget about.

reviewText: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is the prequel to one of the most highly acclaimed real-time strategy games of all time and it comes from some of the original developers and their new studio Blackbird Interactive. Although it started off its life as more of a spiritual successor, Gearbox acquired the developer, allowing Blackbird to use the Homeworld IP and it doesn't feel slapped on. Every part of the product, from the gameplay to the presentation, is oozing with original Homeworld flavor, with the exception, of course, of 3D movement. For more information, check out the  VIDEO REVIEW:	 https://youtu.be/oOpkWlbFOVI

reviewText:
*EDIT* The game gets better the longer you play it and the multiplayer is very good despite being barebones. I have upped my non-preorder score. I utimately feel as though I rewarded for rolling the dice and buying a game without reading any reviews. After being burned hard by Gearbox for Aliens: Colonial Marines, the company has regained my loyalty. Thanks Gearbox and Blackbird Interactive.

Homeworld​: Deserts of Kharak is the best RTS game since StarCraft 2. Although at $49.99 it's a tough value proposition. As an owner of the Homeworld: Remastered Collection I got 20% off and an interactive encyclopedia worth $5.99. I'm a little miffed that the soundtrack was not included, $7.99, and you need to have the game to download it (DLC model). But hey I like pre-order bonuses.

The game is stripped down to a refined RTS core and the unit count represents that. Not quite MOBA simplified, but complex enough not to scare that crowd away. You've got a decent papers, rocks, scissors interplay going and a dedicated airstrike platform, your cruiser. If I compared the game to chess, the cruiser would be a queen/king combo. Lose it, you're dead. Yet properly upgraded it will wreck havoc and coordinated airstrikes with ground forces properly erases the opposition from the map, no matter how overwhelming. Cue me whooping like a falcon diving for the kill and a meal.

I really like the cover system where elevation actively blocks direct fire and units firing from higher positions get a damage bonus which makes sense for a vehicle based RTS. Armored vehicles are weakest at their rear and turrets in true Company of Heroes fashion (if you like RTS play CoH). I play the game mostly from the satellite view since I like the interface and how informative it is. Relic and employees that used to work for that Canadian studio have the best audio guys in the business. Unit chatter is appropriately stoic with ironic wit (which I like), but most importantly provides valuable information. If a unit is being attacked instead of getting a ping saying Yo dude. Your dudes are under attack. Pay attention!"

The intel officer or unit itself will simply say "Strike craft taking effective fire." Unit chatter can get layered
date: but the design is genius. It's almost like listening to sports on the radio and being able to picture the battle unfolding.\n\nIf I had anything negative to say it'd probably be that the game feels too basic at times
recommended: sometimes too slow for its own good
hoursPlayed: and has inconsistent performance. I also encountered a game breaking bug. Not quite Total War Rome 2's caliber where I actually rage quitted in frustration
voteText: but the devs were responsive and helpful. The game uses a lot of scripted sequences so I tend to finish secondary objective out of fear of breaking the primary ones.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: a great purchase. 9/10 at $39.99 with pre-order bonus and discount. Wait for a steam sale and if you like RTS you'll fall in love with the game and plus the bugs will be ironed out.\n\n8.5/10 at $49.99 without expedition guide DLC. The game has quite the solid foundation and will post-release love it should get some wings and take flight. Like the Kushan people fleeing their dying planet where desert erosion slowly erases top soil. No top soil
votesHelpful: no food. No food... well that's a terrible way to go if you have water and that's in short supply too."

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the original homeworld series, 1, 2 and Cataclysm. So when Homeworld remastered got released last year, I spent a huge amount of time working my way through the missions and the skirmish mode.
When I found out that Shipbreakers wasn't far off I took the decision to stop playing and move onto something else , and a day after it was released as Deserts of Kharak I have already completed the games campaign in the easy mode.

So what does this game have to offer?
If you are a fan of the RTS games like C&C or Supreme Commander then this is a must for you, even if you didnt like the original homeworld games.
The ground orientated combat is merged seemlessly with homeworlds ambiance and storytelling as you guide an expidition though the war torn banded desert on the hunt for an artifact that will save your race.

Yup - you guessed it if you didnt already know, this is a prequel and you ultimatley find the Khar-Toba, which would lead onto the Guidestone, and onto Homeworld 1...

What doesnt this game have?
Well, I'd like to say a long story, its only 13 missions long which was a bit of a disapointment, i would have liked to have played a bit longer.
Also the game seems to end each mission very quickly not allowing you to harvest the local resources and find artifacts that remain. Surely a mission like this, that would be a key focus. Similar to homeworld 1.
Also there are only a handful of skirmish maps, so I am hoping the developers release some FREE DLC soon with added maps, maybe some of the missions converted into skirmish maps as each mission map was excellently crafted.

All-in-all this for homeworld fans and other RTS fans alike, this game is a must.
But remember if like me you have an older system to turn the graphics down before you launch into the campaign as its difficult to change the settings unless if you use the main menu options pannel. There is one mission in particular that is a graphics hog.

So why did i metion that I stopped playing the remastered games?
I had a feeling that the last scene in the last mission would get me wanting to play the other games again.
And I wasnt dissapointed when I heard something familiar in the last cutscene. Im looking forward to playing homeworld 1 again after this. And I hope we see more new homeworld coming soon!

reviewText:
I recommend it. There's definitely some bad to it, but it's very solid. 8/10

I am a long time RTS player and as far as game mechanics go, this game is in my top 5.
Visually/atmospherically: This game is number 1. The music, the art, the effects, the feel, all of it are amazing.

Currently, the game loses a point for the multiplayer having too few maps. There are 13 story missions and I don't see how they couldn't reuse or rework story mission maps into skirmish maps. Perhaps that will happen later. Or even better, we will get player made ones.

The game also loses a point for some of the vehicle balance. LAV's are worthless. There is no point in having them except maybe as cannon fodder. You can run around with 4-5 AAV's, 4-5Rail guns, and 3-4 Missile AAV's and never get touched with a support cruiser in tow.

All in all, if this is what I can expect from BBI, I hope they continue the homeworld franchise. Very impressed. If you're a fan, you will love this.

reviewText:
Deserts of Kharak is a love letter to both Homeworld games that came before it.  A beautiful re-imagining of the original games, modernized similar to the HD re-releases Gearbox put out earlier this year.  From its unique art style, rousing music, to its masterful balance of your typical rock paper scissor mechanics found in most RTS games, its about as polished and well made as any RTS game released in the last decade.

The story, while a bit light, which is usual for games in this genre, still manages to hit the right notes and provide some great Sci Fi story telling.  It provides a thrilling backstory to the Homeworld universe, with unique a varied mission objectives.  I didn't mind the desert environments, each map feeling hand crafted.

If I had any complaints, it was the length of the campaign.  Similar to the previous homeworlds, it only had 13 missions in total.  There were several late game units that I didn't feel I had time to learn how to use, or bring to bare in an exciting way against my enemies.  Aircraft can also feel like an I win" button for several early mission
date: but are balanced later in the game when anti air vehicles become more prevalent.\n\nThe land carrier
recommended: which takes the place of the mother-ship from previous games
hoursPlayed: feels a bit too strong.  I did enjoy the overhead mechanics which had me switching between systems
voteText: but with a few repair vehicles near by I never felt it was at threat.\n\nOver all
helpfulPercent: one of the best RTS games I've played in years.  More grand strategy
votesHelpful: then your typical Star Craft twitch / micromanagement play style.\n\nI'm really hoping they continue the Homeworld series."

reviewText: Well, it's another Homeworld game, and one deserving of the name.\n\nThe gameplay is great, with hints of Supreme Commander in there and other influences while obviously maintaining that Homeworldy feel. The campaign does a good job (a couple bugs here and there, but nothing that can't be overcome or hopefully patched soon) of showing what the beginning of the Homeworld journey was like. Other game modes show the variety of tweaks and new gameplay features put in to make this game unique. It certainly isn't just Homeworld 1&2 compressed to 2D, but something quite interesting in itself.

reviewText: Deserts of Kharak, while good, is somewhat difficult to recommend at its current price. The campaign, while quite good for the most part, has a frustrating last mission/ending (although maybe they assume most who are playing have also played the first Homeworld game, which takes place soon afterward) and fewer missions than I would've liked. The art style is terrific, although certain things, like the textures, are a little muddy (it also drops a lot of frames in parts where I feel it shouldn't; I have a GTX 970 with an i7 3.5 Ghz CPU and 8 Gigs of DDR3). I have yet to try multiplayer, but there only appears to be 5 maps, which for an RTS in 2016 is too low. The game itself alot fun to play, with cool unit design, old school RTS gameplay and some pretty unique game mechanics. The vehicle physics are particularly impressive, with dune buggies jumping and tumbling all over the place. There are only two factions in the game, as has always been the case with the Homeworld franchise, which didn't bother me as much as it might others. There aren't a WHOLE lot of units, but there are tons of upgrades that offer them a great deal of flexibility. I am hoping that Black Bird Interactive will add more multiplayer maps soon, as I believe that interest in this game will die pretty quickly with only the 5 available (which would be a huge shame).  In short, if this game were even $10.00 cheaper I wouldn't hesitate recommending it to anyone, but at its current price I suggest you check out gameplay videos and get a feeling for it. If the asking price doesn't scare you away and you like supporting small, new and promising development studios (or just the Homeworld franchise), you'll get plenty of RTS bang out of your buck from DoK.

reviewText:
A prequel to the award-winning Homeworld series, Deserts of Kharak puts the player in charge of the Kapisi; a half kilometer-long landcarrier on a mission to retrieve a curious artifact deep in enemy territory.

At your disposal is a small, albeit adaptable, range of vehicles capable of traversing the dunes with ease.

While I'm not that deep into the Homeworld lore I still recommend this game as it is simply awesome; every single detail, from the realistic physics to the radio chatter, provides the dead desert environment with a surprising amount of life.

Meanwhile the score builds up an incredible atmosphere as you travel deeper into uncharted areas.

For a game set on a desert planet it is absolutely gorgeous visually as vehicles kick up dust, projectiles scorch the sand and as missiles cause realistic explosions.

All in all this is definietly worth the buy, especially if you are fan of Homeworld.

Good work BBI, I never doubted you for a second.

reviewText:
TLDR;

-Worth the price tag
-Could have been a bit more polished
-Not much content (Only a few multiplayer maps)
-Solid game overall

Not going to lie, the AI is dumb, the campaign is very easy. I chose normal difficulty on my first playthrough, and never even came close to losing a mission. On my second playthrough, I chose the harder 'classic' difficulty, and only lost once, (Due to my own stupidity, not the difficulty of the mission).

The storyline is nice, although the campaign feels quite short, and ends on a rather dull note, in my opinion at least. And from the outset, you are told the objective in the desert will lead to the salvation of the Kushun people, but why? How do they know this? Just seems like strange dialogue to have so early in the game when they aren't even sure what they are going to find out there in the desert.

I found the campaign to be nicely immersive however, and it seems a lot of thought and development has gone into the technology and engineering of the units, for how a civilization living on a desert planet would design their vehicles and such.

The camera is somewhat annoying as well, much of the time I found it very claustrophobic outside of the sensors manager (The blue map you get when you hit spacebar), and there isn't a lot of range to zoom in and out, it is capped at a very low altitude. Unit selection is kind of a pain too, there is no military-priority selection, so dragging a big box around everything is only going to select everything.

Pathfinding AI is quite bad too, on my second playthrough I tried building a lot of cruisers to form a carrier battlegroup, but most of them wouldn't follow my carrier properly, and would sit still trying to engage an enemy unit that wasn't within their line of sight.

There are no formation controls as far as I can see, and no proper positioning for units in formations, when told to guard/escort your carrier, all the utility units place themselves on the outside of the formation (where they will get killed by the first unit that attacks you), instead of hugging close to the carrier like you would expect.

There isn't a lot of content either, I seem to remember there being a much bigger variety of units in the other HW games, in this game you have;
A resource collector
Light attack vehicle (Scissors)
Armoured Assault Vehicle (Rock)
Railgun (Paper)
Baserunner (minelayer)
4 x kinds of cruisers
A fighter
A bomber

That is it, so overall it is a very simple game, there aren't different kinds of frigates or corvettes like we had in the other games. But this is partially compensated for by your carrier (mothership) which can shunt power and be used offensively, defensively, or as a support ship.

There are only 5 multiplayer maps too, which is a shame because it could really use the variety. I am presuming they will bring out more DLC to rectify this (Which we will have to pay for).

But overall, I am happy with my purchase, if you like homeworld, you will probably like this. If you aren't familiar with homeworld, I would probably just stick with the remastered collection, at least acquiant yourself with it before buying this one, because the story of this game really depends on your knowledge of the other games.

reviewText: This was a great pre-quel to a Real Time Strategy game that revolutionized an industry. The dynamics of playing on land rather then space but still keeping the feel of the original game are observed.  The story campaign is short, sweet, and full of drama and a real plot unlike most stories.  The gameplay is quick, many units counter other units,  geography is key as height gives you an advantage when shooting down on your oppenent. The graphics are beauitul the gameplay is great. Its one of the better Real Time Strategy games out there. Iv'e played over a dozen hours on Multiplayer they are always fun experiences. The only badside is lack of maps but the developers are going to release more soon.\n\nA lot of the issues brought up by people are being observed by the Developeres and they are going to be releasing patches with updates, new Maps, Replay ability and more. I believe they wanted to test the waters and make a great gameplay and later on when they had the resources give the game the much needed polishing it needs to be an outstanding Real Time Strategy game.

reviewText:
Homeworld, with all that flavor of space epicness. Add some beautiful Ground Control to make it just more terrain-related and season with Dune. Shake it well and the gorgeous result is Deserts of Kharak.
The 10-hour campaign is fantastic. The musics, sound effects, voices, animations are top-notch.
It's not a perfect game, but it's one of the best RTS out there. The game is faster than Homeworld 1 and 2 and units are definitely more fragile. During the campaign I missed that pause between skirmishes and battles that allows you to relax and appreciate each single unit deployed on the battlefield (the enemy keeps threading a lot and you have to focus on both strategy and micro management to keep your fleet alive).

Anyway, RTS players and Sci-Fi fan: you must try this game. That's an order!
WE DEFINITELY NEED HOMEWORLD 3.

reviewText:
I was a huge fan of the Homeworld games back in the day, it blew my mind.

While I can't say this game blew my mind, it was great to play. The controls and gameplay were solid, and having played Homeworld and Homeworld 2, despite it being on a flat plan this go round, I eased right into these controls in a heartbeat. There were a few moments where I got frustrated that ships would venture off faster than their battle group, and thus wind up in situations where they were essentially screwed and I had to bite the loss, but it wasn't an issue often.

It looks breathtaking, if such a word can be used for desert landscapes, but I feel in this instance it can. I ran the game full bore, and it was smooth, no noticable drops in FPS, and at lulls in battles or resource gathering, I found myself just panning around and moving the camera just to take in the landscape. It is a beautiful game.

I think the only let down was the story, and only in it's length. I threw the difficulty up to the hardest, which in this game is labeled classic, and got through it in about 16 hours. Granted, I spent the extra time gathering resources, anticipating a potential nasty and gritty pitched battle later (experience early in the game taught me to be prepared), so that adds considerable time to my play, but it still felt short as campaigns go, despite some great missions. Of note was a mission where you have to defend an ally, and I was on the edge of my seat sending support flights over to attack enemy positions and repair ships to keep my allies in the fight. Plot wise though, it was exciting to play through the prequel to Homeworld, and feel the race-against-time tension that the story exhibits. It's entertaining and fun to see the Homeworld universe lore expand through this game, and I can see them adding DLC or another game playing out the political landscape of Kharak more.

One thing of note: Multiplayer. I gave it a shot...but, and this could just be it's a Saturday night, no one was on. I mean no one. I could not find a game to save my life. I hope this is just a fluke, because it would be exciting to play online, but that was my experience. We'll see.

reviewText:
Absolutely terrible game. Very very very simplified and casual. Have nothing to do with HW2.

Very low diversity of units. Several little cars, and airplanes, it is all what you have.
Each plane it is just a single plane, no squadron. Massive 100 vs. 100 fighters battles from HW2 is gone.
No large units. Huge battleships and shipyards is gone. The only huge unit it is starting carrier.
Starting carrier moving very fast, seems very casual, the feeling of huge mothership is gone.
Resource collectors do not docking with the carrier. They are just touch the carrier to unload resource instantly and moving back to resource extraction point. Cool looking docking from HW2 where resource collectors docked to the huge ship on the fly and slowly unload its storage - is gone.
Units limit is ridiculous, you start from 25 and by spending 1000 units of resources (cost of 10 little cars) you may up it to 125, and that's all. The game is very fast passing and casual.
Docking system completely gone. No more epic carrier which unleash the swarm of the fighters and frigates.
Absolutely disappointment. Do not buy, except it will cost 5$, that is a price of this casual game.
If you wish really HW game, get classic HW2 (not remastered) and install Complex Mod"."

reviewText:
Full disclosure:  I'm about 3 hours into it right now.   I'll update this after I finish the game.  So take this as a first impressions after getting a few missions under my belt.

I played a lot of homeworld back in the day.  I really enjoyed it.   For me this has fell a bit flat.   I'll list out some pros and cons I've felt playing it.

pros:
+ homeworld kinda-feel
+ carrier can behave as a unit that is very effective depending on how you distribute the power
+ nostalgia around the control scheme
+ unit persistence
+ tech upgrades
+ beautiful, although somewhat boring, terrain
+ simplification of y axis movement (or maybe removed?)

cons:
- physics engine almost seems not to exist.
-  height advantage is nice in theory, but is a constant struggle as you fight the camera to figure out where high ground is relative to other units.
-  constant fighting with control scheme and figuring out which units are which.
- textures are inconsistent.   Some are decent, others are just horrible.
- missions seem to follow a formula that is as predictable as ever.   Do something non-combat related, prepare to trigger waves of enemies.
- scale of stuff is really strange and disappointing.   Some of the cut scenes have the correct scale, but then you have a ship that fits a few people in it (like the science team unit) and the giant carrier not looking as big as it should outside of a cutscene.   I get it, a lot of RTS do this, but there's some weirdness in that sometimes scale is preserved and sometimes it isn't.  Plus, with the camera zooming functions you kinda expect reasonably to scale.
- story seems to try to replicate the homeworld experience,  like with the launching of the carrier -- but it just doesn't feel as grand.   It feels like you're a petty raider.   Story not very well explained as to even what your character understand of the world.
-  objectives seem very outward facing without the original story and characters backing up your fight for survival.
-  unit persistence can cause some problems at higher difficulty if you barely win a mission.  Mitigating this is the option to use a default set of units for the mission.
-  knowing where you can move units based on height of terrain is difficult or impossible until you try to move.

Right now my feeling is if you are a die hard homeworld fan like myself you will find this generally enjoyable.   For others I can't really recommend the game.  Will update after I finish.

reviewText:
I must say, I was frustrated wit the developers on this one. Great product gone bad. Here is an outlook of the first 3 months of release...

Initial impression, Engaging campaign, Gorgeous landscape and graphics, overall gameplay and physics pretty spot on.

Then came the multiplayer/comp stomp experience... absolutely awful. I look to the maps available and at release I believe it was 4... yes, 4 maps. Games in the 1990's had a better selection of battlegrounds to wage war on (since then they've slowly added but every other game out there has more maps still) .Region locking issues, the worst AI i've ever encountered in a game. I've played starcraft, total annihilation, red alert, warcraft, dawn of war, company of heroes... yes.. this game blows with AI. Some AI units dont respond when being attacked, some games it's the same 5 scout units routinely attacking me in 5min intervals, some games you literally could win with 1 type of unit, the AI is not intelligent.

Then came cash grab tactics.. Look at the release date, Jan 20th. In two months after release they release a PAID fleet pack. 2 months after the game came out!! Oh wait, they put another fleet pack out a month after that one too! If you can whip out two fleet packs but take two months to make one AI patch that had a minimal impact on AI

It's ridiculous on how developers are about cash grabs and taking advantage of the faithful like myself who preordered the game and have been a lifelong fan of homeworld.

My suggestion, wait til the game comes on sale for about 20 bucks and you can enjoy some pretty visuals, a decent campaign, and lackluster AI.

Recap:
+ Visuals, Gameplay mechanics, Campaign
- Annoying Bugs, Unresponsive/Lackluster AI, Greedy Devs, Weak online community/multiplayer, limited map selection

reviewText:
I've clocked a little over an hour into the game and completed the first three (of what I believe is around 10-12 missions for the story) and have stopped for now to provide a review and feedback.

My initial reaction to playing the game, is that there are some deep seeded homeworld aspects that are missing from the game, this was something I was expecting due to the limited press demo's provided prior to the games release.

Homeworld as a series remains my all-time favourite, I am an owner of the Remastered Collectors Edition and have dumped quite a few hours into that now that I can play homeworld on a modern PC. The negative feedback I have is such:

Map Texture quality
Seems very low, I am running the game on maximum settings and the sand and scenery simply doesn't add the same atmosphere that you see in the pre-rendered footage.

No Unit Interactions like Homeworld 1-2
Unit interactions are a generation behind the original homeworld games. In Homeworld 1, when your resource harvester collected materials and returned to hand them in, you could actually watch it dock with your resource controller/mothership and transfer the resources back.

The resource controller in DoK looks like it was going to have something similar, but they didn't finish implementing it, instead, when your resource collectors reach your collector, the mineral bar vanishes and they move off for their next collection.

No Docking
Another cool and fun Sci-fi aspect of Homeworld was docking, the fact that after a run, you could dock your strike craft with your mothership or carriers for more efficient repairs (and in Catacylsm, retro-fitting), there is no docking in DoK, once your carrier spits out a new unit it outside for good, with the extremely shot repair range on the other vessels, repairing large groups of small craft is fiddly and annoying rather than engaging and fun.

With your main 'mothership' in DoK being a Carrier, I was expecting the same mechanic

Cutscene Rendering
Several of the cut-scenes seem a little poorly rendered, the art-style itself is fantastic, but again on a modern game on a very high-end PC, I expected more crisp visuals than how they are displaying on my PC.

Zoom controls
These seem way too limited, I find myself constantly wanting to zoom out more, the maximum limit feels very claustraphobic, resulting in an awful lot of scrolling around and quick-tabbing to the sensors manager just to view short distances, unlike again the original homeworld games where you could zoom out to a great degree for unit selection and controls

omfg, why is the main menu on F10 and not ESC like 99% of games?!?!
I was taking part in a mission and needed to pause, to my surprise, ESC did nothing, I started spamming every key on the keyboard until suddenly one of them opened the game menu, I was then able to check the key-bindings (which, are fixed btw and cannot be remapped) and discover that mid-game, the main menu is accessed from F10 (whyyyyyyyyyyyyy).

Summary
Maybe my expectations are too high, considering that Homeworld 1 + 2 are multi-award, ground breaking titles, but I at least, from my perspective was expecting more, not because it's a homeworld prequal, but but because it was made by the core guys that made the original HW games, I was expecting an evolution of mechanics, not a simplification that in many ways looks like a step-back to me, or, unfinished implementation due to a rushed development and launch.

reviewText:
Pretense this here first, I think this is a good game, but it's not really up to the standards of todays games.

We are in an era where we have a blurring number of games, and other forms of entertainment, so we have little time or money to spare on other things, and I really can't suggest Deserts of Kharak as a good option.

You can feel the age of the games design in how closely it follows with Homeworld.  Very linear story, not a lot of change of scenary, relatively short campaign, no real closure at the end.

Artistically it's an amazingly beautiful game.  The ship/structure designs are top notch, and the visuals and cut scenes are wonderous pieces of art, but it really feels more like an episode of a telltale game more than a fleshed out world.

There is not a lot of replayability in the game despite multiplayer but few of my friends even got the game, so it heralds back to an age where massively multiplayer options were just not an option.  Lastly it feels like the difficulty ramps down slowly from the beginning then immediately near the end they dump more power than you'd ever be able to really need or want, so it steals any excitement near the crucial climax of the game.

If you have nothing else you'd rather play, or spend your money on, the game is still very homeworld-esque.  Great music score, amazing visuals in mechanical design, and cut scenes, but ultimately it feels like an incomplete story, no denouement almost at all, and odd unveiling of tech progression that holds the best till last stealing a lot of the challenge from early game.

reviewText:
As a long time fan of the Homeworld franchise (I remember getting the original for Christmas when I was in high school) I am sadly wishing I could get a refund... but unfortunately I have spent 5 hours with the game and can no longer do that.

The good:

-Interesting story- just like the other Homeworld games.
-Very strong art direction (looks and feels like Homeworld)
-Good visuals (it can sometimes be hard to discern what units are what when not in overlay mode though)
-Good UI and game mechanics feel solid.

The bad:

-Laughably weak AI for skirmish. The devs should be embarassed by how incompetent the Normal AI is. The only reason the Hard AI is hard" is because it is given a resource advantage and just kind of throws units at you.
-Only 5 skirmish maps (2 2-player maps
recommended:
and 1 6-player map)
-Very condensed game space and very small fleet cap. The one place this game does not feel like Homeworld is in its scope- battles tend to be much smaller tactical affairs.

Honestly
hoursPlayed: I don't even know if I will finish the campaign. I would almost rather just play HW: Remastered or Planetary Annihilation: Titans.\n\nSince I already had HW: Remastered the game was $40 instead of $50."

reviewText:
[     ] Buy now
[ ✔ ] Wait for patches
[ ✔ ] Wait for sale
[     ] Avoid

General Gameplay
In terms of performance and integrity, the game is rock solid. I've yet to encounter any bugs or crashes, a huge contrast from playing Fallout 4's infestation of (mostly non-breaking) bugs. The developers did well doing QA on this game.

Response time is excellent and pathing is mostly fantastic. I've yet to witness any issues with units being stuck or causing unwanted collisions. With that said, all the maps are open deserts with minimal obstructions so not much can go wrong.

There's only about a dozen units per faction and the other faction has a mirroring unit with minor differences. This is far from being comparable to Starcraft 2 nor Company of Heroes 2. You can dumb it down to being a two dimensional plane version of Homeworld but it's much more refreshing to play.

Single Player Campaign
Overall, I enjoyed the single player campaign experience but it was lucklustre. I just wish there was more going on, be it in the background or actively part of the campaign. There's no critters" or random environment props and units disappear after being destroyed. To be fair
date: there were sand storms in one of the missions.\n\nI don't consider myself to be an RTS expert and I don't think my APM is high enough to brag about
recommended: but I managed to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty and was only defeated twice - once on two seperate missions.\n\nThe campaign is also linear and you only get to play as one of the two factions in the game. I was actually hoping that I get to play another 13 missions as the opposing faction. However
hoursPlayed: the amount of detail and production to produce the cutscenes and dialogue was fantastic!\n\nThere's no ingame mechanic to compel you to replay the campaign again

Multiplayer / Skirmish
There's only 5 maps. No joke.

The only challenge you find here is if you play multiplayer against real players

reviewText:
I'm a diehard Homeworld fan. Playing the original on Windows 98 when I was 7 got me into gaming, and since then I've played hundreds of games, yet none have matched Homeworld's place in my heart. Naturally, expectations were high for this game, perhaps unfairly so.

Needless to say I was super excited to hear another Homeworld game was being made, but was equally terrified when it was announced it wouldn't be in space. Here's the impressions I've gotten so far (Mission 7, about 6 hours in)

Positives:
The story is great, like Homeworld stories always are.
Strong voice acting - it's nice to have several people to identify with rather than just Karan S'Jet.
Compelling enigmatic enemy - knowing the lore of the subsequent games makes it a lot more fun to learn about the Gaalsien.
Soundtrack is classic Homeworld - almost too similar - did they actually use the same sound files?
Cinematics are much improved - I loved seeing the interiors of the ships" and the character's faces.
Improved chatter - background chatter when things are slow really helps to build the immersion.
Artifacts - although it seems to break with the HW canon
date: shipbreaking and collecting artifacts to beef up your ships is fun.\n\nAlas
recommended: despite all that is done well here
hoursPlayed:
there are some things that at least for now have made it tough to recommend this game.

Negatives:
Unless you have a BRAND NEW beast of a machine

reviewText:
This is a portion of a larger review... if you want to read the whole thing, I put a link at the bottom.

Deserts of Kharak’s strongest element is assuredly its campaign. The campaign is hauntingly atmospheric, full of starkly vast spaces and lonely stretches of desert, and challenging. I’ll touch on this more in my next section. The multiplayer, at least in the game’s launch state, falls short of the promise of the game’s mechanics.

One of the strongest and most interesting elements of the game is the Carrier’s mobility. However, in both the campaign and the multiplayer, this seems oddly de-emphasized. It is as if the developers were being cautious, or were unsure of how to design around this unique feature. In the campaign, the Carrier is often left up on a plateau or stuck down in the dunes, while its armies swarm around the map completing objectives and fighting Gaalsien battlegroups. Similarly, in multiplayer, I seldom found myself moving the Carrier much, if at all, especially when playing Gaalsien.

The layout of most multiplayer matches incorporates a somewhat traditional RTS setup, with roughly a third or so of each map sectioned off into a “base sector” or “home turf” for each player, and it is in these that most or all resources on the map are found. The central and contested map area tends to feature the mach objectives: 3 automatically respawning relics Artifacts that must be collected by a player’s Baserunner and deposited at their drop-off zone. The first player to retrieve 5 of these Artifacts (or who destroys their opponent’s Carrier) is the winner.

In practice, this setup actually works fairly well for the most part, aside from the negligible mobility requirements for the Carrier (which to me are a crying shame). Conceptually, I have some deep issues with this setup.

First of all, despite the attention to detail the rest of the game receives, drop-off areas are just an arbitrarily-placed ring of pylons on the map. There’s no real asset or logically-driven factor behind the placement of these zones: the only goal was apparently to have such a zone and to place it in an area of the map roughly equidistant to each player’s start location. In terms of map design, it’s functional but scarcely supportable. Any existing game asset: structures, dropships, some sort of supply cache etc, would make this design more sensible within the game’s context. I certainly hope that future map designs take into account the story they’re telling. What are they delivering their artifacts to?

Also, the Artifacts themselves automatically self-extract at regular intervals. Sensible, to be sure, but again a bit uninspired. Perhaps such a design was tested and turned down, but I can’t help but want my Baserunner to have to manually extract each Artifact, and to defend it while the artifact is extracted, and then defend it (as is currently the case in multiplayer) en route to the drop-off zone. Such a system should seem to feel, to me, more satisfying mechanically as well as in the context of the story. Should they release modding tools for the game, I plan to test such a system myself.

The pacing of multiplayer feels appropriate to me, with matches tending to last around 10 minutes if the players are matched well, the player constantly expanding their force and building new units, the choices the player is making being meaningful: tech to air, or focus on railguns, or power through to cruisers? Scouting is difficult, thanks to Carriers coming equipped with weapons of not inconsiderable firepower.

Actually, I have found that Carriers are well situated within the context of the game. They’re able to take out small groups of units early on, but midgame armies give them pause, and can wear them down over time. Late-game units pose a serious threat, and if Carriers take them out, it would be with considerable damage to their hulls. So, the Carrier ends up being a powerful supporting unit without devolving into a MOBA-style hero (which would be a tragedy).

With access to the full unit lists of both factions, I’ve become more-or-less at peace with the unit design in Deserts of Kharak. Unit abilities are a welcome addition, such as the Gaalsien Missle Cruiser’s ground-targeted area of effect attack, which damages friendly units as well as foes, and is a counter to enemy light attack vehicles only if it manages to hit them. Rail Guns still feel odd to me as an alternative to artillery weapons, but as I mention in my preview, they work well with the game’s line of sight system so I can appreciate the choice.

Air units feel quite powerful, but I believe that a recent patch (released shortly before the publication of this article) implemented a balance fix to air units. Additionally, in opposition to my earlier statement, air units can, in fact, be individually controlled, though their default area attack command is a simple way to get some mileage out of them. They are best handled through the sensors manager, by the way.

On the topic of air units, the game’s counter system escalates greatly with the addition of Air, and Cruisers, each of which require a deep commitment from the opposing player in order to properly counter. Cruisers have many times the hull integrity of smaller craft, making them require a significant anti-armor investment from opponents, and air units move fast and hit hard, requiring (again) significant preparation from opponents to properly counter.

http://waywardstrategist.com/2016/02/02/in-the-dunes-the-carriers-deserts-of-kharak-non-review/

reviewText: I do recommend this game, but not at this $54.99 CDN price. The campaign, as you'd expect from a team responsible for the original Homeworld, Dawn of War, and Company of Heroes series, is amazing. Depending on difficulty, it's only about 10-15 hours though. Anyone who considers themselves a fan of RTS owes it to themselves to play it at some point, but not for this price. I'd suggest waiting for 50% off. The MP community is already fairly dead just a few weeks after release. The MP portion is pretty threadbare - not many maps, no replay system, matches last about 15-30 minutes. The depth of tactics and strategy is not comparable to the games mentioned above. It does have veterancy, unit abilities, and some nice terrain/line of site mechanics but would need a lot of work and expansions to give it more depth and lasting appeal. I suspect that won't happen though.

reviewText: I felt let down by this particular title. I have never played any of the Homeworld titles but this seemed to appeal to me being a ground based RTS. All I really had to go on was Gearbox's Borderlands and how I really enjoyed them so I figured, why not?, I will give it a shot. After 6 hours of gameplay, I am already deleting this title from my library because the gameplay already tastes stale like a soda gone warm and drunk the next day.\n
