reviewText:
I can't recommend this game at full price - which is a HUGE shame. On discount (50%) it is much better value.

My whole issue with this game is its depth; it just feels rushed.

Pros
Explosions look great and feel satisfying - the way lightning arcs through the plumes of black sandy smoke looks awsome. Carrier explosions are unfortunatly the other side of this coin and are pretty lackluster.
The in mission atmosphere, generated by the ambient unit chatter ect, can feel amazing especially when combat gets going.
The game feels like a homeworld game which is nostalgic.
The units that are there, are fun to use.
I enjoyed the story, even if it does feel a bit rushed towards the end.
The music fits will into the game and brings a lot of life to some of the duller missions.
The game runs pretty well on highest settings on 4k despite my rig ageing a bit.

(2500k @ 4.5, 24GB ram, 290x 4GB, SSD, Win10)
Cons

The minor stuff (which could get fixed by patches)

The game crashes. I had 4 .exe has stopped working on my 10 hours play through the campaign.
Buggy unit targeting priority - rail guns which are basically incapable of hitting the sandskirmishers (lighter vehicles) but will consistently target them despite other targets being available.
More buggy unit behavior - Bombers will often fly over their targets and simply not drop any bombs.
Visual bugs - aircraft are often invisible until they have left the end of the carrier ramp and cruise missiles will clip through vehicles and terrain before hitting their target.
Unit clipping - light ground vehicles will drive through structures they are targeting.
The major stuff which really hurts the game.

Very poor unit diversity - Where are the dreadnoughts ect?! This feels like Homeworld 1/2 with everything above a destroyer removed.
The Galsean (or however you spell the name) feel really underbaked in Multiplayer - they even have less units than the  Coalition! I find it odd that the Coalition get a fast battleship style ship which hovers (when all the rest of their units are tracked) and the Galsean feel like they are missing just such a unit. Was the side swapped because of poor unit diversity in the campaign for the Coalition?
No more resource ships docking like in Homeworld :(.
Had this game has more units and a couple more single player missions with more variety this would have been a huge thumbs up. In the state it's in, with crashes and abysmal unit diversity I have to say don't buy! Hopefully BBI can patch in some diversity and make this game what it could have been!
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
7 hours. Thats all it took to complete.
That amount of campaign time would make even a console game blush with embarrasment. For a PC game? Dear gods... I'm glad I got it cheaper having bought the remastered set in the past (and long before than the original two games....)

I could see it coming, the pace at which you get given new units is fast. Many researches... it doesn't feel like long before you have everything.

This said, it feels like Homeworld, the sounds, styles, most of the gameplay (obviously being on land changes things somewhat!) the unit icons indicating what class something is etc

TL;DR> If you love Homeworld, you'll probably love this. The problem is that just as you're starting to fall in love with it, it goes and breaks your heart and ends.

reviewText: campaign was quite nice and enjoyable but lets face it with games these days its all about the multiplayer so how does that go? well if you like games like starcraft and you can build up ultra fast resources and pump out units like nobodies business then your gonna love this. if however your like me and find starcraft a bit too spammy and in all honesty just too damned fast then prepare to love literally EVERY game as your lovely little workers slowly toil away and they get utterly wrecked by what seems to be 10 thousand units, and if you manage to fend them off dont relax because ine xactly 5 seconds an even bigger army is coming your way. The matchmaking completly sucks because of region locking so you wait ages (ive seen the queue timer hit 30 minutes then i gave up) and when you finally get a game you get stomped because the person your matched against is simply FAR better than you and its not even close to a contest. The only way to have fun online is public games but of course this means no rank gained etc. I wouldnt mind this but i feel im at very least a silver player but being matched against players who should be diamond rank is just insane. So for the campaign yes i liked it, kinda worth the money but now its going to sit in my steam library unplayed because the multiplayer is so unbalanced its unreal

reviewText:
I could go on and on about what's awesome and what is just flat out wrong with this game for hours. I might even make a review about it on youtube, since there's a lot to discuss. In the end however, to do that here would end up in a TL:DR for most people. So I will simply say this:  when compared to Command and Conquer (C&C) 3, arguably the greatest land-based RTS game ever created (and from where I think this game got a lot of its inspiration from), this newest title of the beloved Homeworld franchise falls short of the RTS genre standard in its current state. In truth the game, without all of the bugs it has right now (and they are Legion, even causing my game to crash while in a skirmish here and there), comes off a lot more like C&C 4--what with the whole mobile base and hardly any fixed structures thing.

Don't get me wrong. I like this game. I think it has massive potential. But the gameplay is restrictive, nothing on the villain's side I've played seems to work, In fact the Gaalsiens seem very rushed. And overall there seems to be an insufficient amount of asymmetrical gameplay between the two factions. It is there, but there could be more, WAY more.

That all briefly said, I cannot recommend this game where it is now. Although, I do trust that there will be patches and definite DLC content added to this game. Being a student of business and the entrainment industry, I know what the developers have done with this title. It's a thing that's happening all over film, television, and gaming right now. It's this idea that less is more." And in the case of Homeworld:  Deserts of Kharak
date: delivering LESS very much equals the fans wanting MORE. Gearbox

reviewText:
Pros: expedition guide, cinematics/story, visuals

Cons: everything else



I really want to like this game, I kept giving it a chance, and I will probably continue to do so becasue im a sentimental idiot about homeworld 1 and 2. But there are too many little things keeping it from being good. As it is, it can be enjoyable at times, but it is no homeworld.

The unit control is terrible. Airstrikes are easily wasted at no fault of the player - they almost made air units work in a cool way, but they didnt pull it off by what I can only assume is laziness. You can't even save groups for air units - once they dock to reload, any grouping is gone, so you either have to waste a lot of time whenever you launch something, or let the ai waste their single shot on whatever they see first.

Units get stuck on each other. Units have to be babied or else they will get stuck behind hills, potentially not contributing to a fight at all. There is no way to control what formation your units take, and there is no way to move a formation to face the way you want it, meaning your guys will run in one at a time in a line rather than as a wall unless you take a ton of time to set them up manually every single time you want them to move together correctly. Also, if you have units of different speeds in a formation (so more than one type of unit at all), they dont match the slowest speed, but instead rush in one unit type at a time rather than as a full force. Combat often boils down to an ugly point blank mess within seconds regardless of what you do, usually resulting in the bigger force winning. There is a way to make it feel like combat is random and frantic and unpredictable, and I doubt that is what they were going for here but regardless it doesnt work.

Also everything is extremely rock-paper-scissorsy, and not in a good subtle way like the previous homeworlds. The way damge is handled and how this-unit-ALWAYS-beats-that-unit feels more like starcraft or command and conquer, or some old 2d rts. That type of game may have its place, but I dont feel that place should be in the homeworld series.

The camera sucks. You can't rotate or zoom at the same time, or rotate and move, etc. When you rotate, it doesnt keep your mouse position where you left it, so if you rotate ~45 degrees, youll be on the edge of the screen when you let off, making you pan, which gets really annoying really fast. Also, as far as im concerned, the camera doesnt zoom out far enough without going into the sensor overlay mode. The entire game feels too close nomatter what is happening. It feels like someone copy-pasted some crap code off a unity rts camera tutorial and said good enough" becasue suckers like me would buy it

reviewText:
Firstly, the game itself feels great, it looks great and so far plays well.

It's at once familiar and fresh and really invokes Homeworld effectively, the story so far is compelling.

It's a great shame then, that I cannot progress through the story to experience it all as I've encountered a bug that many people are also encountering that halts progress at mission 4.

Restarting the mission three times hasn't fixed it, the twenty other mystical solutions offered by equally frustrated players hasn't fixed it.

I really want to give this game a positive review but the trend of Gearbox allowing glaring bugs through to retail release is inexcusable, their general inability or unwillingness to perform proper QA shows utter contempt for the people who buy their games.

If the bug is fixed in a timely fashion I'll consider changing my review for the benefit of BBS and the hard work they've poured into this game.

Even if I do alter my review rest assured I'll be continuing my general avoidance of Gearbox products - if it wasn't for my love of Homeworld I wouldn't have spent another penny at Gearbox - not that I'll be missing much, Battleborn looks like garbage and Broderlands has been milked drier than the deserts of Kharak harhar.

reviewText:
First off, for a DirectX 9c game, this is very impressive and runs on older hardware for how nice it actually looks.
Sure I've noticed a few people complaining about nvidia cards not really working with the game, go add it to your control panel and turn off your extra gpus...

The gameplay, if you Bull rush every objective, like any homeworld game series can be incredibly short.  Good luck calling yourself a true Homeworld player though, thats not how you play Homeworld games.

Go out, learn the game and take your time in it, learn how to not take heavy losses in each mission and gather up resources for the next.  I refuse to give you any spoilers other then the Story is about how the Kushan from Homeworld 1 got the tech for their mothership.

Sure the gameplay could be a little more, but its meant to keep a certain Homeworld feel to it, and for that I respect its changes and limits on the units.  Don't knock it before you try it you know.

Lastly, if your not a Homeworld fan, well maybe you should go watch a youtube review about this first instead of read up on other peoples twisted views, including mine.


-Edit: Will point out this, they really need to go about getting us some more skirmish maps.

reviewText: Homeworld + Sand = fun\n\nThere are enough overlapping mechanical and auditory elements to trigger a strong nostalgia; which translates into a less critical position towards the game than might otherwise be.  That said, this is a good RTS by any standard.  The campaign is solid, without being epic (my recollection of the first homeworld campaign).  I suspect that the real fun will begin once I dig into the multiplayer.  Bottom line: if you like RTS games, a good buy; if you also played original homeworld, a must have.

reviewText:
I am astonished at how this game is rated so highly, especially when most of those buying/playing this game, I suspect, have played homeworld 1 + 2. The is some enjoyment to be found but its short lived and just not worth the price tag or time. The are a number of major issues I have with this game.

1) The game feels rushed and unfinished. For example, the appearance of some unit models doesn't fit with their final game-play implementation e.g. coalition support cruises, which function as armoured mobile resource drop of points for collectors and repair bays for all vehicles, have a large gaping whole in them where presumably collectors were supposed to dock and off-load their resources and/or where vehicles could dock for repairs. Instead resources just magically transfer from collectors to support cruises or the main carrier when the collector gets within a set range, this is similar to the coalition repairing mechanism; instead of docking, your vehicles are healed by magic beams when they are within a set range of a repair vehicle such as the support cruiser. I can understand why the developers might have changed the game-play mechanisms at a late stage; maybe they ran out of time, or it was too difficult to implement them properly, or they were causing problems/balance issues, but if so they should at least alter/re-designed the appearance of the units affected to fit with the new game-play mechanics, not doing so is just lazy.
Interceptors/strike fighters for all intensive purposes play like bombers even though both factions also have dedicated bomber units as well. Each interceptor (Gaalsien) or strike fighter (Coalition) carries a single missile" which it can only fire at ground targets so its essentially a small guided bomb
date: they do not have any other weapons and so can NOT attack other air units. I assume from their names "interceptor" and "fighter" they were originally intended to be primarily air to air fighters and likely a hard counter to bombers and gunships
recommended: instead they just work like bombers and are arguable better at bombing than the actual bombers themselves and neither faction has any aircraft capable of fighting other aircraft which just seems silly.\nIf you order a redundant unit to be decommissioned/recycled/retired and get back a fraction of the resources used to make it
hoursPlayed: instead of returning into the carrier through the entrance (in an opposite manner to if you had just made the unit)
voteText: as you would expect
helpfulPercent: the unit just clips through to the centre of the carrier from any point on the surface of the carrier which just looks stupid and breaks any immersion.\n\n2) Why can I not dock my units!? An integral and incredibly useful feature of the homeworld games was the ability to dock smaller ships with your capital ship(s). With Deserts of Kharak this feature is no more

votesFunny: to protect them during attacks such as air strikes

reviewText: FINALLY a new RTS game on the market! Ignore all those negative reviews, just a bunch of spoiled gamers who only want to play a game they designed in their imagination (but that is just not how it works). I only just met with the Homeland Series and I must say I am really impressed! I love the fact that every unit you create counts, especially in the Campaign, as they gain veterancy and every unit and CU/RU get transfered to the next mission. This veterancy system becomes more and more important as the missions progress, and trust me, you will want high ranking units further in the game! The same goes for Skirmish mode, there is no unit spamming due to the fact that you have to micro manage you resources and research, as well as veterancy. An elite unit will always over power a lower ranked unit. Regardless off what many reviewers on here say about infantry, I also love the fact that it is vehicle combar only, as infantry would be useless due to the massive sizes of the vehicles, (just look at some of the cut-scene's, Rachel sitting under the Science Runner, or when the Runner enters the Epsilon base) so infantry would make no sense .. I agree on the fact that there are not a lot of skirmish maps at the moment but, come on, the game just launched I am sure they will add more in the future! As for NO Base Building, I do not care too much for that. I love the fact that you command a huge carrier which is your mobile FOB and you have to protect it all costs. People also complained that there was not enough advertising before the launch, but I can understand and even prefer that, as too many games over advertise their games and end up with just a lot of fuss .. I can recommend this game to everyone who has missed a proper RTS game (as it is a dying breed), I am really happy to be able to play a new type of RTS without unit spamming. The only thing that does bug me a little is the unit limit, a max fleet of 125 (vehicles can take up to 8 units at once) so that is another point that needs working on (I think it is like that for performance). As for the rest, I think we will some major balance and content updates in the near future and I cannot wait to see them.

reviewText:
Fast paced, well balanced rock-paper-scissors RTS action with satisfying, visceral combat.

Thats the short of it, while the long is that it is a tragic, emotional journey, of which most of us know the ending to. There were times when I teared up, just knowing how things were going to end.

For a game of fiction, it came off as so realistic and heartfelt in its struggle. 10/10

reviewText: A worthy successor to the genre defining classic. Delivers a very tightly focused and engaging, albeit short, campaign. Easy and intuitive controls that are the staple of Homeworld games, and the devs really hit the mark on getting the feel right. Sidenote: Bind your carrier to a hotkey it will alleviate your build, research, and airstrike woes. Some minor optimization issues during cutscenes on ultra (i7 gen3 and nvidia 750ti) but overall smooth gameplay at high resolution. Played through on medium difficulty with only a minor challenge, no palm sweating like Tenhauser on the original and didn't have to restart the entire campaign because of an improper build. If you're looking for a devastating challenge this might not be for you(at least on medium difficulty), but if you loved Homeworld this is definitely worth your time. Full price might be a stretch given the campaign length. If you havn't played Homeworld, what the hell are you doing with your life? Pick up the remastered and enjoy a masterpiece. If you're already a fan, grab this on a sale, or if you're rolling in cash support the devs and encourage future titles in the series.

reviewerDisplayName: Prof. Dr. Sir Lord Master, Esq.
reviewText:
(Some spoilers for those who haven't played Homeworld)


If you enjoyed the original Homeworld game, then you'll enjoy this sandy romp through the desert.

You've got the familiar structure of units and strategy built around a central mobile base, you've got a heirarchy of units that each have that rock vs paper vs scissors tactical system at the low end, and a moving story about people fighting against the odds in the pursuit of truth + salvation in the face of tyranny.

Everything a good Homeworld game needs.

My only complaints are that the pacing of the game is forcibly fast, and the ending is a bit too succint in my opinion.

(Spoilers for Deserts of Kharak, don't read on unless you don't mind the risk )

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy all that is here, I just wish that the game wouldn't force certain conflicts that'll end the map, I can count 3~4 instances where a final battle on a map is forced because the enemy is rushing at me and I pretty much have little choice but to bring the hammer down.  I think this sort of tactic should be reserved for the classic difficulty, or add another mid boss type enemy that'll chase you down, but maybe save a final objective for when the player wishes to end it, for easy and / or normal difficulty anyhoo.

Again my complaint is when the final objective that will end a map happens to be a boss type character that is chasing the Kapisi down, forcing an early end of a map, I don't mind if the enemy is throwing other groups of enemies or challenges at the kapisi, I just don't like having the map end so fast because the final objective is chasing the kapisi, this just shortens the game overall, I'm sure I would've gleefully enjoyed a few more hours recovering any and all artifacts and resources on each of the maps, and my overall playtime would've been closer to 15 ~ 20 hrs at least, and I would've been happier for it.

The impatient players can always go force that final fight themselves, if they REALLY want to, what I liked about Homeworld was being able to strategize how I would win.

As for the ending, yes all of us who played homeworld know what will be found deep in the great banded desert, BUT it would be nice to add more of that lore and story, I don't even remember seeing the galactic map etched on stone being found in 'Deserts of Kharak'.

I mean sure, you see that in Homeworld proper in the intro, but that intro summarizes what happened after, told in the future.  I would have loved to see the S'jets exposition the discovery, maybe even discussion between the people who worked the expedition react, posit theory etc.  and then at least have a 5 minute + exposition about the next 100+ years:  The tribes again becoming the Kuushan, the world embracing unity and discovery, the design and building of the Great Mothership.

Hopefully some decently priced DLC could cover this?  The greatest moving aspect of this franchise is the story, don't give it too short a shrift.  ;)

Some other minor complaints I have include Rachel's Hack ability, why does it require RUs to use it? Why aren't hacked units special abilities researchable to add to your own units?

Also why does Rachel habitually drive in front of the Kapisi if she is assigned to it?  shouldn't as a support unit naturally stay to the rear of the Kapisi?

Why do direct fire units (like the railgun units) not get their shots eclipsed by terrain?  I'm pretty sure they shouldn't be able to shoot through hills / dunes accurately with ZERO line of sight.

reviewText:
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak
Wow the first Homeworld game in over a decade. And while I'm not that happy that it did play on ground this time I still very much enjoyed it.

Black Bird Interactive tried to remain loyal to the original art and style which goes from the epic cutscenes including the famous cinema borders + sound to the level of cutscenes while slightly enhanced nowadays you certainly know that this is a Homeworld game so fans of the old series might feel at home right away just in regards of the style.

Story: Well there isn't much to tell and I don't want to say much about it but it is a prequel to Homeworld 1 in which you rediscover your origin of your people. While few plot holes and unanswered questions remain the story was well executed and does flow charmingly into the franchise.

Gameplay: The game arrives with a decent tech tree and alot of discovery awaits. How ever I felt that the (SP) Missions were somewhat to easy and also to repetiive compared to the masterpieces of the original Homeworld games.

As for the factions both of em seem rather balanced and are mostly copying each other. Their animations and looks differ but that's all I could tell during the playthrough of the campaign. (on medium by the way) But that doesn't necessarily make it bad in either way.

Terrain also plays a significant role in this game as the line of sight and hight matters which adds some sort of strategic benefit similar to the Ground Control games. Also long range units are of certain importance as well. Because they can mean the difference between defeat and victory. If you're getting caught off guard an enemy air raid might eradicate your ground forces kinda fast if there's no AA nearby. Same goes for Artillery if you lack your own long range units or other counters you might be in for a rough ride. Conclusion it's a fun and rather balanced game with several strategic possibilities.

Mp:
There isn't much to tell yet as the mp section of the game is very tiny to this point. There're like 5,6 maps total which is kinda sad although I suspect more might follow. The game modi are also limited to (team)deathmatch and artifact recovery which is somewhat similar to capture the flag or king of the hill gaming modes except that you need to deliver the artifacts to a certain drop off point just like in CTF.

Most maps are very small which adds a certain tension throughout the match though at the same time I also find it limiting as it doesn't allow you much room to flank your opponents. Also pity that they didn't add in some of their weather effects of the single player missions (Sand storms, Tornados) to the mp maps as that might have added in some additional spice to the mp game sector.

Pro:
-Lovely story.
-Balanced game
-Good audio components
-Nice graphics
-Good performance on a 3 year old Quad Core I5.

Contra:
-Tiny and limited mp section
-Small sp campaign with somewhat repetitive mission design Salvage this
date:
destroy that" kind of thing.
- Few plot holes and unanswered questions remained in the story arc (Taiidan? And why did it crash? 1st expedition? What happened to the remaining crew of certain Characters ship?)
-Can't modify the controls (yet)
(-What do they eat? Not a single plant nor animal seen throughout the game. I know it's a desert planet but at least some alien cactus here and there wont hurt.) Getting answered more closely in the Survival Guide.


All in all I can recommend it. Though I would possibly wait till a steam sale. It's good but it's not that good to pay 50 bucks for. Simply because it's a rather small game at this point. If you're a hardcore Homeworld fan though

reviewText: Just beat the campaign on Normal setting. When I first heard of the concept of this game, I thought it was stupid, but the pre-release videos really sold me on it. The game definitely exudes that 'Homeworld Vibe' I've been missing since Homeworld 2 was released, and is a worthy purchase. If you are a Homeworld vet, as I am, you may find the 'normal' difficulty level to be a bit too easy. But perhaps hard is called 'Classic' for a reason... I thoroughly enjoyed the game and would recommend it wholeheartedly to any RTS fan in general, but especially to any Homeworld fans out there that may be holding back. If you feel like modern RTS's have gone the way of all twitch reflexes (and think that that kinda sucks), this game is defintely for you.

reviewText:
Upgraded Carrier to Power 5, rushed enemy carrier. Resulting explosions were gratifying. 10/10

On a more serious note, I enjoy the games aesthetics and it's streamlined gameplay. Normally I'm a fan of RTS games such of the likes of Command & Conquer Red Alert 2 to call back to the days or the Total War games, but this is a great example of pairing down the RTS and still making it enjoyable. I'm able to be jump in and play a good game without having to invest several hours into it.

Deserts of Kharak doesnt have to be a very big and complex title to be a good RTS. The AI needs work but over-all it was worth the money I put down on it. (Mind you it wasn't the full 60!) So I'm happy with it and would recommend it.

reviewText:
So far, game is very entertaining.  Much nostalgia.  Missions are fast and furious, so if you're expecting a slow easy pace like Starcraft 2's campaign, you will be disappointed.  Air units are pretty strong, and mistakes are pretty punishing.

The game, like the remastered version of Homeworld 2, does not allow you to manually progress to the next mission.  This results in many lost minerals and artifacts if you progress on the main objectives at a fast pace.  The end result is that you start the next mission without the resources required to get off to a decent start.  This can be VERY frustrating!

Only other complaint is that most of the strike units are pretty boring.  Gone are the Ion Frigates, support corvettes, and other smaller units that made their mark on the homeworld franchise.  Instead, it's a bunch of trucks that all sort of seem to do the same thing, or very close to it.  The game is very heavily focused around fighter and corvette equivalent class vessels, and more than halfway through the story, I can't build anything bigger yet.  Makes for some frustrating gameplay, especially considering how flimsy those vehicles are and how impossible that makes maintaining veteran units.

I'll update this review when I finish my playthrough, but for right now, I'm giving this a recommend based 90% on the fact that it's Homeworld and 10% on the quality of the game itself.

reviewText:
Honestly, I was totally excited when I saw Hardware: Shipbreakers, cause I knew right off the bat that it was a prequel to HW1.  Me and my bro used to play these games all the time even though I was too young to understand the story at the time, eventual re-runs solved that as I got older.

In my opinion, the story is the best part in the HW series, and is the overall contribution to the positive review.  There are some minor things that could have been improved on but I believe HW: DK holds true to the previous games as being story rich.

My only real disappointment was after the first mission when the stats of the fleet showed up and it showed the water and fuel levels.  I was really hoping for there to be some side missions where you had to re-supply and half-way hoping that the units in the game had a fuel meter that had to be managed or risk leaving a craft a sitting duck while waiting for fuel rats.  I know it kinda sounds like a pain but this would have had a moderate impact on how the game would have been played, as the last thing any sane person would have done was attack an excavation site running on fumes and it would have added a great deal to the desperate mood of the game.

Now, I was reading through some of the other reviews and I have to admit, the graphics, camera controls, and unit diversity was a bit subpar.  Although I am more concerned about the camera controls than the graphics.  It was sometimes very difficult to get a good view of what was going on around you but popping into the strategy view helps with that at the loss of viewing the actual crafts.  I think that the ships could have been more detailed upon closer inspection and some of the in-mission cutscenes really pointed this out.

Finally the unit diversity, which was pretty small, but in my honest opinion, was a good choice to go with as the story line revolves around a fleet with limited supplies (again, not as stressed as I was hoping it to be) going from point A to point B fighting enemies along the way.  Having multipurpose crafts such as the Baserunner would have been the economical choice.  Also I can't think of any other way to diversify the fleet that wouldn't have to have been re-discovered in HW1, such as beam weapons and the like.  Would be kind of silly to have a beam weapon craft in HW: DK and then play HW1 and have to buy Beam Tech from the Bentusi in order to build one :S

I have yet to play MP, but I looked at it briefly and noticed there are very few maps.  I fear that DLC will add more maps and content for the price of 30 dollars...

reviewText:
A high-quality modern RTS, but very short singleplayer campaign.

The story takes a while to get going - they don't give you reason to be invested in this expedition until it's been going awhile, unlike the older Homeworlds, where the singular nature of the mothership provides immediate weight.  Here, it mostly feels like a plot designed purely to shove you into the combat in a way consistent with established lore - it's not until most of the way through the campaign that it starts to feel like more than a perfunctory/excuse plot and starts explaining its own internal logic.  By the end though, it does feel like a Homeworld game in tone, if not in length or depth.  The lore seems to mostly follow Homeworld 2, while the gameplay more draws from Homeworld 1.

The campaign seems a bit on the easy side.  For much of the campaign, the unit mix is relatively modern (ie small set of rock-paper-scissors units) - the unit diversity only comes in rather late, which is unfortunate, since the late missions are often much *shorter* since you have such a strong, veteran force (and numerous tools & utilities) by then.  Air units are treated more like special attacks than units, and are incredibly powerful, seeming to negate much of the potential difficulty.  The brevity means much of compounding economic decisions Homeworld usually has you make are vastly milder here.  It's like the game is filled with Homeworld's great macro-mechanics, but the campaign fails to utilize them well.

The brevity of the campaign is unfortunate, and makes it a questionable purchase at full launch price if that's your main interest.  But the quality means that if you can get over the lack of content by one means or another, Shipbreakers Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a solid offering.  Certainly the best RTS I've encountered in many years.

reviewText:
First off I have always loved the homeworld series. Played them since they came out when i was a kid. And, i think this game and its background story as told in the expadition guide are incredible and i want more. There is a serious feel and connection to the old homeworld games that is distict. Ground Homeworld I feel is an AMAZING idea which needs to be repeated. That being said, there are many points about this game i like...

Pros
- Guard Command in this game is one of the most useful tools in this game. Allowing automatic battlegrounds that work really well.
- The line of sight tool in this game works very well and that combined with the move command allows for simple and intresting game play
- LAND CARRIERS HOW FREAKING COOL IS THAT!!!
- Units look like they should work in real life and i havent noticed any clipping in the models themselves
- The Battle Chatter is AMAZING!
- Music is PERFECT. Its something thats many times over looked but it sets the scene and this games music does it well.
- The Deserts themselves are very well done. The rolling dunes look real and the desert walls look so realistic.
- Vehicles move very well as far as ive noticed.
- waypoint setting is very intuitive
- Once again if you read the expedition guide you find the story is SOOO rich its incredible. Very much worth touching on again

There are however a few big things that i dont like

Cons -
- TEXTURES ARE HORRIBLE and ill tell you why... if this where any other game id say what ever its an RTS. However this game is trying to focus on massive scales (not to mention being a series which always pushed the bounderies of graphics potential). As i play this game i find it very hard to realize the sence of scale because when i zoom as close as i can get to get a good scenic view the SAND LOOKS FUZZY AND UNDEFINED. This combined with the vehicles own textures being rather blurry results in making all the units look smaller.

- SCALE COMPARISIONS are few and far between. with the sand and units hull detail lacking there is not much else to help you visualize the true scale being represented by the units under your command. Id like to see more human sized representations if not in some cases humans standing on the units walkways.

- Terrain Shadows are not crisp even on Ultra which also separates me from the world immersion.

- Weapons Fire seems very random. It would seem the units movement across the dunes means nothing. They could hit the target while on the move or miss by a mile while standing still. If your trying to sell the units as having future tech I don't see how you could miss by as much as some of these units do while they aren't moving.

- Both teams units are basically the same exact things. As Ive heard it put so well, one teams units hover the other teams dont. Other then that they might as well be the same thing. Gotta switch it up. Every good RTS game ive ever played has done something to make the two teams really stand apart. Ground Control 2, all C&C games, War Craft and Star Craft are all examples of this. Also, all Total War games inately have this as well (because they seek to emulate real life)

All and all dispite my gripes, I really like what this game is trying to do and its original concepts and story are fresh and inovative. I dont nessisarally think this game recaptures what i felt when i played homeworld & homeworld 2 for the first time as a kid. However, although i may not find it to be the best made Homeworld game its still a good game if your just looking to play a game. I think maybe if they kept up on this path and didnt abandon it this titles predesessors will be truely amazing. For that reason i have to vote this game up.

reviewText: Before DoK, I knew nothing of the Homeworld franchise.  The only reason I bought this was because it reminded me of Dune II all those years ago.  The pre-order came with Homeworld 1 & 2 remastered editions.  Knowing nothing of Homeworld, I played through those campaigns before starting the DoK prequel.  Solid and fun campaigns, reminded me of Battlestar Galactica.  Open space combat kind of felt like a giant submarine battle.  Interesting twist on RTS.  Remastered multiplayer could be fun but I prefer the polished balance of SC2 for competitive play.  I feared DoK would be a C&C4 abomination with the mobile carrier/construction yard.  It was not an abomination, it was excellent, a modern Dune II without the spice.  DoK has been widely criticized for multiplayer balance issues, a general lack of content, and easy campaign upgrades.  The balance is fine, I can win with either faction on all difficulty settings on skirmish mode.  Content is solid, but I did get 3 games for the price of one.  If you think the campaign is too easy then raise the difficulty and you won't have the resources to upgrade everything until maybe the later missions if you managed to keep your persistent fleet alive.  I enjoyed fleet persistence between missions on all 3 games.  The stories amount to a short comic book per game with little character development, and that's ok, it's still on par with or superior to most offerings.  DoK multiplayer could use some more maps, but there's plenty to get started with.  Now that the campaigns are done I might keep DoK installed to challenge my brothers on multiplayer when the price comes down.  I used the Steam Controller for all 3 campaigns.  Community templates get you started, might take an hour or two to customize for yourself.  After this I think the Steam Controller might improve my SC2 APM's.  If anymore DoK DLC comes out I'll probably play it too.

reviewText:
TL;DR version
A really polished and stripped down assymettric RTS with some environmental positioning tactics that has a 10 hour story of pretty good value.  Needs more maps for multiplayer and a more consistent AI.

First off, this game is fantastically well polished in the fundamental aspects.  With the other homeworlds I often felt there were lots of features and ships and upgrades that weren't pertinent to any viable strategy.  I think the goal was to make sure that all the content created and implimented was meant to be pertinent to the player.  I found myself using every single unit and almost all of their abilities.  I think they did a fantastic job with making this an in between 3D space RTS and 2D traditional RPS with the implementation of dunes.

What is being said about the lack of content is somewhat true.  The story was rich and was easy to get into; an all around good time that didn't drag on forever.  Others might be looking for longer stories but I felt like it was appropriately measured for a prologue.  The number of maps is pretty depressing and I did notice that if a battle waged on for too long eventually the AI would kind of just stop pressing the offensive and turtle.

The assymettric factions are well put together with similiar units but put together in a way that requires different play styles.  There was perhaps room for a 3rd faction (the sakala really should have had a different design) but I wouldn't be surprised if all this was intended to be hand in somekind of DLC.

reviewText:
Should you play this game?

Well i just two minutes ago finished the story... 13.5hrs and its pushed me to write my first recommendation review.

Many games pad it out and drop allot of fluff in you know, busy work. This was desperate cut throat gameplay, intense pressured missions.

It has all the vibe of the HW1/2 the cutscenes are great the storyline was enjoyable but could have been expanded on a little (Id but any potential SP DLC for that allone)

The units are few but the value of those units, especially when you carry them through each mission never using the default fleet mode. The pain of losing that honourguard at the end he was with me from so early on.

Its risk vs reward especially in the later missions. I loved it im glad they put a fully working game out with an intense singleplayer campain instead of padding it out and ruining the pacing.

I do hope for more DLC and for (fingers crossed) homeworld 3.

I think if you are a fan of the series it is a must, if you are a casual gamer id be on the fence. IF its all multiplayer for you then i can comment as im only about to jump into a game now.

But ill be jumping into Homeworld:1 HD as it feels like you can do so without sacraficing anything gameplay wise.

8/10

More SP missions DLC and some new units and ill be chuffed.

reviewText:
Love all the Homeworld games.

Wanted to love this.

Didn't happen.

Graphics - Great, top-notch
Sound - Also very nice. No complaints.
UI - Mediochre. Needs work.

Gameplay - Fail.


So here's how every mission will go.

The game will most likely drop you into a senario where you have about 5 seconds to react and setup your forces before you start getting pounded or have to go meet some timed objective. Oh and remember, there's NO PAUSE feature so forget about doing any planning or strategy. You will then proceed to move into a defensive formation around your carrier. That is pretty much the last you will move your ground forces for the remainder of mission (with the exception of maybe sending out scavs). They will just sit there turtled and defending.

Why? Well a number of reasons.

Computer has infinite resourses and units. You do not. sending out your units is pointless since even if they win a skirmish, the enemy will get new units in 5 seconds for free. Eventually you will lose all your units and will have accomplished little to nothing. Ground forces are just defensive turrets for your carrier.

Also the game does not allow a high enough unit cound to field and offensive and a defensive team. If you use your units on offense, your carrier will be undefended.
The only real offensive units are your aircraft. They will do ALL the work and they will do it better and more efficiently than any of your ground units.

Another thing....your units in this game are WAY too fragile. It's absolutely stuipid how fast units die.


Another downside to the game is mission design. Whoever was in charge of this, you really need to go back to flipping burgers.

Almost every mission is exactly the same. They pretend to be different, but in the end I played almost every mission exactly the same, had the same triggers, had the same outcomes.

Only variety to this was when the game would randomly take units away from you for ....reasons.
My favorite occurance of this being when you carrier arrives to a misson BEFORE all you other units/crusiers/etc. Um ok, your carrier, which is basically the slowest, lumbering beast in your entire task force, by some miracle, managed to arrive at the combat site a full half day before all these other units which are faster.

Sure makes perfect sense.


Another gripe...

Research.

So for the first handful of missions you get to research a few things at a time. Than at one point in the game you suddenly get like 50 things to research (basically all of the tech left in the game). Even though you are really only about half way through the game.

There's a veterancy system in the game but good luck with that. I acutally went through the trouble to farm units for a LONG time to build up veterancy in many of my forces. Only to have these forces instantly obliterated later by...oh any host of things. It doesn't matter. Your units pretty much die if anything larger than a gnat hits them.


For a game that claims to be an RTS, it is by far the worst RTS I've played in a LONG time.

But quite frankly, it's really not an RTS.

So there's my rant. Sorry if it's a bit random but I tend to just spew thoughts.

reviewerDisplayName: Prof. Dr. Sir Lord Master, Esq.
reviewText:
(Some spoilers for those who haven't played Homeworld)


If you enjoyed the original Homeworld game, then you'll enjoy this sandy romp through the desert.

You've got the familiar structure of units and strategy built around a central mobile base, you've got a heirarchy of units that each have that rock vs paper vs scissors tactical system at the low end, and a moving story about people fighting against the odds in the pursuit of truth + salvation in the face of tyranny.

Everything a good Homeworld game needs.

My only complaints are that the pacing of the game is forcibly fast, and the ending is a bit too succint in my opinion.

(Spoilers for Deserts of Kharak, don't read on unless you don't mind the risk )

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy all that is here, I just wish that the game wouldn't force certain conflicts that'll end the map, I can count 3~4 instances where a final battle on a map is forced because the enemy is rushing at me and I pretty much have little choice but to bring the hammer down.  I think this sort of tactic should be reserved for the classic difficulty, or add another mid boss type enemy that'll chase you down, but maybe save a final objective for when the player wishes to end it, for easy and / or normal difficulty anyhoo.

Again my complaint is when the final objective that will end a map happens to be a boss type character that is chasing the Kapisi down, forcing an early end of a map, I don't mind if the enemy is throwing other groups of enemies or challenges at the kapisi, I just don't like having the map end so fast because the final objective is chasing the kapisi, this just shortens the game overall, I'm sure I would've gleefully enjoyed a few more hours recovering any and all artifacts and resources on each of the maps, and my overall playtime would've been closer to 15 ~ 20 hrs at least, and I would've been happier for it.

The impatient players can always go force that final fight themselves, if they REALLY want to, what I liked about Homeworld was being able to strategize how I would win.

As for the ending, yes all of us who played homeworld know what will be found deep in the great banded desert, BUT it would be nice to add more of that lore and story, I don't even remember seeing the galactic map etched on stone being found in 'Deserts of Kharak'.

I mean sure, you see that in Homeworld proper in the intro, but that intro summarizes what happened after, told in the future.  I would have loved to see the S'jets exposition the discovery, maybe even discussion between the people who worked the expedition react, posit theory etc.  and then at least have a 5 minute + exposition about the next 100+ years:  The tribes again becoming the Kuushan, the world embracing unity and discovery, the design and building of the Great Mothership.

Hopefully some decently priced DLC could cover this?  The greatest moving aspect of this franchise is the story, don't give it too short a shrift.  ;)

Some other minor complaints I have include Rachel's Hack ability, why does it require RUs to use it? Why aren't hacked units special abilities researchable to add to your own units?

Also why does Rachel habitually drive in front of the Kapisi if she is assigned to it?  shouldn't as a support unit naturally stay to the rear of the Kapisi?

Why do direct fire units (like the railgun units) not get their shots eclipsed by terrain?  I'm pretty sure they shouldn't be able to shoot through hills / dunes accurately with ZERO line of sight.

reviewText:
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak
Wow the first Homeworld game in over a decade. And while I'm not that happy that it did play on ground this time I still very much enjoyed it.

Black Bird Interactive tried to remain loyal to the original art and style which goes from the epic cutscenes including the famous cinema borders + sound to the level of cutscenes while slightly enhanced nowadays you certainly know that this is a Homeworld game so fans of the old series might feel at home right away just in regards of the style.

Story: Well there isn't much to tell and I don't want to say much about it but it is a prequel to Homeworld 1 in which you rediscover your origin of your people. While few plot holes and unanswered questions remain the story was well executed and does flow charmingly into the franchise.

Gameplay: The game arrives with a decent tech tree and alot of discovery awaits. How ever I felt that the (SP) Missions were somewhat to easy and also to repetiive compared to the masterpieces of the original Homeworld games.

As for the factions both of em seem rather balanced and are mostly copying each other. Their animations and looks differ but that's all I could tell during the playthrough of the campaign. (on medium by the way) But that doesn't necessarily make it bad in either way.

Terrain also plays a significant role in this game as the line of sight and hight matters which adds some sort of strategic benefit similar to the Ground Control games. Also long range units are of certain importance as well. Because they can mean the difference between defeat and victory. If you're getting caught off guard an enemy air raid might eradicate your ground forces kinda fast if there's no AA nearby. Same goes for Artillery if you lack your own long range units or other counters you might be in for a rough ride. Conclusion it's a fun and rather balanced game with several strategic possibilities.

Mp:
There isn't much to tell yet as the mp section of the game is very tiny to this point. There're like 5,6 maps total which is kinda sad although I suspect more might follow. The game modi are also limited to (team)deathmatch and artifact recovery which is somewhat similar to capture the flag or king of the hill gaming modes except that you need to deliver the artifacts to a certain drop off point just like in CTF.

Most maps are very small which adds a certain tension throughout the match though at the same time I also find it limiting as it doesn't allow you much room to flank your opponents. Also pity that they didn't add in some of their weather effects of the single player missions (Sand storms, Tornados) to the mp maps as that might have added in some additional spice to the mp game sector.

Pro:
-Lovely story.
-Balanced game
-Good audio components
-Nice graphics
-Good performance on a 3 year old Quad Core I5.

Contra:
-Tiny and limited mp section
-Small sp campaign with somewhat repetitive mission design Salvage this
date:
destroy that" kind of thing.
- Few plot holes and unanswered questions remained in the story arc (Taiidan? And why did it crash? 1st expedition? What happened to the remaining crew of certain Characters ship?)
-Can't modify the controls (yet)
(-What do they eat? Not a single plant nor animal seen throughout the game. I know it's a desert planet but at least some alien cactus here and there wont hurt.) Getting answered more closely in the Survival Guide.


All in all I can recommend it. Though I would possibly wait till a steam sale. It's good but it's not that good to pay 50 bucks for. Simply because it's a rather small game at this point. If you're a hardcore Homeworld fan though

reviewText:
This game looks and feels like homeworld. Im not good with the lore of the series so I don't know how well of a prequel this is. votesTotal: context-sensitive reaction to whatever you’ve ordered them to do. An endangered unit might thank you for sending in air support. A ship which has spotted incoming enemies will tell you what type of craft they are. Idle units will chatter amongst themselves at length about faults and tactics. As well as successfully giving you a general sense of what’s going via audio alone

reviewText: Just beat the campaign on Normal setting. When I first heard of the concept of this game, I thought it was stupid, but the pre-release videos really sold me on it. The game definitely exudes that 'Homeworld Vibe' I've been missing since Homeworld 2 was released, and is a worthy purchase. If you are a Homeworld vet, as I am, you may find the 'normal' difficulty level to be a bit too easy. But perhaps hard is called 'Classic' for a reason... I thoroughly enjoyed the game and would recommend it wholeheartedly to any RTS fan in general, but especially to any Homeworld fans out there that may be holding back. If you feel like modern RTS's have gone the way of all twitch reflexes (and think that that kinda sucks), this game is defintely for you.

reviewText:
Upgraded Carrier to Power 5, rushed enemy carrier. Resulting explosions were gratifying. 10/10

On a more serious note, I enjoy the games aesthetics and it's streamlined gameplay. Normally I'm a fan of RTS games such of the likes of Command & Conquer Red Alert 2 to call back to the days or the Total War games, but this is a great example of pairing down the RTS and still making it enjoyable. I'm able to be jump in and play a good game without having to invest several hours into it.

Deserts of Kharak doesnt have to be a very big and complex title to be a good RTS. The AI needs work but over-all it was worth the money I put down on it. (Mind you it wasn't the full 60!) So I'm happy with it and would recommend it.

reviewText:
So far, game is very entertaining.  Much nostalgia.  Missions are fast and furious, so if you're expecting a slow easy pace like Starcraft 2's campaign, you will be disappointed.  Air units are pretty strong, and mistakes are pretty punishing.

The game, like the remastered version of Homeworld 2, does not allow you to manually progress to the next mission.  This results in many lost minerals and artifacts if you progress on the main objectives at a fast pace.  The end result is that you start the next mission without the resources required to get off to a decent start.  This can be VERY frustrating!

Only other complaint is that most of the strike units are pretty boring.  Gone are the Ion Frigates, support corvettes, and other smaller units that made their mark on the homeworld franchise.  Instead, it's a bunch of trucks that all sort of seem to do the same thing, or very close to it.  The game is very heavily focused around fighter and corvette equivalent class vessels, and more than halfway through the story, I can't build anything bigger yet.  Makes for some frustrating gameplay, especially considering how flimsy those vehicles are and how impossible that makes maintaining veteran units.

I'll update this review when I finish my playthrough, but for right now, I'm giving this a recommend based 90% on the fact that it's Homeworld and 10% on the quality of the game itself.

reviewText:
This is a good take on an excellent classic. It's a RTS, but it's not in the same vein as the frenzied click-fest style of so many modern RTS's. For the most part, you have time to plan moves, co-ordinate attacks with ground and air assets, long range and repair craft all contributing towards a sucessful maneuver.

There are times when it does turn into a panic, and you have to move fast and click even faster, but that's not the norm, and I think it only serves to add tension to an otherwise slower paced RTS.

Significient tactical choices are few, but vital. For exmaple, some terrain will not allow the passage of your carrier, so do you leave it unguarded and send the rest of your units off, or split them, losing the punch?

I haven't tried mlultiplayer yet, but I can imagine that is a bit more of a click-fest, but still not overwhelmingly so, due to the way the game works. I think that it will be played better on the tactical map for MP than in the close u p pretty view though, so you can keep an eye on what your opponent is up to.

The game looks and sounds very good indeed, and although that's not why you buy a strategy game, it does add a lot towards the value of it.

Overall, I'd recommend this game as rewarding and fun to play, but not a serious challange, at least in SP mode.

reviewText: Before DoK, I knew nothing of the Homeworld franchise.  The only reason I bought this was because it reminded me of Dune II all those years ago.  The pre-order came with Homeworld 1 & 2 remastered editions.  Knowing nothing of Homeworld, I played through those campaigns before starting the DoK prequel.  Solid and fun campaigns, reminded me of Battlestar Galactica.  Open space combat kind of felt like a giant submarine battle.  Interesting twist on RTS.  Remastered multiplayer could be fun but I prefer the polished balance of SC2 for competitive play.  I feared DoK would be a C&C4 abomination with the mobile carrier/construction yard.  It was not an abomination, it was excellent, a modern Dune II without the spice.  DoK has been widely criticized for multiplayer balance issues, a general lack of content, and easy campaign upgrades.  The balance is fine, I can win with either faction on all difficulty settings on skirmish mode.  Content is solid, but I did get 3 games for the price of one.  If you think the campaign is too easy then raise the difficulty and you won't have the resources to upgrade everything until maybe the later missions if you managed to keep your persistent fleet alive.  I enjoyed fleet persistence between missions on all 3 games.  The stories amount to a short comic book per game with little character development, and that's ok, it's still on par with or superior to most offerings.  DoK multiplayer could use some more maps, but there's plenty to get started with.  Now that the campaigns are done I might keep DoK installed to challenge my brothers on multiplayer when the price comes down.  I used the Steam Controller for all 3 campaigns.  Community templates get you started, might take an hour or two to customize for yourself.  After this I think the Steam Controller might improve my SC2 APM's.  If anymore DoK DLC comes out I'll probably play it too.

reviewText:
TL;DR version
A really polished and stripped down assymettric RTS with some environmental positioning tactics that has a 10 hour story of pretty good value.  Needs more maps for multiplayer and a more consistent AI.

First off, this game is fantastically well polished in the fundamental aspects.  With the other homeworlds I often felt there were lots of features and ships and upgrades that weren't pertinent to any viable strategy.  I think the goal was to make sure that all the content created and implimented was meant to be pertinent to the player.  I found myself using every single unit and almost all of their abilities.  I think they did a fantastic job with making this an in between 3D space RTS and 2D traditional RPS with the implementation of dunes.

What is being said about the lack of content is somewhat true.  The story was rich and was easy to get into; an all around good time that didn't drag on forever.  Others might be looking for longer stories but I felt like it was appropriately measured for a prologue.  The number of maps is pretty depressing and I did notice that if a battle waged on for too long eventually the AI would kind of just stop pressing the offensive and turtle.

The assymettric factions are well put together with similiar units but put together in a way that requires different play styles.  There was perhaps room for a 3rd faction (the sakala really should have had a different design) but I wouldn't be surprised if all this was intended to be hand in somekind of DLC.

reviewText:
First off I have always loved the homeworld series. Played them since they came out when i was a kid. And, i think this game and its background story as told in the expadition guide are incredible and i want more. There is a serious feel and connection to the old homeworld games that is distict. Ground Homeworld I feel is an AMAZING idea which needs to be repeated. That being said, there are many points about this game i like...

Pros
- Guard Command in this game is one of the most useful tools in this game. Allowing automatic battlegrounds that work really well.
- The line of sight tool in this game works very well and that combined with the move command allows for simple and intresting game play
- LAND CARRIERS HOW FREAKING COOL IS THAT!!!
- Units look like they should work in real life and i havent noticed any clipping in the models themselves
- The Battle Chatter is AMAZING!
- Music is PERFECT. Its something thats many times over looked but it sets the scene and this games music does it well.
- The Deserts themselves are very well done. The rolling dunes look real and the desert walls look so realistic.
- Vehicles move very well as far as ive noticed.
- waypoint setting is very intuitive
- Once again if you read the expedition guide you find the story is SOOO rich its incredible. Very much worth touching on again

There are however a few big things that i dont like

Cons -
- TEXTURES ARE HORRIBLE and ill tell you why... if this where any other game id say what ever its an RTS. However this game is trying to focus on massive scales (not to mention being a series which always pushed the bounderies of graphics potential). As i play this game i find it very hard to realize the sence of scale because when i zoom as close as i can get to get a good scenic view the SAND LOOKS FUZZY AND UNDEFINED. This combined with the vehicles own textures being rather blurry results in making all the units look smaller.

- SCALE COMPARISIONS are few and far between. with the sand and units hull detail lacking there is not much else to help you visualize the true scale being represented by the units under your command. Id like to see more human sized representations if not in some cases humans standing on the units walkways.

- Terrain Shadows are not crisp even on Ultra which also separates me from the world immersion.

- Weapons Fire seems very random. It would seem the units movement across the dunes means nothing. They could hit the target while on the move or miss by a mile while standing still. If your trying to sell the units as having future tech I don't see how you could miss by as much as some of these units do while they aren't moving.

- Both teams units are basically the same exact things. As Ive heard it put so well, one teams units hover the other teams dont. Other then that they might as well be the same thing. Gotta switch it up. Every good RTS game ive ever played has done something to make the two teams really stand apart. Ground Control 2, all C&C games, War Craft and Star Craft are all examples of this. Also, all Total War games inately have this as well (because they seek to emulate real life)

All and all dispite my gripes, I really like what this game is trying to do and its original concepts and story are fresh and inovative. I dont nessisarally think this game recaptures what i felt when i played homeworld & homeworld 2 for the first time as a kid. However, although i may not find it to be the best made Homeworld game its still a good game if your just looking to play a game. I think maybe if they kept up on this path and didnt abandon it this titles predesessors will be truely amazing. For that reason i have to vote this game up.

reviewText: I went into this game thinking it would be more like a typical RTS.  While it does maintain those type of aspects, there is no base building.  You base is mobile, just like it was in Homeworld 1 and 2.  This game, however, brings about the unique idea of having technology that can be added to your carrier to increases its capabilities. You have to find the tech fast, because it can be lost!  I've only played for ~5 hours but I love the art and graphics in this game.  Even the story telling hooks you!  I would definitely recommend purchasing and beating this game!

reviewText:
I am a HW fan and I like this game.

Before I started, I wondered whether the team can tranlate the core of the universe battle into fights on the ground. After about 100 minutes play, I am concieved they did. This is a game fabricated with sincerity, deep understanding to the old HW games and creative thinking, which I have found lost in so many old frachises. It is hularious to see it. Some games, bearing the same name of the series and doing good job of keeping superficial things all along, have lost their core on the way. In contrast, this game keeps the core of homeworld, what makes fan like it, while has been creatively done in a very different way.

A smart and enjoyable piece of work for me.

reviewText:
I must admit when I first heard about this game I thought:

how could you make a Homeworld game that is planet-based?"

Well the answer simply is by how HW: DoK is designed and executed.  It's a ground-based RTS sure but unlike any you have played.

The vehicles look gorgeous zipping along; zooming off sand dunes only to bounce on their bouncy-bouncy tires followed by hair-raising hand-brake turns so that they can get close to their prey to finish them off with their high caliber
date:
high powered kinetic weapons.

Obliterate your enemy form the air by dispatching an air squad or gunship (the equivalent to an AC-130); finally turning them to molten slag by raining death from your bombers.

Feel envious of the enemy's shiny railgun capital ship floating in the air in the same way that bricks don't?  Well just appropriate it with Rachel's groovy "obedience whip" (well hacking ray anyway) and its all yours!  Arrr! That be pirates in this 'ere dunes now!

Send out your salvagers to gather much needed resources; go defend your allies carrier; defend against incoming units.  Oh no incoming ordinance!  Potential information overload!  Thank goodness for the real-time tactical map (better than HW's) which is surely the best thing since pop-tarts.  With this map you can be sure you can remain in complete control even you can hear the lambs screaming."

reviewText:
While no means perfect, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is an amazing game.

Having been a player of the Homeworld series since it first came out in 1999, Deserts of Kharak fills the Homeworld universe with more large scale battles set against epic vista's.

The game has enough variety in the terrain for me that it doesn't get boring or repetitive. Vehicles are well detailed and it has different types to keep things interesting.

I do have several things I disliked. The campaign I feel could have been a bit longer. While I am satisfied with what we got, I feel that a few more missions would have helped. I do feel the mission variety did help a bit though.

Several other users have made comments of the low textures. I feel I must partialy agree. While zoomed out and moving around the map it really isnt that noticeable, when zoomed in, it does become apparent.

All in all, I was happy with the game and the way it turned out. Hopefully BBI will improve upon this and work with Gearbox to create new space-based Homeworld games that we all have been dreaming for.

reviewText: This game is amazing. Really it is. As a strategy game, it has great tactical depth and forethought to make both the campaign and multiplayer delicious for years to come. The graphics are great, and units feel good. But that is not what makes this game so spectacular. No, its that it may be the best homeworld game since homeworld. This game BREATHES the aura of  sparsity, mystery, and holiness that homeworld evoked. This game blows homeworld 2 out of the water as true to the original and a great succeeding game, and makes me want to buy the remastered collection before I have even beaten the campaign or tried the multiplayer. If you like strategy games buy this game. If you like homeworld, prepare to immerse yourself in the best cutscenes and music since 1999...

reviewText:
I am an old Homeworld fan, so this may influence my review somewhat.

Having awaited for the next HW installment for a long time, I was positively surprised when I saw HW DoK up for pre-order a few days before release, and since I enjoyed the first games I decided to give it a go. Already having the remastered edition I got a discount on the buy. And since I pre-ordered I got the DoK Expedition Guide as well.


HW DoK certainly brings you back into the franchise - there is no Mothership nor space 3D tactics, but HW DoK has the same feel to it as the other games had - same type of mission videos, well told story line, music. The game evolves much like the original games - steady upgrading of your Carrier (Mothership) and units with research, while scaveninging as much resources as you can out of every map. Basicly, for the same reasons I liked the original games so much I also like DoK.

As others have mentioned the multiplayer maps are few - yet for me, this doesn't matter all that much, as I mostly stick to single player.
Otherwise, the main drawback of HW DoK, for me, is like the other HW games - It's so enjoyable it simply isn't enough of it and you keep wishing for more. (Perhaps that is why we like the franchise so much ?)


The Expedition guide adds a bit of history to Kharak and the Kushan people. Enjoyable read which expands a bit on the HW universe.

reviewText:
Atmospheric and fairly engaging, but don't expect strategic depth on the level of a Starcraft-tier RTS. Think more like Supreme Commander 2 but on a more tactical scale. Combat features generally small engagements with well under 100 units per side, and the campaign can be drawn out in terms of time (especially by completionists who make sure to mine every penny on a map before moving on), but it isn't very complicated or difficult. The UI can also be a little wonky at times (good luck figuring out weapon ranges, and just try getting units to form up facing a particular direction), and it would be nice if the main camera could zoom out a little more so we don't always have switch to the strategic view.

Nonetheless, good voice acting, very good - and mature, thoguhtful - writing, nicely done cutscenes, and excellent music all combine with a beautiful aesthetic to make something very enjoyable. The levels may just all be rocks and sand, but they're memorable, and even though a couple of the units tend to blend into each other when amassed in great piles and viewed at a distance, a lot of thoughtful detail has been put into the audio-visual experience.

It's soothing. It may not require tactical genius or bring very much new to the RTS genre, but it's a fun piece of art.

reviewText: Deserts of Kharak is essentially Homeworld on a planet's surface.  That's the best description I can come up with.  Various vehicles act as near-direct counterparts to ships from the previous two space-side games.  You research to upgrade your units, build up your forces by sending out mining teams, and manage your forces to stay under the population cap, same as Homeworld. Terrain offers minor advantages or disadvantages compared to space, but overall the gameplay is more of the same.  The story plays out through movies with a painting-like aesthetic between missions or in-engine cutscenes during the missions.  Without spoilers, it's a decent story, if that sort of thing matters to you, not superior to original Homeworld but still very solid.\n\nIn short, if you liked Homeworld, you'll probably dig DoK.  If you were looking for more than that, you'll probably be disappointed.  I myself liked it just fine.

reviewText:
So far the game is a mixed bag for me.  I find the story pretty interesting and like the look of it but I am already bored of the old-school RTS gameplay in the campaign.

I had the same issue with Starcraft2.  After playing Supreme Commander FA for hundreds of games and the Warhammer RTSs I just don't find much fun in spamming units, ramming some health bars into some enemy health bars and waiting for my inevitable win.  I want more strategic and tactical depth.  There is a rock-paper-scissors thing but it's extremely obvious when to use what unit so the only real challenge is in putting up with a bit of tedium and moving quickly.

Also, I DESPERATELY want to scroll the camera back more in non-sensor mode.  It feels super claustrophobic and I wrestle with the camera to get it pointed at the action in time to see anything.  Which makes me want to stay in sensor mode, which seems like a waste. SupCom solved this problem years ago, but in the name of old-school we gotta ignore that?

And yes, even though I loved homeworld back in the day I had the same feeling of boredom when I replayed the recent remastered version.  That old school RTS thing was just played to death and does not entertain me anymore.

I hate to thumbs it down because it does what it says on the tin.  But I am sad that I probably won't finish the interesting story because the gameplay is not very engaging.  I would only reccomend it to someone with a nostalgic love of retro or who is new to RTSs in general.

reviewText:
I really like RTS's as a genre, but this is a disappointment on many levels.
- The graphics are bad. I play in 1920x1200, as I have for over a decade. Settings are on ultra. The video looks terrible, definitely low res up-sample. Ok, but who needs video, it's purely cosmetic. The UI is upsampled, this is unforgivable. The UI for an RTS needs to be 1:1, functional, efficient and utilitarian. It is the most important part of the game. The map itself is not very good looking, but now I'm just complaining. I can get over this.
- There is no mini-map!?! There is no way to hop the camera around from part of the map to another. All you have is pan/scan which is too slow and inefficient. There is sensor mode" which is not a good substitute.
- The AI doesn't seem to be very smart at all
date: it simply seems to rely on scripts and overwhelming force. It appears hard the first play
recommended: but then you learn the script and you prepare a defense. Really not that insightful.\n- The controls aren't very good

And you remember 10 years layer sitting in linear algebra with the professor droning about eigenstuff and wondering "Huh

- The units have a lot of special abilities that seem very challenging to effectively use given the limitations of the UI. I expect I will spend 90% of my time with the arrow keys moving my camera around.

I plan to return this game. I'm sorry

reviewText:
This game reminds me of RTS in the 90s and early 2000s.
Not in the good way.
Unskippable cutscenes, that you're going to have to watch repeatedly because the game bugs out and you have to load earlier games.
Missions designed around a special ability" that is completely useless outside of that special ability.
UI choices that make no sense (esc should always close open menus and the focus for the save file name should be the text entry).
The game cynically cashes in on the name of the Homeworld franchise while producing little to none of the gameplay or feel that the original games had. In trying to do something different to the Homeworld franchise
date: they produced a game almost exactly like every other ground-based RTS in existence.\nAt least it's pretty."

reviewText:
So disappointed, was really looking forward to this.
This game was not ready for release and does not live up to its heritage.
Have requested a refund.

As other reviewers have said, and in no particular order:

- shoddy animations
- shoddy physics
- selecting units can sometimes be difficult and behaves inconsistently
- inconsistent texturing (though some of it is beautiful)
- a carrier that doesn't carry anything
- resource harvesters that don't actually visibly return resources, just pull up 100m away from the carrier, pause and then continue.
- pathing management with large vehicles and somewhat enclosed spaces is clumsy
- backstory isn't particularly well presented, more implicit than anything else
- semi-adoption of Homeworld keyboard shortcuts, but pressing 'f' to focus doesn't really work, double tapping it does nothing
- no alt-select for focus
- camera controls don't seem intuitive
- camera can not be zoomed out far enough, forced into the sensor view 90% of the time, even though the maps aren't that large
- only a handful of skirmish maps
- AI is lacking in the campaign

The biggest problem though is one of the games core mechanics, the effect that elevation has on combat:

- an overlay is displayed with elevation hints when you are issuing move or attack-move commands but this info is unavailable if you're simply right clicking to issue move commands. A keyboard key to toggle the overlay would have been more useful.
- positioning units, particularly large groups of units, to take advantage of elevation is virtually impossible as there are:
- no formations for units
- no way of specifying the orientation of units or groups of units
- despite LOS being such an important mechanic, you will often find half your units have none, and there's little you can do about it.

I love the concept and art design. The UI is fine. Music is spot on and the Story is OK, just under presented.

I think most punters were surprised when this was announced. Almost seems like the release date was a little bit of a surprise for the developers - seems as if they were rushed into getting this out the door well before it was ready, otherwise I would be DEEPLY surprised if all these game dev vets who were supposedly working on the title would have been content shipping it.

If development continues post release and some of the above gets fixed, I would gladly change my review. Would love to this title shine.

reviewText:
This game could be described as a reskinning of homeworld. That would  be ok, but i find certain
Mechanics and elements lacking making the overall gaming experiance a bit of a let down.

For example....
1. You cant skip certain  cut  scenes making replaying difficult missions a drag
2. Game load time is slow, even on very fast dedicated games machine
3. Game path is linear, certain events are triggered regardless of whats happening making the completion of objectives difficult.
4. The controls are not as sophisticated as homeworld. For example you cant queue your build order when you dont have minerals.
5. Not sure how intelligent the units ai is. In homeworld units would attack the appropriate units they were meant to counter.
