reviewText:
While Deserts of Kharak certainly was inspired by the Homeworld series, and the touchstones fans are looking for are present, the execution of the game demonstrates a bewildering naïveté by the developers who never seemed to get their arms around what they were writing.

First, let me say this game is beautiful.  The artists did a top-notch job, and the cinematics feel like a more evolved form of Homeworld's black-and-white, simply animated cut scenes.  The new characters, the models, and the interface all compare favorably with modern RTS's.

The main problem I had with Deserts of Kharak actually had to do with the way the setting, the mission design, the visual design, and world never seem to meet, and indeed, actively clash in numerous places.

Let's start with the visual design.  Deserts of Kharak, as the name suggests, takes place almost exclusively on enormous, tan dunes of sand.  There's very little visual distinction between terrain rises, falls, and textures.  If the game were in VR or otherwise provided steroscopic vision to the user, this might be less of a problem, but as it stands, just reading the terrain you're looking at can be surprisingly difficult.

Secondly, there's the units.  They're the same color as the terrain they're sitting on.  While that would probably make sense for a desert fighting force, from a gameplay perspective, it makes interacting with your units from the main game view very tricky.  Even with the overlays that provide different shapes for different types of units, it can be a challenge even to see a unit, let along distinguish what kind of unit it is.

The sensor manager from Homeworld is back, and provides the shape-based overlays for both friendly and enemy units.  Unlike Homeworld, though, terrain plays a major role in the micromanagement-heavy gameplay of Deserts, as does unit orientation.  Neither bit of information is clearly expressed in the sensor manager, and as a result attempting to control the battle from the sensor manager can be something of an exercise in surprise and frustration.

The sensor manager also gives me an opportunity to segue into the issues with the mission design.  Especially early in the game, the missions introduce challenge by having enemy units attack simultaneously from multiple different directions.  In principle, that's fine, and it makes sense in the context of the story, but that type of mission is singularly poorly-suited to the interface of Deserts.  Because the game encourages, to the point of requiring, micromanagement of units, and because you can only get a view of the battle as a whole from the sensor manager (which is an entirely separate screen), it is very easy for a player to simply be unaware of a new attack force or front moving in from a different position.

To put it in more technical terms, the other games in the Homeworld franchise could get away with their UI choices because the missions always made it clear there was a defined axis of attack.  Deserts of Kharak does away with that choice, and while it is unlikely to cause a player to fail a mission outright (although certainly possible), it feeds a feeling not that the enemy is outsmarting you, but that the interface you're using isn't up to the task you've been set to.

Finally, the story is... strange.  It moves in fits and jerks, asks a lot of questions, and answers few.  Long-time fans of the Homeworld universe will undoubtedly be left scratching their heads at a number of the retcons that were introduced to support the new story.  The end of the campaign comes suddenly, and the few seconds we're spared of denounement do nothing to resolve any of the questions raised to that point, or hint at the fate of the characters between the end of this game and the beginning of Homeworld 1.

Ultimately, and in spite of the Making Of content, this game feels like a game written about a science fiction desert society, that was crowbarred into the Homeworld franchise by adjusting the interface and story, but ignoring the game design lessons of its predecessors.  Deserts of Kharak would've been much better served to have simply remained Shipbreakers and stood on its own.  By becoming a Homeworld game, both the franchise and this product have been diminished.

reviewText: Imagine your favorite movie. The opening scene comes, your hero comes into view and... you can't hear a word he/she's saying because the music is too loud! reviewText:
It's homeworld, but on the ground...

Yep, that's all.




Actually, no.

First off, it's a LOT faster than original homeworld, since you got no slugging spaceshuips (Well, you kinda have cruisers, which are impressive, strong land vehicles with lots of firepower). There's a lot more going on.
At some point, it even felt a little bit like C&C Generals (If anyone remembers that game).  And yes, that's a weird and probably wrong comparsion to make (atleast according to some people), but the speed and action reminded me of that game.

I miss some things, especially from the Remastered version of Homeworld. Battles are not as customizable as they were before. I can't change the population limit or ressource density anymore, which, since I like long and drawn out battles, really is a bummer. Also, it feels like there are less units available, so you feel limited. That's not really true, because you got your awesome carrier that you can upgrade into a truly powerful battlewagon and Aircraft is just amazing.

The graphics are absolutely stunning, BUT... if you zoom in and take a close look at your carrier or other vehicles, you notice some low res textures, but since you not often have the time to watch a battle errupt, that's not that bad.

The sound, oh man, the sound. It's brilliant. I love the sound design. Explosions have a good amount of *WAAM* in them, aircraft flying by your ground troops sounds like in a movie. Perfect. Just perfect.

I, personally, instantly fell in love with it. I hope to spend more time with it further on.

reviewText:
The game itself was quite good. I played it whenever I had some free time. All in all, I managed to finish the game on the highest difficulty setting within ... 18 hrs. For a 49 EUR game it is a joke, really.
Multiplayer is weak at the best, skirmish mode - I tried it, played a couple of matches, all of which I had won easily on the highest difficulty setting without any trouble.
And I am not THAT good a player.

Was the game worth buying at the current price? No. Definately not. Would I recommend buying it with at least a 50% discount? Yes. A price range of up to 25 EUR would be fine. As a 49 EUR title the game is much too short. Less than 20 hours of play for such money should not happen.

My recommendation - wait until the game is much cheaper or on sale and then buy. Not before.

reviewText:
Ill say up front, I want to love this game.
The multiplayer is quick, fun yet still tactical. (Though could use plenty more maps and better AI for skirmish mode)
The single player mode is atmospheric, in depth and gives me that same sense of wonder and being alone as the original did.
The graphics are amazing, full of little detailed, nothing like seeing the dust clouds as a group of AAVs nearly jump over the crest of the sand dune, hit the ground with a satisfying thunk, and open fire into the flank of an enemy attack group.

That all being said,
Its buggy as hell at times
I have a consistent repeatble complete system crash at the end of mission 5 during the unskippable cutscene. I run the game maxed out on my 980ti, the temps never get high and i dont see FPS drop.
But a game shoudl not SHUT OFF my video card when crashing.

reviewText:
Given that I haven't played much homeworld before, though I've played RTS games for decades.

Graphics are a bit underwhelming. The levels look ok-ish, the units and FX just look bland. There's zero sense of theatrics
, for the actual gameplay.

Gameplay, I can see myself eventually getting used to the interface. I like the grand veiwpoint and the great sense of scale,  but the gameplay gives no sense of gratification.
An enemy unit is there, you select your units, click on the enemy, wait a bit and it's gone. They should've taken a lesson from Company of Heroes 2, SC2 or Warhammer; destroying an enemy unit should have a sense of occasion, you see debris exploding into the sky.

Audio, what a mess. Especially for someone new to Homeworld, nobody shuts up for a second.

Conclussion, I'm tired and I haven't smiled or raised my eyebrows once, in the hour and a bit playing this game, which is a problem, especially for a game that's this expensive. I MIGHT give it another go, when it goes on sale, but there's no way I'm paying 50 bucks for something this 'meh'.

reviewText:
Pros:
- story feels like homeworld (but lacks fresh ideas)
- overall homeworld look and feel

Cons:
- NO PAUSE to issue commands - and this is why I cannot recommend it as a strategy" game
- missing animations for docking etc.
- weak AI
- gameplay changed to an action RTS (you build a lot of units and throw them at enemy waves)
- research too fast (doesn't feel like a hard earned reward)
- campaign too short (13 missions)

People who like fast paced RTS might like this title - real strategy gamers expect something more."

reviewText:
TLDR: At $30usd I’d recommend this, $50 feels pretty steep. Add it to your list and wait for the price to drop a bit.

I’m gonna go on the record and say I loved Homeworld. In fact, I even made a Babylon 5 themed mod years back for the original (Conflicts of Interest), so I was super excited for this game.

Spoiler free review.


Positives

Art direction  - Continuing the unique homeworld aesthetic, it’s almost minimalist letting silhouette and contrast describe things rather than piling on armour plate after plate. Its visually a breath of fresh air especially today when a lot of sci-fi these days is just over blinged crap (I’m looking at you Halo, StarCraft). The endless dunes in conjunction with massive machines is genuinely cool. The cut scenes are also fantastic, it’s a sublime mixture of 2.5d animation with in game cinematics.

Homeworld feel  – The game is a prequel so naturally it’s going to borrow things but it really does recreate that feeling of the original. Unit icons, radio chatter, upgrading functionality of your fleet is all very reminiscent of the original.

Music, sound and voice acting  – Everything again feels spot on. From explosions to the urgency of dialogue in the middle of a battle, it’s extremely well produced.


Negatives
The game is really short for a $50 title. I know I got the remastered editions of HW1 and 2 with it, originally I thought this was a plus, but now I almost wish I didn’t, did the price get pumped up to justify this? The missions themselves offer very little in diversity compared to SC2. Many missed opportunities here.

Factional mirror matchup. Well one has tracks and moves a bit slower and the other has hover engines and moves a bit faster. It’s cool visually but gameplay wise after 6ish hours it really just feels visual. Disappointing.

Homeworld feel  – The original came out eons ago, and while it was mind blowing at the time, I can’t help but feel like some things should change by now. No minimap. Yes, there’s a sensor manager but I just feel it’s a holdover from when you needed a fully 3d map(for homeworld). It’s too much toggling. It feels unnatural these days to be toggling on a mode that is essentially an oversized minimap. You can’t appreciate the art of the game while doing this, and you can’t properly manage any large scale battle without resorting to looking at light blue on darker blue boxes to decide the outcome of things. It’s kind of like how pro StarCraft players turn the settings all way down but to the nth degree. It’s cool for a mission briefing but I’ve grown to despise it for in game usage.

Some units are also criminally forgettable  and look the same at a distance. Resource collectors and light units. Gotta use that sensor manager to select resourcers properly. But then Cruisers, all of them just blend into each other. In the sensor manager, battlecruisers, artillery cruisers and support cruisers share the same damn icon. But as they have vastly different functions, you have to zoom in or listen to the radio feedback when selecting them. But then you can’t see what’s happening on to your other units because you aren’t using the sensor manager to look at things, ugh. It’s just annoying. I’m forced to look at stupid light blue on blue boxes to issue orders and have map awareness, but it just hurts the experience. I can’t appreciate the little firing animations or the little clouds of dust they kick up when moving. Stop taking me out of the experience 

While the story is cool it’s also a bit naff. What do I mean? Well it drops you right in the middle of things and sets you up for an epic ride, and it just doesn’t quite get there. The motivations of your foes are quite flimsy, it feels a bit rushed or cut short. It basically left me feeling a lot of why and what and then just ok whatever towards the end.

UI annoyances - Burying build units under icons. I found it rather irritating that building units you have to select your carrier, then select a box, an arrow shaped box, a diamond shaped box or a slightly askew box to then build light medium air or heavy units. The icon differences are just crap and it feels unnecessary given that there really aren’t that many units total to justify the categorization. The game focuses on quick decision making while managing your entire fleet and their abilities, this is something that takes away from your concentration in a big fight.  Basically the game definitely is a step back from the control and finesse system of SC2.
I honestly did enjoy the game, and won’t be asking for a refund or anything but since steam only allows for positive or negative and not something in between, I’m going to have to go with negative mainly due to the current price. I was also kind of a superfan of homeworld, so for a newcomer I think at around $30(USD) would’ve been a good price (turn the recommendation to yes) for this title.
I’ve been harsh on the game but only because of how I had such high hopes. My negatives really aren’t show stopping in any way, but I feel like the current price point the game just doesn’t offer enough to justify things. I both love the homeworld feel but also feel like BBI hamstrung themselves adhering to it so closely. They wanted genre defining but I feel like this will simply stand as a good game, not as the standout title that Homeworld was.

reviewText:
I highly recommend against getting this game.

It is boring, easy, has the most basic uninteresting gameplay.  The controls are absolutely terrible and constantly get in the way.  The story isn't uninspired, has terrible voice acting, and utterly lacks tension. The shipbreaking mechanic crosses past pointless into annoying, and nothing gameplay wise happens in the campaign.

I Alt-F4ed the game just now in frustration because half my army got wiped out DURING THE CINEMATIC of a group of enemies appearing. The game feels exactly like an RTS made in 1999, and not in a good way. There is just so much more they could have done, and so many concepts they could have borrowed from games that came later.  I'd say the only good thing about it is the music.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game, but if you are new to the series, I can't recommend given the price-to-content ratio.

Definately captures the feel of Homeworld... The graphics, UI and cutscenes are true to HW. The game also makes good use of the 2D aspect. Introduces carrier-borne aircraft to add more dimension as well.

Campaign is good and sizeable (10hrs?), although being a prequel you should know whats going to happen, and there really aren't any surprises. Even the 'big twist' is completely obvious if you've been paying any attention to the dialogue.

Unfortunately has little content upon release... Only 5 maps. 2x2-player, 2x4-player and 1x6-player. Unit selection feels a little small, and even the heaviest non-carrier units die very quickly if properly countered.

The game also has completely braindead AI that is only capable of throwing endless waves of units into your meatgrinder. It can't even build up a significant force, it just spams you with small groups of units.

I hope they add more FREE content to this game. They have created a good base game here, but it has no longevity. If they are simply going to leave it to the modders to extend its lifespan, then the asking price should not be nearly so high.

reviewText:
I was going to write a long review of Deserts of Kharak.

I was going to airily start with an evocative image of the sun broiling its way down towards the horizon of wind-sculpted dunes, as seen from the ramparts of Epsilon Base. I was going to talk about the manful chuckle of delight this opening sequence forced from me, an ardent and devoted Homeworld fan of many years.

I was going to move on to detailing all the wonderful things the game does so well: Its delicate but inventive handling of the source material, the jaw-dropping graphics, the colourful and interesting units, the beautiful music scoring and the snappy voice acting. Having waxed lyrical over these facets and having thoroughly set the scene for the rest of the review, I intended to move on to a brief detailing of my first hour with the game, you know, walk you through what you could expect afer you finished reading my sycophantic witterings and purchased the game for yourself.

However...

About twenty minutes into the second mission, things began to get ever so slightly hectic. So, my years-honed Homeworld insticts snapped my pinkie out and slapped the pause key...

The game menu popped up and the screen greyed out.

Wait... what?

That must be a mistake, I thought. Escape that, press the 'P' key... nothing.

Tap the 'pause' button again...

...Menu, grey screen.

Ten minutes later I asked for a refund.

reviewText:
Having played a lot of Homeworld with its finelly tuned control scheme, H:DoK control scheme surely is not. Right clicking puts the mouse in view mode rather than interpreting it as a move order. Control-dragging often results in a selection rather than an attack box. The alt-click and alt-drag to focus from HW is sorely missed, instead click F to focus on selected unit(s) together with a hit-and-miss selection function (it is more difficult to select units than one should expect from an RTS.

- Story is fine so far.

- Graphics (except the lo-res stuttering cut scenes used sometimes instead of game engine cutscenes) is what I expected and wanted from the HW devs and art directors.

- Sounds and music are as good as HW.

- Controls are so irky, quirky and sub par, I don't want to ruin my experience by continuing until the game has been patched. I hope it's not a Unity engine issue but only an unfinished, untuned release.

In the state the game is now and for the current asking price I unfortunately cannot recommend the game. I got everything I expected except from the control scheme that is neither up to HW nor RTS standards.

Will come back after a patch or two though and promise to change my No to a Yes. I wan't to believe ;)

reviewText:
When I first loaded up Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak and dove into the first mission, I knew it felt right within seconds. The technical sci-fi unit chatter was there, the strategic overlay was a familiar blue with helpful unit icons, and my fleet was setting off into the emptiness of space the desert.

DoK is a love song to the original 1999 Homeworld in all of the best ways.  Although I found myself missing the Z-axis, the rest of the Homeworld formula remained quite intact--from the strike/armored/ranged/cruiser unit types to the versatile camera movement. It also speaks to the fluid controls that I was able to play the entire game easily with a Steam Controller :)

The story in DoK also does a great job of mirroring the great continuity that was present from mission to mission in vanilla Homeworld.  You are not jumping around the planet/galaxy on various missions like in a Starcraft or C&C game--it is just your fleet on a long, difficult journey.  And true to the 1999 original's legacy, your fleet persists from mission to mission, so units left alive at the end of a battle are able to continue on in the campaign (now with helpful veterancy bonuses).

One place where I was a little disappointed was with the difficulty of DoK.  Although the campaign's strong narrative does a good job of making you feel a sense of urgency, I found that I was able to take losses and keep going way more than I could in the original Homeworld--even on Hard difficulty.  This lack of extreme difficulty also made the game effectively shorter for me (17 hours for the campaign) than its 1999 brother, even though I think the number of campaign missions was comparable.

The easier difficulty could be partly due to lulls in the fighting that allow ample time for your salvagers to hoover up every last resource in the AO--a tactic that was essential in 1999 Homeworld--so I was rarely wanting for resources.  But I really only found myself sweating before I had built up a fleet in some of the early missions, and in a couple cases where my fleet was not available on account of some smaller scale missions.

But I have a fix for these gripes.  I was not planning on getting the Homeworld: Remastered Collection before; but DoK has left me so thirsty for the brand of storytelling that has been true of all of the Homeworld games that I cannot resist grabbing the Remaster at this point.

reviewText:
I almost gave up on getting this game to work.

If you have a 21:9 monitor don’t change any settings or they will be stuck, as there are no 21:9 resolution listed and the video modes drop down is broken as it acts like something is pressing up when the drop down is selected.  Deleting the config and letting it regenerate does not help as it is stored in the steam cloud and is downloaded each time you launch.  So annoying.

Mouse control was erratic and has something to do with having joysticks plugged in - unplug all joysticks if you are having erratic mouse issues.

Game is sometimes jerky and slow sometimes (not always) even on extremely overclocked high performance machines and I suspect it has to do with Unitiy.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I'm very unpleased with not having unit formations.

I like the guard function for its circle type formation, however, when something is being guarded the guarding vehicles don’t defend (when they are out of range) - They really should “GUARD” the unit in question…

The AI in this game is very dumb to non-existent.

It was a fun game for its story as it fits the Homeworld story timeline.

reviewText:
To start out with, I liked this game, but did feel it could have been something more.  For reference, I am far more interested in the single player campaign than multiplayer/skirmish.

Positives:

-The feel of the game was very reminisent of the origional Homeworld game.  Everything about the art style and the music was very much in keeping with the orgional.
- Going along with this was the quality of the vehicle and fleet designs and compostion.  I did not feel like there were any useless units, and overall the game felt well balanced.
- The game was fun.  Both the story and the gameplay were generally immersive and fun.

Negatives/Improvements

- As mentioned elsewhere, the campaign was short.  In general, the whole game felt smaller, not as grand in scale, as the origional Homeworld Games.
- A lot of interesting things happen off screen.  The inclusion of the Feild Guide" was a nice piece of worldbuilding
date: but some of the things in it would have made for great missions
recommended: or would have made the reasons for some in game events make more sense.  I would have liked to see more of the guide included in the actual game.\n- The control scheme is a bit basic.  Something as simple as the ability to rotate your arrival points would have been greatly appreciated.  In general I thought the controls were adequet
hoursPlayed:
but were a bit dated.

Overall

As noted

reviewText:
Fantastic new style RTS - 90/100

Pros:
-Great Single Player (all I really wanted from this game)
-Story is up to par and similar to Homeworld 1 and 2
-Desert terrain mechanism for sight is fun
-Units have rock/paper/scissor counters and you definitely need to whatch what units engage and retreat
-Graphics and sound are fantastic

Cons:
-When mission ends, the left over resources are lost including artifacts.  It would be nice for a continue after mission ends to gather these.  So save often.
-Storyline is predictable, but it barely matters.  Would have loved additional backstory of the other clans etc.

Final Thought:
I personally loved this game as a campaign only" purchase.  I tried multiplayer a few times and it did seem to have very redeeming gameplay.  However
date: since I play a TON of other games I have sidelined the multiplayer till other friends buy the game."

reviewText:
*Spoilers duh...*


+ Homeworld! I was dreaming about this game since first one and loved cataclysm, more please! (Bentusi ftw)
+ Techtree, A bit classic did miss tech vessels tho for faster research and 1 mission dumps like 10 at once.
+ Voice acting, Pretty sure I reconise the female voice anyways I helped the game and story.
+ Story line, finnaly! A look at what transpired on Kharak before the mothership was built.
+ Solid references to homeworld 1 and 2 lore.

+/- Haven't decided yet if I liked how the units look, not a big fan of the giant flat vehicles, and the hovers would actually make a hole in the sand if they stay in 1 spot too long.
+/- Where's my lasers, auto cannons and all the other shiny particles where homeworld grew up with?

- Too damn short, Cleared within 7 hours thats bad for a full priced game. (had discount tho :P)
- Mapdesign, can clear almost all levels without even discovering half the map.
- Artifacts dont need em, and heavily screws with my OCD to collect every one of em which ties into next point.
- AI, Enemy suicides into me before I can grab all artifacts and I auto win mission... :(
- Bugs - carrier was breakdancing on a dune and then decided to jump up / artillery cruiser refuses to fire for Gaalsien.
- Multiplayer achievements, really?! my OCD doesn't like that one bit. Guess it's to ''up'' the replayability but with 6 maps orso that doesn't seem to fly.

I would definitly buy this again, I know the - is  more then the + but the game itself is very enjoyable.
And most the - points can be fixed in future patches, like AI, bugs and making mapdesign more viable to discover.
Would definitly recommend to play homeworld 1 and 2 before this one, eventho for story sake it doesn't really matter.

Now give me a homeworld where the beast is re-introduced please!

reviewText:
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a very good game for fans who adore the Homeworld franchise as much as I do. It has the same look and feel as the Space-RTS. The missions are interesting and offer variation. Not as much as e.g. Warcraft III, but enough to satistfy. The visuals, sounds, voice-actors, etc. are very very good. The soundtrack and cutscenes reminds me a lot of Homeworld I. The developers really did a great job of re-enacting!

Sadly the campaign is very short and the story provides not many highlights, except for a little story-twist in the end. The developers could have implemented more and longer cut-scenes to lengthen the story, explaining more background information. Especially the transition vom Deserts of Kharak to Homeworld I.

With that said, I hope that the sales go well, so that the developers will be able to create Homeworld III.

reviewText:
These thoughts are regarding the campaign.

I get terribly stressed out playing RTS, and so I play them all on the easiest difficulty and mostly for the atmosphere and story. This game has both of it. The desert is looking gorgeous and the story is subtle and compelling. The campaign gives you a sense of discovery and adventure.

You get to keep your units between missions and see them level up, gaining many times the power it had when it was a rookie. You get a feeling of responsibility towards the survival of said units, and I've reloaded a save game many times in order to save a unit from getting destroyed.

Otherwise the mechanics of the game are pretty straight forward. It's a case of stone-rock-scissors, even up in the tiers of units. You gather resources and spend them on new units (up to a unit cap that increases during the campaign) and on research which is done from the carrier which acts as your mobile base.

For the atmosphere and story I thoroughly recommend this game. I can't speak for the challenge, seeing that I played the game on easy.

reviewText:
A ground based RTS that feels like a space opera.

The aesthetics are varied even when set only in the desert. Each level feels different, whether it's set at night or set in a sandstorm. Vehicle design is spot on.

The level design has goals that are varied and the story keeps you gripped wanting to play one more level.

It's a tactical game that encourages you to be cautious and use the terrain to your advantage and to keep hold of your units to promote them as resources are limited. Saying that I had alot of fun rolling in with my carrier using it as a mobile siege engine and decimating the enemy at close quarters and stealing the enemy units to bolster my own.

A solid game worthy of the Homeworld legacy.

reviewText: I've just purchased this game, I haven't put very much time into it but I can spot an amazing game when I see one. This game is fantastic. As a huge fan of the original Homeworld games, I was cautious about a Homeworld prequel game, especially given the fact that the game was being developed by someone other than the original developers, Relic. My fears appear to have been unfounded. What struck me immediately was the tone and feel of Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak. It's pitch perfect, completely reminicent of the original games. Everything, down to the music, effects and even the comm chatter between units...it's all so great. I've played 3 of the campaign missions thus far, and the gameplay is fantastic. Controls are smooth, intuitive, simple and easy to use. Combat requires a bit of strategy (for example, using terrain for a height advantage, using unit abilities to turn the tide of a battle) and it's challenging but for me the bottom line is always...is it fun? YES, yes it is. Given what I've seen thus far, I am so pleased that the Homeworld series appears to have risen from the dead. The series appears to be in the capable hands of Blackbird Interactive and Gearbox Software and if this game is any indication of what the future might hold...the future of Homeworld seems bright indeed. I'll likely update this review as I get further into the campaign and try out the Skirmish mode, but as of this moment I highly, highly recommend to anyone who loved the original Homeworld games or fans of RTS games in general. Go buy it!

reviewText:
I've played all of the Homeworld games - Including Cataclysm. My favorite game was H2, however this game has become my favorite game out of the series. I just finished it on normal and it took me about 21 hours. That isn't too bad considering I haven't tried multiplayer or skirmishes yet.

One of the major reasons why I love it so much, is that you can take the campaign at your own pace. What I mean by that is that you can resource first, and hoarde the CUs before you complete mission objectives most of the time. This gives you alot of flexibility and you end up being able to change your strategies often to minimize unit loss, and cause the most destruction.

I'm not a huge fan of RTS games where the meta is fast and cheap zerg strategy. You never really get to use the really cool, heavy units and It's just, well - Boring to me. THIS game does not seem to reward the fast and cheap strategy. It was all about the heavy, destructive units. I had a lot of fun using them! There are a TON of resources in the mid to late game missions and it's nice to be able to really max out your fleet easily enough.

Fair warning - The game does NOT auto-collect resources if you finish a mission, so make sure to collect all the resources you can in the early to mid campaign.

Another thing that impressed me was the amount of unit abilities, things you can research, combinations of ships where their skills compliment eachother. It seems well put together. The unit pathing is fairly easy to control - I rarely if ever mis-moved units to their death.

Air units are sick. Make sure to take out AA. Did I mention the air units are sick?

Turrets are sick. Make sure to set up regular and AA turrets. They will make things easier for you to defend.

Use the higher ground tactics with units and turrets - Sit them at the top of a hill and they do more damage and get a bonus to armor as well I think.

The story was good. It ties in directly with HW1. The ending could have been better, but that's all I'll say about it.

One thing I missed is the mothership/small carrier upgrading where you would make them what you wanted in terms of modules. This game has a linear upgrade path and you don't get a choice as to how they upgrade except in two ways; 1. You can collect artifacts (Carrier plug-ins) 2. You can research carrier upgrades. So it's limited in that sense. However, you do use the heck out of the main carrier - The Kapisi. Without spoiling anything - You eventually get smaller carriers capable of construction, and they're awesome. You'll see.

You also use the main character's baserunner a lot. She gets some really awesome abilities. One of them is hacking. Use it on the larger enemy ships for some free crusiers ;) She also gets EMP which is crazy - It really does a number on enemy units.

The audio is what you'd expect - Excellent. It feels like a Homeworld game in every sense.

The effects are very well done. The turrets, missiles, lasers, engine sounds, explosions - All very immersive.

The graphics are very good IMO. There are some anomalies here and there like clipping of units through things, but it's not too bad.

Game optimization is excellent. I have an i5-2500k and an nvidia 660ti 2GB w/16gb of DDR3 and a Samsung 256GB 850pro SSD. Ran the game on full ultra settings. The game ran most of the time at 60FPS. Some cutscenes dipped below that, but I never saw stuttering or artifacting, etc. Top notch programming there.

I love the art style. The detailing of the maps, units, backdrops, etc. are great. I spent a lot of time just looking around at all the units :D

Overall, I'd rate this a 10/10. The reasons that I've described can all be funneled down to one thing - I had a LOT of fun playing the game and couldn't put it down.

Thank you BBI and Gearbox for an awesome game! I'm excited for the next Homeworld installment! Hopefully it's 3D/Set in space :)

-BoostBlitzen

reviewText:
When I first loaded up Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak and dove into the first mission, I knew it felt right within seconds. The technical sci-fi unit chatter was there, the strategic overlay was a familiar blue with helpful unit icons, and my fleet was setting off into the emptiness of space the desert.

DoK is a love song to the original 1999 Homeworld in all of the best ways.  Although I found myself missing the Z-axis, the rest of the Homeworld formula remained quite intact--from the strike/armored/ranged/cruiser unit types to the versatile camera movement. It also speaks to the fluid controls that I was able to play the entire game easily with a Steam Controller :)

The story in DoK also does a great job of mirroring the great continuity that was present from mission to mission in vanilla Homeworld.  You are not jumping around the planet/galaxy on various missions like in a Starcraft or C&C game--it is just your fleet on a long, difficult journey.  And true to the 1999 original's legacy, your fleet persists from mission to mission, so units left alive at the end of a battle are able to continue on in the campaign (now with helpful veterancy bonuses).

One place where I was a little disappointed was with the difficulty of DoK.  Although the campaign's strong narrative does a good job of making you feel a sense of urgency, I found that I was able to take losses and keep going way more than I could in the original Homeworld--even on Hard difficulty.  This lack of extreme difficulty also made the game effectively shorter for me (17 hours for the campaign) than its 1999 brother, even though I think the number of campaign missions was comparable.

The easier difficulty could be partly due to lulls in the fighting that allow ample time for your salvagers to hoover up every last resource in the AO--a tactic that was essential in 1999 Homeworld--so I was rarely wanting for resources.  But I really only found myself sweating before I had built up a fleet in some of the early missions, and in a couple cases where my fleet was not available on account of some smaller scale missions.

But I have a fix for these gripes.  I was not planning on getting the Homeworld: Remastered Collection before; but DoK has left me so thirsty for the brand of storytelling that has been true of all of the Homeworld games that I cannot resist grabbing the Remaster at this point.

Feels like Homeworld. Looks like Homeworld. Sounds like Homeworld.

Doesn't play like Homeworld. Units are bland and boring. Maps are incredibly small. reviewText:
I'm recommending this game, but a bit tentatively.

I've been a homeworld fan since around 2001, and am in the camp that thoroughly enjoyed the remastered version. While I'm overjoyed to see the original developers back in control of the IP and doing new things with it, I don't think this game ended up being what I wanted it to be.

It's a ground-based RTS that tries to be like the space-based games in some respects. This works well in some ways, but is a bit odd in others. Aircraft, the units most like units in the original games, are pretty nuked, and maneuvering/management of ground units is less seamlessly intuitive than fleet management in 2 or RM. I found myself playing a LOT of the game out of the sensors manager, because it was too difficult to get a strategic view from the main camera.

When I heard BBI got the rights to use the Homeworld Universe and was going to turn Hardware: Shipbreakers into a prequel, I was most excited to see them draw on the existing body of backstory from the first game. This they certainly did in spades; the main antagonist of the game is discussed at length in the original game's manual, and indeed I went back to read my ~15-year-old copy to understand the plot better. They did a great job fitting the campaign's plot into the existing mythos, and even the retcons make perfect sense and don't feel weird given the plot of the first game.

However, though the campaign story was exactly the one I wanted to be told, I don't think it was told very well. All the events I wanted to see happened on-screen and seemed to make sense within the mythos, but some of them just felt... awkward. The game seemed to expect players to be familiar with the plot of the first game, and so did not conceal critical information or make certain assumptions that I think should have been in place in the first half of the campaign. The main voices in the game transitioned far too rapidly from early exposition to a mentality that seemed more suited to AFTER the game's plot, and seemed to demonstrate knowledge of a certain ship's specific nature well before they should have known or even guessed that information. I would have really liked to see this story told with a greater degree of unfamiliarity and doubt on the part of the characters; it would have made the wonder of the final revelation much more dramatic, the way I always pictured it when playing the first game.

I also found the campaign painfully short. Homeworld is known for its short campaigns that give you just enough to invest you, not enough to satisfy you, but the norm is 16 or 17 missions. HW:DoK has 13. I could point out specific parts of the map that I feel could have had additional missions.

Overall, the campaign felt rushed, and some of the game mechanics feel somewhat underdeveloped. I would have loved to see more done with the heat mechanic, for example. The unit designs don't present as cohesive of a theme as the original game's did, and though I give BBI props for recreating the 'feel' of 2 nearly seamlessly in a completely different game engine (Unity), the graphics didn't blow my mind and make me squee the way HW:RM's did.

So, why am I recommending this game if I'm giving it so much flak? A couple reasons. Firstly, I think some of the game's limitations are due to the nature of its production. I almost feel like it would have been a better game if BBI had NOT gotten the rights to the IP, though I'm still glad they did. I'm not sure this game was ready to be the next Homeworld game"

reviewText:
7/10 game.

Solid gameplay with a few minor glitches and bugs.

The things I enjoyed was the music, the 'spacebar' minimap (the same with the other Homeworld games) and the units.
The music was very reminiscent of the Homeworld series.

The minimap worked good and I found myself using it a lot to direct units, it’s quick to change from the tactical map to normal view. I did not find it an issue at all that there was no permanent minimap on the corner of the screen.

The units that you can build are not overwhelming, the first three attacking units that you build in the campaign are very rock, paper, scissors. however at the end of the campaign I stopped building them in favor of the heavier 'cruisers' and 'basebuilders' and I just turtled for when the enemy arrives.

The bugs I have come across was when your vehicle's randomly started doing barrel rolls as they drive forward. random stuttering (not from my pc), one random air unit that died and was still floating in the air, shadows in some of the cinematics were not full (very choppy), small texture bugs in scenery and unit selection boxes or attack move boxes staying up (cycling to the minimap helped remove that).


Still a good campaign for the $40 i paid for it, it was worth it.

I would definitly buy this again, I know the - is  more then the + but the game itself is very enjoyable.
And most the - points can be fixed in future patches, like AI, bugs and making mapdesign more viable to discover.
Would definitly recommend to play homeworld 1 and 2 before this one, eventho for story sake it doesn't really matter.

Now give me a homeworld where the beast is re-introduced please!

reviewText:
A ground based RTS that feels like a space opera.

The aesthetics are varied even when set only in the desert. Each level feels different, whether it's set at night or set in a sandstorm. Vehicle design is spot on.

The level design has goals that are varied and the story keeps you gripped wanting to play one more level.

It's a tactical game that encourages you to be cautious and use the terrain to your advantage and to keep hold of your units to promote them as resources are limited. Saying that I had alot of fun rolling in with my carrier using it as a mobile siege engine and decimating the enemy at close quarters and stealing the enemy units to bolster my own.

A solid game worthy of the Homeworld legacy.

reviewText:
TL;DR

Game is fun. Units are well thought out and the game is welcoming of many different strategies. Campaign could be longer, there could be more skirmish maps, but overall quite fun for any RTS fan.

Long Review

Some of the top reviews for this game are negative. I'm not sure what angle they're coming at the game or what their background on RTS games is, but I can assure you that if you're an RTS fan, especially if you're a Homeworld fan, you will enjoy this game.

It plays very similar to Starcraft in terms of unit construction, resource gathering, giving orders to units and other aspects. If you're looking for a grand-scale RTS like Supreme Commander, Total War, Age of Empires / Mythology or anything like that, don't even consider this game. It's decidedly very small-scale.

The main object of the gaim is centered around these giant, land-going aircraft carriers. We won't discuss the necessity of such a device, but the aim is to protect your own and destroy your enemy's. They have very high health but poor defense systems, and can be upgraded in a variety of ways by shunting" power to their various systems

reviewText:
Before we start the Music is 10/10, the best part about it, same guy who did HW1 and 2.

The game is fun, but it is really simple, I bet you can play it on a console.

Not alot of units
Not alot of unique things to do

X is better than Y which is better Z however X is better than Z so its balanced... and thats about it, theres no X1 or X2, no Y1 or Y2, no real variation.

Also the graphics are subpar at best for a game supposodly in prodcution for such a long time plus we are in 2016, Company of Heroes 1 looks better. A desert landscape isnt that hard to do I assume? The units have really crappy textures. What i find annoying is the game forces you to use Ultra graphics forced with ANTIALIASING which is the prime FPS killer. I try to cancel AA but then the game gives me a message my hardware isnt good for this game and turns textures down to high, If you want to use Ultra textures you are forced to enable AA.

Homeworld is bascially dead, they tried to cash in on the homeworld name but had they released this game as a standalone and not with the homeworld game perhaps it would have been taken in a better light, but the expectations that people expect OF a homeworld game are not really here.

TL;DR

Gaem doesn't have the graphics people expect in 2015-16 ( modders will, ofcourse, fix that soon )( HW2 original looks better)
Gaem is really simple to play, not complex like in Homeworld 1 or other such RTS's,
Gaem multiplayer is kill already, (4000 people in game, 1 online game being hosted) lessons from HWR learned

I'll still recommend it, just for the story.

reviewText:
I'm a RTS guy but I've never played Homeworld(embarassing) so I went in having no expectations or love for the franchise.

Pros:
Beatiful
The carrier as a centerpiece is very unique compared to other RTS
Engaging solo player, good story
Streamlined unit production and tech tree
Captured my imagination! I get so excited when I call in a massive airstrike or send in a cruiser squad.

Cons:
Very short solo campaign
Combat feels like rock paper scissors sometimes
Multiplayer only has 6 maps and 2 game modes
I personally don't like limited resource games, it's fun to have gamnes drag out for an hour sometimes

Conclusion:
This game is super fun and I'm glad I bought it. Def got my moneys worth. However I don't see myself putting in 500 hours like some of my other strat/rts games I have, the replayability just isn't there. Although the devs seem like the sort of company who stick with a game and continue to improve/release stuff so I'll be checking back in waiting for content.

reviewText: Home world on the ground? At first I was a bit skeptical. But since I have loved the other Homeworld titles I got the pre-order. Jumped into the story and wow! A must have for Homeworld and RTS fans.\n\nMy only complant is the bad AI in skirmish mode. But according to the devs, they are working to revamp it and add new content.
